PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Senators in Parliament assembled, your humble petitioners showeth that the proposed Australia Card will have a dramatic impact on the lives of all Australians, and your petitioners therefore request a national referendum on the Australia Card Bill before the proposal is resubmitted to Parliament.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) that we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Australia Card
(2) that this national identity system will be intrusive, will not appreciably combat tax or social security fraud, is authoritarian and alien to the Australian way of life
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
urge the Government to institute a national referendum on the Australia Card Bill before the proposal is re-submitted to Parliament
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully requests that the Australia Card Legislation be rejected because the proposed system:
1. has been demonstrated to have no capacity to stop tax evasion, Social Security fraud, illegal immigration or to recoup the revenue lost through abuse of these systems as was claimed.
2. will impose a large financial impact on Australian citizens, and has been demonstrated by the Parliament's own Joint Committee to be not cost effective.
3. has been shown to have the capacity to actually aid and abet both illegal immigration and organised crime.
4. is designed to cause a great intrusion and disruption to the normal day to day activities of all citizens.
5. does not contain the very necessary barriers to invasion of privacy, and loss of personal liberties.
6. will in both the words of the Government and the HIC be enlarged to encompass far greater uses, and the compilation of much more information on the data base.

And your petitioners humbly pray that in the light of the obvious and proven inability of the proposed Australia Card to achieve its stated objectives that the Government explain the reason why it is persisting in reintroducing this legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth;

That we the undersigned, having great concern because of the threat to personal freedom posed by the introduction of the Australia Card, call on the Government to withdraw the enabling legislation on the following grounds;
1. Expert opinion does not agree ``that a National identification system for all Australians'' would ``combat tax evasion and welfare fraud''.
2. Once established at enormous cost to the taxpayer, the system would be here to stay.
3. The potential for the invasion of individual privacy by persons unknown to the private citizen is so great as to be unacceptable to us.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will protect this society by rejecting the Bill outright. And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Senate in Parliament Assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we believe that the Australia Card Bill is unacceptable to a free and democratic people. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Reject any legislation which seeks to implement the intrusive Australia Card proposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled;
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we believe there to be cheaper, more efficient means of combating social security and taxation fraud than those contained in the Australia Card Bill.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should: Consider these alternatives and reject any legislation which seeks to implement the intrusive and expensive Australia Card proposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Smoke Free Air Travel
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned,
(i) are greatly disturbed by the dangers to health posed by passive smoking, and evidence of which is being documented daily by medical authorities around the world;

(ii) note that environmental tobacco smoke has been identified as the major pollutant in aeroplane cabins, and that its direct threat to health is recognised in the special leave provisions for flight attendants specifically on grounds of upper respiratory infections;

(iii) appreciate the government's undertaking to legislate for smoke-free travel on aeroplanes, but are dismayed at the apparent reluctance to follow up the Minister for Aviation's December announcement with action; and

(iv) call upon the government to make smoke-free aeroplane travel a reality without further delay, and to ensure that smoke-free areas which cannot be contaminated by recycled pollutants, are available at all aerodromes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament assembled.
The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia.
Respectfully showeth
that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide, independent radio and television service.
that the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia.
that the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources, would destroy the independence of the Corporation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Honourable Senators will oppose the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programmes of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned expresses concern that some scientists in Australia are intent on undertaking destructive experimentation on human embryos. This subject was examined exhaustively by the 1985-86 Senate Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill which received 270 submissions and more than 2,000 pages of evidence. The report of the Senate Committee recommended in October 1986 that the Commonwealth Government make unlawful any destructive experiment which frustrated the development of the human embryo.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
Implement without delay the major recommendation of the Senate Select Committee to outlaw destructive experiments on human embryos.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Public Order in the Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows that:
There is widespread concern at the increasing breakdown of public order in the A.C.T.
This breakdown is shown by the recent increase in reports of violent assault-one of which concerned the tragic death of a young man at a school fete.
The involvement of groups of youths in some of these assaults causes particular concern.
Such behaviour is affected by the ready availability, to young people, of alcohol and video and films which depict extreme violence.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Parliament to:
Make unlawful the creation of a public nuisance by loitering.
Ensure the enforcement of laws which prohibit the public consumption of alcohol by under-age persons, and
Legislate to restrict the production, distribution and sale of material which depicts extreme violence.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Jack High Bowling Tournament, 1988

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TEXTILES, CLOTHING AND FOOTWEAR INDUSTRIES PLAN

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer the Minister to comments in interviews reported in the Times on Sunday of 29 November and in today's Australian, in which he admits to doubts as to whether the seven-year span of the textiles, clothing and footwear (TCF) industries plan is too long. Is the Government giving serious consideration to changing the TCF plan before it even starts? If so, in what respects? If not, does the Minister agree that his thinking aloud or, as the Australian today described it, `his disarming habit of anticipating, and agreeing with, most of the criticisms made of the past performance of his industry policy', will contribute only to industry uncertainty?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly agree that, as a result of a number of factors which have impinged on sectoral plans of one kind or another, some of those plans are too long. I am asked specifically about the textiles, clothing and footwear industries plan. I think seven years is a very long period to project into the future a regime of assistance for this industry. Of course the Industries Assistance Commission recommended that there be such a seven-year plan post-1988 and, in the context of the debate which took place arising from the IAC report, the notion of a seven-year plan was accepted by the Government, as indeed it was by I think all parties, including the Opposition. The reason for that, I suppose, was that the IAC report laid down a sort of bench-mark period which all sides in the debate tended to adopt, including the Government. Nonetheless, I say that that is a very long period for an adjustment process to take effect.

ANSWER.PARA: I have been asked whether I am giving serious consideration to changing the plan. First of all, if I were, I certainly would not spell out the details of any consideration one might have about that in answer to a question in the Senate. If there were to be any changes to the textiles, clothing and footwear plan, one thing is quite clear: those changes would have an element of continuity which goes to the essence of the plan maintained by the Government. I do not know what the last part of Senator Lewis's question was but I do not think it was to the point, which was trying to find out from me whether there are any specific changes to the textiles, clothing and footwear plan before the Government at the moment. The answer to that is no.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister not appreciate that there are business people out there in the world who are committing themselves to many millions of dollars of expenditure on the basis of something which the Government announced last year and which was agreed to last year? Not only is the Government speculating in the newspapers but also the Minister has speculated in his answer to my question today about the possibility of changing this plan. Does he want me to repeat that?
—I understand that.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance and relates to the call by Mr Nobby Clark, the Managing Director of the National Australia Bank and Chairman of the Business Council of Australia's task force on the role of the Government, for the States to produce figures on their budgets using a common accounting framework. First, is the Minister aware that Mr Les McCarrey of the Institute of Public Affairs has publicly endorsed Mr Clark's call and has supported the argument that this would facilitate the setting of Commonwealth Government budgetary policy? Secondly, can the Minister indicate whether he has received any communication from the Queensland Government indicating that that State intends to respond positively to these calls for improved government accounting and accounting disclosure practices?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday of the week before last, that is, 13 days ago, I answered a similar question regarding Mr Clark's earlier comments and stated that the Commonwealth Government strongly supported the call for more adequate and accurate disclosure of financial information by State governments. I have noted that Mr McCarrey also supported that call. Mr McCarrey, for those who have not heard of him, is the Director of the States' Policy Unit of the Institute of Public Affairs, an organisation of which Senator Stone, in one of his previous incarnations, was officially described, I think, as a senior fellow. Bearing that in mind, I was rather surprised to read that Mr McCarrey had said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . I totally endorse Mr Clark's call for the Commonwealth and the States to compile and publish net PSBR estimates for the whole public sector on a uniform basis. At present only one State, South Australia, provides estimates for the State public sector based on the ABS methodology as part of the budget process. Victoria provides estimates for the budget sector only which is of little value given that major spending authorities such as SEC are off-budget. New South Wales has most of the information in its otherwise excellent set of budget papers and I am sure would have little difficulty in pulling it together.
As I said, I was rather surprised to read that Mr McCarrey had said that because Mr McCarrey, in one of his previous incarnations, was the Under-Secretary, I think the term is-

TALK.START.PARA: —Under-Treasurer.

—He was the Under-Treasurer in Western Australia and in that capacity presided for many years over Charles Court's Budget outcomes, which always came in with a surplus of half a million dollars, or thereabouts, which Sir Charles Court used to describe as good housekeeping. It was, of course, no such thing. It was the outcome of the shuffling of money in and out of hollow logs and trust accounts, as anybody with the slightest comprehension of the difficulty of estimating with any precision government revenue or expenditure or the balance between the two would well know. These claims by Sir Charles Court as Premier year after year, with a surplus of half a million dollars or less, which he described as good housekeeping, occurred during the period when Mr McCarrey was Under-Treasurer. He did not appear to have any objections to that sort of shonky accountancy in that time.

ANSWER.PARA: I was asked whether I had received any communication from the Queensland Government on that matter. The answer is that I have not received any communication from the Queensland Government. It is of course a matter of notoriety that of all the State governments the Queensland Government shows the least public financial accountability for its transactions, to the point indeed where it does not even have a public accounts committee. To the best of my knowledge, there is no firm proposal from the new Premier, and the allegedly new regime, that they will have a public accounts committee. I commend this issue to Senator Stone as one which he might take up, he having been critical two weeks ago of the Commonwealth Government's alleged failure to provide the Auditor-General with sufficient resources and money. I commend this matter of Queensland negligence in this area-negligence or worse-as a matter which he might take up as a Queensland member of the National Party. It is also of course one of the matters that fall directly in his shadow portfolio responsibility-that is, insofar as the Department of Finance has the primary responsibility within the Commonwealth Administration for presenting government accounts. So in his dual capacity as the shadow spokesman for finance and the most senior parliamentary representative of the National Party in Queensland, if not the Party machine in that State, it is something that he might well take up with his Queensland colleagues.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Finance. I refer to the front page article in today's Australian Financial Review reporting a strongly worded call by the Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia for the Government to undertake policy shifts to speed up economic adjustment in Australia in the face of a continuing deterioration in domestic and international economic prospects. I ask the Minister to confirm the reports referred to in that article that the next round of economic forecasting by the Government's Joint Economic Forecasting Group (JEFG) has been brought forward a month to 22 December, and that his Department is pressing for early and substantial policy adjustments, in particular by way of expenditure cuts. Is this a belated recognition by the Government of the inevitability of economic policy adjustment by Australia in the wake of the world financial market crash, and in particular of the need for a mini-Budget early in the new year?

—I am not sure whether I got all Senator Stone's questions down. The first referred to the article itself. I was rather too busy this morning doing other things to read all the article. I did, however, have a quick scan through it. I am not therefore able to confirm its essential accuracy or otherwise. I was also asked about the Joint Economic Forecasting Group and whether a report was coming through on 22 December or whether JEFG plans to produce a report by 22 December. The answer is: not to my knowledge.
—That it would meet by that date.

—That it would meet by 22 December? That might be so. But to the best of my knowledge, the JEFG report will be presented to the Government towards the end of January. I do not think there is any precise date scheduled for that. If Senator Stone is interested in economic information, and particularly the outlook for future Commonwealth Budgets, I inform him that either this week or next week-this week if time permits-the Government will be publishing the Estimates of forward expenditure. There will be in those Estimates a graph illustrating the real growth in the Forward Estimates of government expenditure going back to the 1980 or 1981 Budget. That graph will show very clearly the consistent pulling down of forward Estimates expenditure growth almost every year since the 1982 Budget. Those people who are familiar with these matters will realise that the shape of the curve is influenced by the scale on both axes of such a graph. This graph will show very clearly that up until 1982, Estimates of forward expenditure, which are derived from settled government policies and ongoing legislation, were climbing at an extremely rapid rate. Every year since then, these Forward Estimates have been progressively reduced-if not in every year, then certainly in every year but one. In this year's Budget the actual expenditure growth in real terms is negative for the first time and Senator Stone should compare this graph with the sorts of Forward Estimates curves that he looked at when he was Secretary to the Treasury when Mr Howard was Treasurer. The Forward Estimates curves which will be published this week or next week should meet with Senator Stone's unqualified approval.

—I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer, in particular for the Forward Estimates document which he hopes to bring down either this week or early next week. Will the Minister agree that on the basis of this tremendous progress that this Government has made, and to which he referred in his reply, of hauling back the Forward Estimates each year, nevertheless something seems to have gone amiss insofar as the balance of payments deficit still remains at 4 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP)-and that is even on the Government's estimate-that the external debt is still climbing and that the Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank is calling for a faster pace of adjustment?

—In relation to the last comment, I do not know whether the Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank has been accurately reported in the Australian Financial Review. I thought I covered that point in my earlier answer. As to the external account or the current account deficit being estimated at being around 4 per cent of GDP this financial year, that is correct. It was the most recently revised figure; I think it was 5.8 per cent of GDP in the last full year of the Fraser-Howard Government. If the Fraser-Howard Government had been facing the terms of trade which this Government faces in this financial year, then the current account deficit as a proportion of GDP would have been of the order of 10 per cent rather than 6 per cent.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer whether he has seen the claim by David Clark in today's Australian Financial Review:

QUESTION.PARA: OECD statistics show that the proportion of total Australian tax revenue collected by taxes on wages and profits is the fourth highest of the OECD countries?
Can the Minister indicate whether the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) statistics do, in fact, support Mr Clark's claim?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article and David Clark seems to be referring to the OECD figures-and this is the OECD's classification-of taxes on income and profits as a percentage of total taxation. It is true that under that classification, Australia was the fourth highest in 1984 and third highest in 1985. However, Mr Clark's article refers not just to taxes on income and profits, but also to-and these were his own words-taxes on wages. If one is trying to assess the relative incidence of taxes on wages, it seems logically inescapable that payroll tax should also be included. A more important source of distortion which is not taken into account in the particular classification which David Clark seems to be relying on is the separate social security contributions levied on wages in most western European countries and in a number of other countries. In other words, if one adds to what we in Australia call income tax, which includes social security contributions, the tax on wages collected as a social security contribution and the payroll tax in other countries, we find that for 1985, which I believe is the most recent year for which figures are available, Australia is in fact seventeenth out of the table of 23 OECD countries in the proportion of revenue derived from taxes on wages, income and profits. The only countries in that table of 23 which have a lower proportion than Australia are Canada, Greece, the Irish Republic, Portugal, Turkey and the United Kingdom. In other words, on a comparable basis of taxes on incomes, wages and profits as a proportion of total revenue, Australia is about seventeenth in the OECD table, not third or fourth. Therefore, if income tax-taxes on wages, profits and incomes-for Australia is measured as a proportion of GDP, Australia's ranking on that table is even lower; I believe it is nineteenth instead of seventeenth.

—My question is also directed to the Minister for Finance. Is the Minister aware of an article in the Australian Financial Review of last Friday citing figures from the Bank for International Settlements indicating that around 40 per cent of lending to Australia by foreign banks has a maturity of less than one year? Does he agree with Professor Warren Hogan of the University of Sydney that this could lead to refinancing problems if bankers demand a higher premium to continue lending to Australian companies and government authorities? Further, does the Minister share Professor Hogan's concern about the use of foreign borrowings for consumption rather than for expansion of productive capacity? In view of this debt problem, does the Government intend to go on allowing foreign borrowings by private companies to be negatively geared? Finally, can the Minister say what loss to revenue occurred in the last financial year because companies were able to write off the interest payments on these foreign borrowings against their company's profits, thereby reducing their tax liability?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that I got all of those questions down. I did see the article and, if it is correct, as Professor Hogan states, that 40 per cent of the overseas borrowings by Australian banks have a maturity of less than one year-I do not know whether it is correct; I have not had that checked out-it follows inescapably, of course, that those loans will have to be refinanced in some way, either repaid or rolled over, within that one-year period. I was asked whether I am concerned about borrowings for consumption instead of borrowings for production or for investment. I am concerned about that. Indeed, I have stated so publicly on probably half a dozen occasions within the last couple of months. One of the adjustments that needs to be made in Australia is that the domestic savings, as a proportion of national income, need to be increased if our economic problems are to be overcome.

ANSWER.PARA: I turn to the other part of Senator Haines's question. We have been through all this before. Naturally, I do not agree with the conclusions which she reaches. She appears to be, yet again, misidentifying the cause of our current account deficit. While it is true that consumption as a result of equity holders in Australian companies selling their shares at a high price and then blowing some of the proceeds on luxury imports, foreign tours or whatever can have some influence at the margin, the cause of the overseas borrowing is the current account deficit itself. If any nation consistently runs a current account deficit, that means one of two things: either its foreign reserves are run down-and they can be run down for only a limited period-or it must borrow overseas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or sell assets.

—Well, that is a variant of running down reserves. Although Senator Stone apparently does not agree, I, for example, do not see any important conceptual difference between having the Australian Government or any Australian having a deposit with a Japanese bank, denominated in yen, and the Australian Government owning a couple of acres of land in Tokyo which it can sell off at a very attractive price. I do not see any important conceptual difference between the two; Senator Stone apparently does. If banks were not borrowing to bridge that current account deficit and if we were not to run down overseas reserves or assets-since Senator Stone prefers assets to be included as well-somebody else must borrow it. I suppose the bottom line is that if nobody else does it, governments must.

ANSWER.PARA: A paper prepared by the Treasury and released by the Treasurer-I think it was last year but it may have been at the beginning of this year-dealt with the question of interest payments. I point out that, to the degree that Senator Haines's final comment is correct-that is, that interest payments on borrowings by companies can be offset against current year taxable income-that applies whether the money that the company borrows is borrowed domestically or externally.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Local Government: What planning is scheduled to assist the Huon channel region to look for new opportunities to broaden its current dependence on a fairly narrow agricultural base?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Devereux for his question. I was in Tasmania recently--
—A very successful visit.

—I thank the Minister. I was able to announce that the country centres project will take off in the Huon area early in 1988. Fifty thousand dollars has been allocated for the Huon region so that new opportunities to assist the region can be identified. The economic situation in the Huon is that the region has traditionally been dependent on agriculture, especially the apple industry. I well remember its dependence on the apple industry. Honourable senators may be interested to know that I spent several holidays in the Huon as a child, and at that time I went picking and packing apples. So I am very well aware of just how important the apple industry has been. However, there have been some difficulties in that sector in recent years and it is very important that new opportunities be found. Oyster and scallop harvesting are also traditional activities in the region. Australian Paper Manufacturers Ltd has also considered reopening or transferring to another company its pulp mill at Port Huon.

ANSWER.PARA: The importance of the country centres program-not just for the Huon region but indeed for the 11 regions that have already operated country centres projects-is that it brings together local government, chambers of commerce, regional development bureaus and a number of other organisations to identify the strengths and weaknesses of those regions and, through so doing, many new opportunities are identified for each region. I am confident that the Commonwealth's support of the Huon region, through its $50,000 country centres project grant, will help the identification of new opportunities for the Huon region. I am sure that Senator Devereux will keep me well informed of its progress.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer the Minister to the extremely disturbing report by Alan Ramsey in the Sydney Morning Herald of last Saturday about the fragility of the freedom of the Press and, in particular, to a conversation between the Prime Minister and the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), Mr Bob Somervaille, relating to a Four Corners program on Sir Peter Abeles. It is alleged in that article that the Prime Minister said that he was upset to learn that the program was being made and said something like, `We don't fund the ABC to do stories on Peter Abeles'. I ask: Does the Minister accept that his responsibility for the ABC extends to protecting the Corporation from being made the political plaything of the Labor Government? Has the description of him by journalists as the `Minister for mates' reminded him that he has a responsibility to the public interest rather than to the friends of the Labor Government? I further ask: Has the Minister investigated the matters reported on by Mr Ramsey? If not, why not? If he investigated, was the Sir Peter Abeles program the subject of any discussion between the Prime Minister and Mr Somervaille? Does the Minister agree that neither he nor the Prime Minister should be trying to influence the ABC in the way reported upon by Mr Ramsey?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course it is the case that neither I nor the Prime Minister should be trying to influence the programming content of ABC programs, whether it be in relation to Four Corners or any other program. It is not the case that I or the Prime Minister, to my certain knowledge, have sought in any way to influence the content of the ABC Four Corners program on Sir Peter Abeles or, to my knowledge, any other program. It is the case that concern has been expressed about the desirability of a high quality being maintained in ABC programming, with any allegation that is made or any program that is produced justifying whatever conclusions it may draw or any imputations it may lead to on the basis of evidence or other things which would amount to a proper description of the program as a quality one.

ANSWER.PARA: There can be no question whatsoever of any interference with the editorial independence and integrity of the ABC. It is a statutory authority established at arm's length from the Government with a deliberately created charter that ensures that the arm's length relationship is maintained. To my certain knowledge, that relationship not only is fully understood, as one would expect, by the Government, but also is fully respected at all times. Here, as elsewhere, I am afraid, Mr Ramsey's enthusiasms have allowed him to be somewhat carried away, presumably on the basis of information he has received which simply is not justified by the facts as I know them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister to tell the Senate the basis of the `certain knowledge' that he has expressed twice in his answer. I asked him specifically whether he had investigated the allegations. I ask him now to please explain the basis of the certain knowledge, which seems to me to be a very high claim, unless he has been in the Prime Minister's pocket continually over the past 4 1/2 years.
—Mr President, I find that last reference a contemptible one and I ask that it be withdrawn.
—Order! I do not think that there was anything unparliamentary in the remarks.

—To make an allegation that somebody is in someone else's pocket, whoever's pocket it may be, is fair game and I appreciate that, Mr President. I take that on board and I will make the appropriate judgments about some other members of parliament as the occasion arises. For the moment, let me say that my certain knowledge of the matters to which I referred derives from the fact that I was present in the Prime Minister's suite at the time the conversation in question took place.

—In the light of recent statements by the Minister for Defence that Australian naval personnel were being sent to the Gulf to protect Australian flag shipping, can the Minister representing the Minister for Defence inform the Senate how many Australian flag ships operate in the Gulf, how often, and by whom they are protected? Can the Minister also inform the Senate where the naval personnel will be stationed and under whose command?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware that the Minister for Defence has anywhere stated publicly that he is sending anyone to the Gulf. If Senator Wood had read most of the Press reports on the subject, I believe that he would know that at no stage has Mr Beazley stated that Royal Australian Navy personnel were being sent to the Gulf; nor, of course, would it be proper for Mr Beazley to make such a statement. Any such decision, of course, would be made after a submission to Cabinet. My understanding is that, to this time, there has been no discussion of that matter in that body. That is not to say that the subject will not be considered at some stage.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator has asked for other information that I am happy to provide regarding Australian flag vessels operating to and from the Gulf. Five Australian merchant ships go to the Gulf regularly, and on average there are 12 visits a year. In addition, about 12 Australian fishing vessels operate in the Gulf area under joint venture arrangements. There were also 221 ships carrying Australian cargo in the Gulf in the first half of 1987, demonstrating the international character of shipping and the level of activity in the Gulf serving Australian interests. Australia has made no request for protection for its shipping; nevertheless, support has been provided by the British naval presence. For instance, the BP Achiever has been escorted by Royal Navy vessels on the grounds that the British have a majority ownership of BP. Other shipping has received information or informal protection under the `buddy system' whereby vessels schedule their sailing times to coincide with Royal Navy convoys or Royal Navy patrols. Otherwise, countries with warships in the area recognise only an obligation to protect their own flag vessels.

The Government's consideration of the issues will be conducted on the basis of Australia's national interests. These include, firstly, our trade of $2.5 billion with Gulf countries; secondly, our commitment as a major trading nation to the principles of freedom of navigation and the safety of merchant shipping; and, finally, our policy of neutrality and strict even-handedness in our dealings with both Iran and Iraq.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Leader of the Government in the Senate use whatever influence he has to ensure that the failed House of Representatives candidate Senator Peter Walsh ceases to use the Senate to indulge in what Senator Walsh himself on Friday described as `self-indulgent orgies of repetition and recitations of trivia', which have dominated his contributions to the Senate, particularly during Question Time, over the past 4 1/2 years? Will the Minister dissociate himself and the Government from Senator Walsh's criticism of the Senate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find the description of Senator Walsh as a failed House of Representatives candidate, like everything else Senator Michael Baume says, totally out of date. Senator Walsh is recognised throughout this country as a highly successful Minister for Finance and a highly successful senator. That is more than could ever be said of Senator Michael Baume, who certainly fills the criteria of being a failed member of the House of Representatives, a failed senator and a failed shadow Minister for health.

ANSWER.PARA: Insofar as Senator Walsh sometimes indulges in repetition in this chamber, that is normally at Question Time, and the repetition is absolutely necessary because it seems that, after months and months or indeed years of repetition of important economic facts and issues, still the Opposition does not understand. If anything, Senator Walsh is to be encouraged because hope springs eternal in the human heart. It may be that some day the Opposition will understand and learn. So to that extent my colleague Senator Walsh is to be encouraged. If from time to time Senator Walsh engages in behaviour which might be regarded as mildly aberrant, as do all honourable senators--

TALK.START.PARA: —Speak for yourself.

—Senator Richardson is another example-I would, of course, exert what influence I have in order to persuade Senator Walsh that he should concentrate more on intelligent repetition of the points which he frequently makes at Question Time. We will do all we can to see that that happens.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I regret the evident inability of the Government to exercise any effective influence over Senator Walsh. However, I again ask Senator Button: Will he disassociate the Government, and particularly Government senators, from Senator Walsh's endorsement of the Treasurer's description of the Senate as the swill of Australian politics?

—The Treasurer is quite capable of speaking for himself on these matters. The purview of the Treasury portfolio is wide and I think that the Treasurer is quite entitled to speak on such matters. Insofar as Senator Walsh made some comments which might be regarded as derogatory of the behaviour of certain senators, if the cap fits, people such as the honourable senator will have to wear it.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. No doubt the Minister is aware of recent Press reports regarding the Opposition's plans to cut up to $7 billion from assistance programs to the unemployed, the sick and single parents as part of its far reaching Budget agenda for the 1990s. Other areas reported to be on the Opposition's hit list to achieve spending cuts of around $11 billion over the medium term include health, with cuts to Medicare; education with the introduction of tertiary fees; culture; and recreation. Will the Minister inform the Senate whether the Government intends to follow the course of action allegedly planned by the Opposition and will he give the reasons for the Government accepting or rejecting such a plan?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I can say that the Government rejects or accepts something called a plan because there is no Opposition plan of which I am aware; what there is is a lot of windy rhetoric. We have become accustomed to a lot of windy rhetoric from the Opposition going back to the time when it was in government. I am sure that Senator Stone would remember this very well: in May 1981 a statement was made by the then Treasurer, Mr Howard. Prior to this May statement in 1981 there had been a buildup of months and months of hype about how the razor gang was going to take the axe to excessive government spending. The razor gang met for several months beating up expectations in the Press about this major statement and change of direction that was about to be made. When the details were finally released what Mr Howard, the then Treasurer, proposed was a cut of some $360m off the Forward Estimates of expenditure for the succeeding years, most of which never happened because John Howard did not have the intestinal fortitude to proceed with those very limited cuts.

ANSWER.PARA: There are two possible responses to the most recent windy rhetoric from Mr Howard. One is that none of it should be taken any more seriously than the 1981 record would justify and the other is that he actually means it. Even if he did mean it it would be subject to veto from various other pressure groups that hang around the Opposition. The people who hold the real power in the Opposition do not include the Opposition Leader. John Elliott, the Queensland branch of the National Party of Australia and a number of other extra-parliamentary groups are the people who hold the real power in the Opposition-not John Howard. But if it is to be taken seriously at all, he did talk about reducing government expenditure to the same proportion of gross domestic product (GDP) that prevailed in the late 1960s. That would require a reduction of close to 3 per cent in expenditure as a proportion of GDP, or around $11 billion. He has been reported in some cases as having advocated expenditure cuts of $13 billion. I am not sure what the basis for that is. The cutting of government expenditure by $11 billion, leaving aside such essentially cosmetic or even fraudulent measures as the re-labelling of health service delivery-for example, shifting that off the Commonwealth Budget, on to the private budget ultimately, without doubt, at higher cost-would obviously require very large cuts in the sorts of programs that Senator Foreman referred to in the question; that is, to education, to pensions, to invalid pensions, to the supporting parent's benefit, to age pensions, and so on.

In response to the last part of the question-that is: will the Government take the Opposition's proposals seriously?-if the Opposition had any specific proposal, I would certainly be willing to look at it; and I think that would be true for the Government as a whole. More than a month ago, in response to a question on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's (ABC) AM program, Mr Howard said that if he was given another interview he would give a detailed list of where expenditure should be cut. The very next day I asked whether I could also have a copy of that list. He has not delivered it to the ABC and he has not delivered it to me. If he will deliver it to the ABC, I expect that it will become a public document. If he will deliver it to me, I will certainly be willing to look at it. But I would not hold my breath, and I would not recommend that Senator Foreman hold his breath either, while waiting for that list.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Why has the Australian Government consistently underestimated Soviet Star Wars research, despite the fact that the Soviet Union is spending more than $2 billion this year on strategic defence initiative (SDI) research and has been engaged for at least 20 years on developing strategic defence capabilities? Why has the Australian Government reserved its unconvincing criticism only for the strategic defence initiative of our ally the United States, despite Mr Hayden's acceptance that SDI is morally superior to the current offensive deterrent? I ask whether the Australian Government will now realistically review its policy position in the light of Mr Gorbachev's admission for the first time last week that:

QUESTION.PARA: The Soviet Union is doing all the United States is doing . . . we are engaged in research, basic research which relates to these aspects which are covered by (SDI) in the United States.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —A lot of people, including Mr Hayden, have said that SDI is morally superior to offensive expenditure on nuclear weapons, and of course that is obviously the case. The big question mark about SDI is whether or not it can ever work and whether the expenditure of scores of billions of dollars or perhaps hundreds of billions of dollars over the years by either of the two super-powers can ever result in an increase in the stability of the international deterrent environment or whether rather, as has been argued so credibly by so many critics of SDI, including the Australian Government, that to embark upon programs of this kind is not to generate greater stability but rather the converse, particularly against a background of a huge uncertainty universally as to whether SDI as an ultimately technologically successful defensive system can ever work. It is against that background that there has been so much opposition to SDI.

ANSWER.PARA: It has never been claimed by this Government that the Soviet Union is not itself engaged in research that could conceivably fit that description. Whether the expenditure figure that Senator Teague has mentioned bears any resemblance to reality is something I would be interested to know, and certainly I would be interested to know his sources on that. It is hardly surprising in the context of the forthcoming ongoing round of negotiations between the Soviet and the United States that Soviet spokesmen are making the best of whatever research effort they may have put into it, obviously as an negotiating tactic, to demonstrate that the United States cannot have it all its own way, that it will result, as everyone has always said, in necessary expenditure by the Soviet Union of a retaliatory or competitive kind and that that particular escalating cycle has started. One would hardly expect the Soviet to be saying anything else, whatever the condition or degree of evolution of its research in this area.

But as I say, nobody on the Government's side has been naive enough for a moment to believe that there has not been some research on the Soviet side which can broadly be so described. The question is how much and whether or not it serves any useful purpose for either of the super-powers to embark upon another massively expensive squandering of resources in the pursuit of a will-o'-the-wisp. That is the background against which the whole SDI debate has been conducted-not with much help or input, I might add, from the Opposition side.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister admits to some Soviet research into SDI. He continues, as does the Government, to underestimate the strategic importance of the extent of the capabilities which the Soviet Union is developing. I ask: In the light of the current evidence and the statement of Mr Gorbachev, will the Australian Government reassess its policy on this matter?

—All I can do is ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Minister for Defence whether they want to respond any further to Senator Teague's question. There is nothing more that I can usefully add on the subject.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and Minister representing the Prime Minister. In light of allegations made on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Four Corners program on 30 November that anabolic steroids find their way into Australia at Perth via United States sailors because the sailors are not subject to Customs checks, does the Government intend to instigate thorough searches of all personnel disembarking from the USS Missouri and other support vessels with it which are due in Fremantle later this week? Why are visiting sailors not subject to Customs clearance checks? Are they tested for sexually transmitted diseases, especially the acquired immune deficiency syndrome, and, if not, why not? Does the Government not consider that it has a primary responsibility for the health of Australians by ensuring that they are not subjected to unnecessary risks by allowing thousands of sailors at a time entry without checks for either illicit drugs or sexually transmitted diseases? Will the relevant Ministers be meeting to discuss proposed actions on these matters because of increasing community concerns?

—I think the relevant Ministers will not be meeting to discuss this matter, but I will endeavour to obtain an answer to Senator Vallentine's question as soon as possible. Senator Vallentine will appreciate that her question embraces a number of portfolios. I would like, however, to congratulate her on the question because, as I recall, all the previous questions she has asked here have related to nuclear hazard. I am glad to see that now she is broadening the scope of her activity to embrace moral hazard and sexual hazard as well. I will attempt to obtain an answer as quickly as possible.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women to the National Women's Consultative Council record of meeting held on 2 and 3 July 1987 and, in particular, to that section dealing with resolutions passed at the meeting. I draw the Minister's attention to the paragraph at the conclusion of the resolutions, which reads:

QUESTION.PARA: A number of other motions which were critical of the outcomes of the May Economic Statement were proposed. Following debate between members it was agreed that while it was important to advise the Government of Council's concerns on these matters it was-
then there is a sentence stating that it is economically unrealistic to expect cuts not to be made-
inappropriate to be publicly critical of the Government so close to the election.
It was agreed that members concerns on these particular issues should be raised in confidence with the Minister Assisting by the Convenor at their next meeting.

As a consequence of that, I ask: What were the concerns raised with the Minister by the convenor which were apparently so sensitive and significant that they needed to be disclosed behind closed doors? Will the Minister provide the Senate with details of which representatives proposed motions which were dealt with in this way, and the substance of each such motion? Is the Minister prepared to assure the Senate that no public servant or Labor Party representative brought any pressure to bear on the meeting to have these matters hushed up? Lastly, given the apparent desire to protect the Government from electorally unpopular comment, can the Minister assure Australian women that the National Women's Consultative Council, without fear or favour, does represent the views of Australian women to the Government?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is obvious that the National Women's Consultative Council is quite willing to make the Opposition aware of its deliberations by providing Senator Vanstone with a record of meeting. That is a very good demonstration that the Council conducts its own affairs. Senator Vanstone is showing a disappointing lack of confidence in the capacities of the women who currently make up the Council. I remind her that the Council is made up of nominees from a range of national women's organisations of very diverse character, but all of which have in common the desire to improve the status of women. There are special interest groups, ethnic interest groups, business and professional women's associations, the Country Women's Association, the National Council of Women, the Women's Electoral Lobby and so on. It is a very wide-ranging Council, representing a major part of the women's movement in Australia. For Senator Vanstone to suggest that somehow it is a puppet of the Government or is intimidated by public servants is to make a quite insulting implication. The Council conducts its own affairs. The Council decides which matters it will raise with me or with the Prime Minister and it proceeds to do that. I propose to refer Senator Vanstone's question to the National Women's Consultative Council and allow it to respond to her suggestions and implications as it sees fit.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. There is a portion of the question that the Minister cannot refer to the Council, because it asks her to give an unqualified assurance that no pressure was brought to bear. Additionally, I suggest that the latter part of my question cannot be referred to the National Women's Consultative Council. To ask the Council whether it is representing the views of Australian women without fear or favour is like asking the fisherman to measure the fish. I am asking the Minister to give her view to the Senate as to whether that is what happens. In addition, I point out that it was not the National Women's Consultative Council that provided me with the record; it was the Office of the Status of Women, at my request.

—I repeat that the National Women's Consultative Council's affairs are for the Council to determine. I certainly would not make available to Senator Vanstone or anybody else details of conversations it had with me, unless it chose those matters to be made available. Of course, I consider that that Council conducts its business without fear or favour, but the Council itself may wish to respond to Senator Vanstone's suggestion that it does not.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a recent report in the Australian Financial Review headlined `Food Importers in Strife'? Is the Minister concerned about the level of food imports within the Australian balance of trade? Is the level of specific food imports an indicator of the success of the Government's economic policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see the report in question, which appeared some time ago, in the Australian Financial Review of 25 November. According to the report-and I have no particular reason to doubt its accuracy-up to 20 local food importing enterprises have gone out of business, and remaining importers are predicting sales slumps of up to 20 per cent next year because a weak Australian dollar has lifted the price of imported goods. If the report is correct, it is a very good practical demonstration that the price mechanism or the J-curve, as the Treasurer calls it, is working and working very effectively. Food-almost all types of food-is one area in which Australia is very well endowed with natural resources with other comparative advantages which make us or ought to make us a very competitive supplier of food not only on the domestic market but also on the export market. If the devaluation of the Australian dollar has had the effect of pushing out of the local market some of the fringe food imports and replacing them with domestic products because of price changes, consequential on the devaluation of the Australian dollar, that is a very good thing. Finally, I refer back to the report upon which the original question was based. I think it is worth noting-and this is not a direct quotation, it is a report-that:

ANSWER.PARA: The national sales manager of the Unilac Company, Mr David Wilson, said the low exchange rate and other economic factors had forced his company to bow out of food importation and concentrate on distributing local food and dairy products.
If that is really happening, any rational person should say that that is a good thing and it is in the nation's economic interest that it should happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to an article in the Canberra Times of 28 November by education correspondent Jeannie Zakharov headed `Legal authority in doubt'. What legal advice has the Minister received regarding the legality or illegality of his action in purporting to dismiss the Council of the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority in September of this year? What legal advice has the Minister received regarding decisions taken since then by the Chief Education Officer? From what source was such legal advice received? Will the Minister be presenting a Bill to this Parliament seeking to legitimise retrospectively decisions made by the Chief Education Officer? If not, what steps will the Minister be taking to remedy the situation?

—I thank Senator Jenkins for giving some late notice of this question. The Government announced substantial changes to the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) education planning arrangements in the 1987-88 Budget. These are aimed at ensuring better co-ordination and efficient management. The Chief Education Officer is to be solely responsible for the management of the ACT schools system and he will be establishing an advisory body to assist him. Those arrangements will require amendments to the ACT Schools Authority Ordinance, which the Minister for Employment, Education and Training will be making before the end of this year. The Schools Authority has not been abolished and the powers of the Chief Education Officer are unaffected.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Hill proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's record of neglect and its failure to pursue sound and consistent policies within the South Pacific region with a consequent loss to Australia of respect and influence.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would suggest that this is a matter of very great importance and something that the Senate should certainly be debating today. It is my view that history will record two great failures of this Hawke Government. One, of course, relates to its economic policy-a debate that is well documented and that we advance in this chamber almost daily. It will be remembered as the time of the collapse of the dollar, when the balance of payments deficit skyrocketed and when Australia moved to what Mr Keating described as a banana republic or Third World status. As I indicated, that is a debate we pursue often.

SPEECH.PARA: I also want to suggest that the other area for which this Government will be remembered-not fondly by historians-relates to its foreign policy and particularly its policy in relation to this region. Its term will be remembered as the period during which Australia lost its natural leadership and a great deal of its respect and capacity to influence events within our region, the South Pacific.

It appears to be a most appropriate time to look at this very serious subject in the light of Mr Hawke having just returned from yet another grandstanding visit, this time to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, apparently, on the basis of evidence that we have, largely to enhance further his already very great ego. I put to honourable senators how the visit was described, very aptly, by Sally Loane in yesterday's Times on Sunday. She talked about the visit and what came out of the visit and she quoted Mr Hawke as saying that his meeting with Mr Gorbachev was `rewarding and stimulating'. She said:

Clearly impressed by the Soviet leader, he used superlatives to describe him. ``He is an engaging human being. There is a warmth. In his conversation there is a vibrance and enthusiasm and quickness of understanding . . . and an attractive preparedness to recognise past weaknesses of position,'' Mr Hawke said.
``I am confident that we have established a cordial, constructive relationship of mutual respect for one another.''.
What Mr Hawke is really interested in is getting powerful people in the world to endorse him. Sally Loane recognised Mr Hawke's assured arrogance when she quoted him as saying of Gorbachev:
He is an intelligent man, and so am I, and we understood the inter-relationships between the issues we were discussing.

I do not know what that means. But, clearly, Mr Hawke very successfully fed his ego on this trip to the Soviet Union. But what was offered to Australia as a result of the visit is highly questionable. What Mr Hawke's staff seem to want to emphasise about the visit is the period of hours that he spent engaged in talks with Mr Gorbachev. They have boasted that in fact Mr Gorbachev held him in audience for only 2 1/2 hours less than he spoke to Margaret Thatcher. That is the boast that comes out of the offices of the staff of Mr Hawke. But what comes of the visit for Australia's benefit?

It is not surprising that Mr Gorbachev should embrace our Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, in audience when he went there largely at his own invitation, remembering, of course, that Mr Hawke asked to be invited. He went there and, in doing so, invited the Soviet Union to become part of our economic and diplomatic community in the South Pacific, and assured it of the very important role that it could play. In other words, he went straight down the line of the policy Mr Gorbachev advanced in his Vladivostok speech of a year or two ago. Mr Gorbachev wanted the Soviet Union in this region, to establish, first, its much greater diplomatic presence and then its economic presence which follows. Of course, as we all know with super-powers, what ultimately comes is a military presence to protect the interests-particularly the economic interests-that are developed. That is the way with super-powers. What has been so pleasing in this region is that we have been able to avoid that situation. It has not been a region of super-power conflict. We had not invited the other super-power, the Soviet Union, into the region in the way that Mr Hawke is now doing. So it is not surprising that he was embraced by Mr Gorbachev and told that he was a fine fellow when Mr Gorbachev got everything he wanted.

I must mention in passing what I believe to be the unsavoury release, in that it was expressed by the Press in terms of a reward, of five or six refuseniks as a result of the visit. I find it entirely offensive to deal with human persons in that way, and perhaps even more offensive when one looks at it in context and realises that there are now only approximately 600 Soviet citizens being released to Israel whereas, in 1974, the figure was about 2,000. There is very little that Mr Hawke has to boast about in the release of those individuals. This visit, like so many other visits of this Prime Minister, shows a mistake in priorities. This view was very well put in the latest Weekend Australian by yet another of the accompanying journalists, Mr Paul Kelly. He wrote at length about interesting aspects of the visit, but then got to the bottom line when he said:
The real worry about foreign policy lies in Hawke-Hayden priorities. It is an axiom that we have a global policy. Well and good. But is globalism an excuse or substitute for defining priorities?
I will not quote Mr Kelly in full, but he also said:
Meanwhile, just look around our region.
In a number of areas Australian policy seems somewhat uncertain. Australian-Indonesian relations are poor . . . Our ties with Papua New Guinea have slipped in recent years . . .

Australia has failed to establish the economic relationship with ASEAN that was hoped for 10 years ago. There is confusion within the Government about how we should exercise political/military leadership in the South Pacific.

That is the point I particularly wish to make: so much for strutting the world stage, the super-power stage, attempting to be part of the big league, but what is being lost as a consequence of that? What is being lost is a concern with what should be our priorities-the priorities of our own region. This has come about in part because of Mr Hawke's insatiable ego and in part because of the rivalry between him and Mr Hayden. It is Mr Hawke who has visited the Soviet Union. It was Mr Hayden who as soon as he got into office immediately set about to solve the Indo-Chinese problem, not by working through it with our friends in the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN) but by attempting to do it in a unilateral way, resulting simply in a deep distrust that still has not been overcome. This has followed from a lack of respect on our part for the sensitivities of our ASEAN friends, the front line states. So it is not only Mr Hawke who has adopted this approach; it has been Mr Hayden as well. To put this matter in context, I remind the Senate that when this Government came to power it said that in foreign policy its first priority was to be the region, the South Pacific. As soon as the Government came to office and stated that-which was commendable-it immediately broke its own rule and headed off on to the world stage to try to make its mark in areas of super-power rivalry where it thought it might receive greater commendation from the powerful.

Why was the South Pacific neglected? No doubt it was because, to Hawke and Hayden, it was small fry. The big players had neglected it, as we know. In some ways that should please us. Mr Hawke and Mr Hayden took the view: `Why should we, Australia, concentrate our endeavours where our efforts would not be rewarded with international status? Besides, it has been a traditionally stable area'. They believed that events could look after themselves. History will recall these assessments as great errors of judgment. It was to be a period of rapid change in the Pacific. Our neglect and disregard have, as I indicated in opening this address, cost us the capacity now to intervene.

Honourable senators could not wish for a better example of how in practice this Government has put into effect its priorities than the fact that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) did not even visit the Pacific in his first three years in office. Now the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) has just finished his first official visit to Pacific states such as Papua New Guinea-one could very well argue that that should have been his first visit-Vanuatu, the Solomon Islands and Kiribati. It was not until the Soviets had negotiated a fishing agreement with Kiribati and subsequently with Vanuatu that the vulnerability of these minute economies to influence from the powerful was suddenly apparent to this Government. It was not until young men from New Caledonia and Vanuatu were being trained in Libya that the Government suddenly appreciated that the small and impoverished economies of the Pacific, with small paramilitary or police forces, were terribly vulnerable to an internal security threat. It was not until democracy in Fiji was snuffed out at the point of a gun that this Government suddenly realised that institutions for securing internal stability in post-colonial Pacific states were highly fragile. But the horse had bolted. We did not even have the intelligence or the diplomatic capacity to predict the chance of a military uprising in Fiji. In some places of the world, that might be excusable. One might ask, `Why did the United States not predict it?'. The important thing is that in places like Fiji, the United States, our allies, rely upon us to provide this information. Traditionally, this has been our area of responsibility, but in this situation we let down not only ourselves but also those with whom we are in alliance.

When democracy was snuffed out, the Australian Government had no idea what to do. Apparently, even the military option was canvassed, but I am pleased to say that sounder heads prevailed. Goodness only knows what the Australian military would have done if it had got to Fiji when, within a few hours of the coup, the problem was not simply a military problem but also a political one. Whilst our diplomats were confident that traditional links and friendships would enable them to facilitate a settlement in typical traditional ways through the Queen, through the Commonwealth and through traditional liaisons such as those, it did not work because Fiji and Fijians saw themselves differently. But of course the Australian Government did not realise that. Then there was the humiliation of the second coup when the Australian Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) reassured the Australian Parliament that progress towards normality was pleasing. That was then followed by the unhelpful grandstanding of the Prime Minister at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting.

The Australian Government still has little idea of how to respond to the problems in Fiji. It has suffered the embarrassment of the union movement taking foreign policy into its own hands. The Australian Government is receiving reports of human rights abuses, but it is unable or unwilling to substantiate the facts surrounding those reports. It is certainly not prepared to advise this Parliament as to whether the allegations are true or false. The Australian Government now sees overtures to the Fijian authorities from South Korea concerning arms, and Fiji's receiving support from both Indonesia and Malaysia from a trade point of view. This Government simply does not know how to respond. It ought to know the cost, both internally and to regional stability, of a complete collapse of the Fijian economy.

No doubt this Government now wishes it had made a little more effort to understand the growing frustrations and the ethnic aspirations that were fanned by a greater consciousness of ethnic solidarity rather than the historical allegiances to which I referred earlier, together with the changes in the Fijian military that arose from its many years' service in the Middle East. I do not have to remind the Senate of the significant part that the military plays in determining political outcomes in the Middle East. All this was overlooked. It seems to be obvious that this Government was both blind and, perhaps more importantly, uninterested. No doubt the Government now sees the incredible short-sightedness of unilaterally further cutting aid to Papua New Guinea last year, shortly after aid reductions had been bilaterally agreed. Sir Julius Chan, the Deputy Prime Minister of Papua New Guinea, said of that action at a conference in the United States last year.
. . . we would not have believed it of Australia. All this for a measly few million dollars.

But the sum is not so important. What is important to Papua New Guinea is that it had already negotiated a reduction in aid and had been prepared to accept that, but within a few months this Government unilaterally reneged and reduced it further. As a result, it has lost respect and its capacity to influence at a time when Papua New Guinea more than ever needs reliable friends. Papua New Guinea is negotiating a new role with the United States of America, which will now provide defence advisers. Obviously, Papua New Guinea no longer has the same confidence in Australia as it once had. No doubt similar feelings were expressed last year when the Australian Government also reduced aid to Vanuatu, Tonga, Tuvalu, Kiribati and the Cook Islands. Certainly, this Government is now trying to rescue its position with respect to Papua New Guinea by Mr Beazley's trip and negotiating a joint declaration of principles, but I suggest that the damage has already been done.

Greater trade opportunities would probably help the Pacific states more than any other single option, yet we export to the South Pacific Forum states more than twice the amount of our imports-$283 compared with $123m. The supposed `liberalising measures' that were introduced by this Government have yielded little benefit. It goes further than simply engendering the frustration and disappointment on the part of island states toward Australia; it has provided opportunities for others to get into the Pacific and to provide greater influence in positions that we once held. Of course, not surprising, those opportunities are being seized by the East Asian states-the Japanese, whose aid, I remind honourable senators, is often tied to Japanese goods and services; the Taiwanese, who are developing interests; and the People's Republic of China, which is now expanding its influence. The linkages established by Australian companies over a long period, which traditionally have been very important to this country, are now being eroded. Windows of opportunity abound for those seeking to expand their influence in the Pacific, and we are providing those windows.

Part of the problem, I suggest, has been our attitude of paternalism. That has shown up even in our defence co-operation project. We said that we would develop, in conjunction with the South Pacific states, a Pacific patrol boat fleet to patrol their exclusive economic zones. Of course, that was a commendable idea, but then we developed boats of an inappropriate design for patrolling open sea distances and too slow to catch poachers. We knew better! The idea was supposed to be that we work together but, patronisingly, we told those states how it should be done. We then failed to understand that the small Pacific states could not afford to operate the boats, so Kiribati and Tuvalu withdrew from the project.

Paternalism has caused us to fail to come to grips with the Melanesian spearhead group. The fact that Melanesian states that traditionally saw Australia in a bilateral context now caucus before South Pacific Forum meetings is something that this Government has failed to cope with. It has pushed Australia to certain positions, for example, championing the independence cause of the Kanaks in New Caledonia. I support the interests of the Kanaks in New Caledonia, even though they are a minority, but it has forced us to go the whole line, with the result that we now have a relationship with France whereby we cannot even get into the debate, whereas the role of Australia in relation to the Kanaks in New Caledonia should have been, as it should have been in so many other areas, one of bringing the parties closer together so that they could work out their own solution.

One could go on if time permitted, and no doubt my colleagues will, to look at how this Government, in so few years, has lost for Australia its importance in the region, its respect and its ability to influence events not only for the benefit of the small Pacific Island states but also in relation to Australia's long term interests and benefits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australian attitudes to the South Pacific when we came into government in 1983 were undoubtedly still characterised by a strong sense of continuing colonial complacency. The South Pacific was perceived to be a Western lake but, in the space of just a few years and as part of the region's accelerating evolution and development, there has been a brand new assertion in that area and, in some important cases, I guess, a reassertion of the values and interests of the countries of the region.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose that events in Fiji were the most dramatic evidence of some of the extreme forms that such assertions can take, but the rate of change that has occurred in the South Pacific in recent years simply has not been recognised widely, even now. Despite all the fulminations we have just heard from Senator Hill, there is no particular evidence that the Opposition has recognised the extent to which the game has been changing. One only has to recall the extraordinarily naive, clumsy and insensitive performance of the former Opposition foreign affairs spokesman, Mr Neil Brown, when in Fiji at the time of the first May coup, to have evidence of the proposition I have just asserted. The Government, by contrast, can claim to have been not only extremely nimble in responding to these various events but also well enough prepared to provide leadership and interpretation to other Western powers. I will justify that statement in a moment by referring to a number of different areas: strategic considerations, regional nuclear concerns, aid or development assistance, defence and trade matters.

Perhaps I should begin by outlining some of the ways in which we have been prepared to play a continuing role. In the first place, in government our response to the region has involved a marked upgrading in the number and, in particular, the variety of ministerial visits that have been made to the region. I make a particular point of this in the light of Senator Hill's criticism, which is simply ill informed. Not only has the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) been to the region twice for South Pacific Forum meetings, not only has Mr Hayden been the only Australian Foreign Minister to have undertaken a really comprehensive tour of Pacific island countries-he went to eight countries in May this year and has participated in Forum meetings-but also as recently as last month Mr Beazley visited five countries; Papua New Guinea, Vanuatu, the Solomon Islands, Tuvalu and Kiribati. Several times I visited Papua New Guinea and participated in a Forum ministerial meeting on New Caledonia in the region. Other visits have taken place by Senator Gietzelt, Mr Willis, Senator Ryan and Mr Lionel Bowen over the period we have been in government.

The traffic has not been one way. There has been a pattern of increasing visits, of both a formal and an informal kind by island leaders to Australia. For example, in just the last few weeks all but one of the following people have visited Australia at their own private initiative: President Tabai of Kiribati, Deputy Prime Minister Tupuola Efi of Western Samoa, Ratu Sir Kamasese Mara, the Deputy Prime Minister of the Solomon Islands, Sir Peter Kenilorea, three members of the Rabuka Administration-Messrs Bole, foreign affairs spokesman; Bose, economic spokesman; and Pickering, the tourism and energy spokesman-and Prime Minister Robati of the Cook Islands. They have all made substantial visits here and they all reflect the continuing role that they see Australia having in this region.

In addition, during our period of government we have not only maintained but also strengthened our diplomatic representation in the area.
