We have accredited representation to the Federated States of Micronesia and the Marshall Islands and we have put additional personnel in Port Moresby, Apia, Suva and Vila. We are represented in all the independent South Pacific countries-nine of them by resident representatives and five by non-resident representatives-and we also have representatives in Honolulu and Noumea.

Australian representatives, without exception, are highly qualified, competent and well respected by their host governments. I should further say by way of general introduction that planning of activities in relation to the South Pacific has been a constant and ongoing feature of the Government's perception of its role in the area. In early 1986 we undertook a review of Australia's South Pacific policy options. In the context of a major policy speech on 21 May 1986 at the University of the South Pacific in Suva, Mr Hayden articulated Australia's approaches to the region. A detailed submission on the South Pacific was prepared for the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence inquiry into the South Pacific, an exercise which is now being supplemented by a further update. In the context of the departmental consideration of the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities and the subsequent defence White Paper, there has been a major assessment of regional security implications for our relationships in the South Pacific region. There have been fundamental reviews of Australian policy towards Papua New Guinea in the context of the joint declaration of principles to be signed this week in Canberra in a very important ceremony. For example, just recently there was a heads of mission meeting which had as its main focus the development of a new strategy for Australia and the region in today's rapidly changing conditions.

I mention all these matters because the picture that has been painted by Senator Hill is one of general indifference to the region, an absence of ministerial focus, concern or physical presence, an absence of diplomatic involvement in the region, an absence of strategic thinking, planning or doing anything out of the way, anything different from the way in which successive previous administrations just assumed that the South Pacific was an unchanging region or sea of tranquillity. That is manifestly not the case for a whole variety of reasons, some of which have been articulated by Senator Hill. He at least knows more of what he is talking about than do most of his counterparts in the Opposition, which is no doubt why he continues to languish on the back bench. There has been full recognition by the Government of the nature of the changes that are occurring in the region and we have done innumerable things to respond accordingly.

Let me turn to the broad policy considerations, the broad sweep of issues, that I foreshadowed previously, beginning with strategic considerations. In 1983 a very thorough review of the ANZUS Treaty checked and confirmed its utility to us. This was the first and essential ingredient in a stocktake of our approach to the region, its welfare and the condition of our policy towards it. It created the policy climate for the Government in responding to challenges to the Treaty arising from the port visits dispute in New Zealand and this enabled us to respond with the confidence which minimised the repercussions in the region and permitted the interim solution of the problem at the 1986 San Francisco meeting between Australia and United States Ministers. Similarly, we were well positions as a result of that exercise to respond to Mr Gorbachev's Vladivostok speech and to follow it through at the Shevardnadze visit in March of this year by securing, at that very high level, Soviet assurance that its activities would be confined to those normal to the diplomatic and commercial spheres. These responses were, we believe, apt and well managed responses to important changes in super-power attitudes toward the region.

There are other such responses. Take, for example, the specifically regional nuclear concerns which have formed so prominent a part in our policy making over the last few years. Early in the period of our Government there was an urgent need for leadership to be shown in responding to rapidly growing concerns in the Pacific about nuclear arms, nuclear testing and nuclear dumping. The detailed development and articulation of policies in the area of peaceful use of nuclear energy and the area of arms control and disarmament positioned the Australian Government to meet that need and to supply the leadership that was required. The Australian initiative, which then resulted in the Treaty of Rarotonga, was a remarkable accomplishment in this region in a period of substantive work of little over a year. Combined with the Convention of the Protection of the Natural Resources and Environment of the South Pacific Region and very important new flexibility in Japan's position about which the Government, including the Prime Minister, made representations, the Treaty of Rarotonga met major Pacific island country concerns about dumping.

The Treaty was also remarkable in achieving an outcome at that time when all of the newly independent Forum countries were satisfied to leave the contentious issue of port visits to sovereign decision rather than adopting a particular policy position. Without Australian leadership in this respect the New Zealand precedent would undoubtedly have been much more powerful and would have produced quite a significant change in the strategic environment of the region.

The Treaty of Rarotonga also addressed strongly held regional concerns about nuclear testing by France at Mururoa, and the Government's credentials on this matter have been fully recognised throughout the region because of Australia's leadership role in the search for a comprehensive test ban treaty, a leadership role which continues to get the very active support of all the Pacific island countries, the United Nations and other multilateral forums.

I turn to the area of aid or development assistance. In 1982 the level of Australian aid to the South Pacific was just $38m per annum. At the 1982 Rotorua South Pacific Forum meeting the then Government-I acknowledge the role that was played in the final year of its term-announced a pledge to the region of a $300m indicative planning figure to be provided as development assistance over a five-year period. This commitment was subsequently confirmed by the present Labor Government. During the five-year currency of that plan, which expires in June 1988, it is expected that approximately $312m in total will have been spent in meeting this pledge. Other aid expenditures not counted towards meeting this pledge will mean that our total aid expenditure during the five-year period will be of the order of $360m. In an interview on Radio Australia last month Mr Hayden stated:
We . . . are, aggregatively, for the region, the biggest aid donor and for almost all of the countries, the biggest aid donor, and this is going to continue.

He said that he did not think that the general nature of our approach would change. Other specific contributions have been made, such as $8m into the trust fund for the Government of Tuvalu, other funds going to cyclone reconstruction activities in the Solomon Islands and Fiji and various bilateral activities pursuant to the $300m pledge implementation, which I have already mentioned.

Turning now to defence in a more specifically bilateral context as distinct from the larger strategic one, which I have already mentioned, consistent with the treatment of the South Pacific in the Government's defence review, the Australian defence co-operation program with the Pacific island countries has been exclusively reviewed and extensively reshaped and now provides, in particular, an important response to the island countries' maritime requirements through the Pacific boat program, the first boat having been handed over to Papua New Guinea in May of this year. The function of the patrol boat is usefully supplemented by the extension of aerial maritime reconnaissance, which is of very great importance to the Pacific island countries in the control of their fishing zones and resources. This development of the defence co-operation program involved a significant addition of defence aid resources to the Pacific and perhaps more importantly in terms of that respect for Australia, which the Opposition's matter of public importance bleats about, it involves a recognition of the high priority needs in the perceptions of the island states themselves. There has been no loss of respect, no loss of influence, in the sense in which they are referred to in Senator Hill's matter of public importance, and that is amply demonstrated in every one of those areas I have mentioned, including finally the subject of trade.

In response to concerns that were expressed at the 1984 Regional Committee on Trade, and subsequently at the South Pacific Forum, Australia undertook a major review of the South Pacific Regional Trade and Economic Co-operation Agreement (SPARTECA). All exports of Forum island countries, other than those to which Australian sectoral policies apply, now enter Australia on a duty free unrestricted basis. Australia and New Zealand have agreed substantially to meet the request put forward at the 1984 Regional Committee on Trade for changes to the SPARTECA rule of origin provision. In the case of apparel, it has been decided to extend the special import quota arrangement, at the existing level, until the end of 1988. Post-1988 arrangements for the whole of the Australian textile, clothing and footwear import market are presently the subject of an inquiry by the Industries Assistance Commission, and the IAC has been directed specifically to address the problems of the island countries and Papua New Guinea in any recommendations that are put to the Australian Government.

So in all the areas that I have very briefly summarised-strategic considerations, regional, nuclear concerns, development assistance, defence and trade-the Government has a very strong 4 1/2 year record of innovation, of sympathetic response and of leadership in the South Pacific. Of course, the evolutionary process which is occurring in the South Pacific, and to which I referred at the outset, will make continuing demands on Australian policy, and there are many very difficult and very sensitive foreign policy issues that will continue to be thrown up as a result of unfolding and often rapidly emerging events in the region. We of course need to be responsive to those concerns and to those events. The process of negotiation that has been in train now for some months with Papua New Guinea and that is culminating in the signature this week of the joint declaration of principles to guide the relationship between the two countries, is designed to provide a whole new framework for the equitable management of the maturing bilateral relationship. To make the sorts of throwaway lines that Senator Hill offered a little while ago about the aid question as it arose last year, and to suggest by implication that as a result our relationship with Papua New Guinea is in a sad and sorry state, is to offer a complete caricature of the reality, as will, I believe, be amply demonstrated by the events of this week as they unfold reflecting, as they do, a very amicable, very constructive, very thoughtful and very mature working through of the new implications of our relationship with our most immediate neighbour, and one for whom we feel a particular respect and affection born of the historic ties between us.

The upheaval in Fiji, which Mr Brown made such a ham-fisted response to when it first happened in May, does point to a delayed rejection, at least in part, by native Fijians of the colonial imposed constitution in favour of greater protection of traditional Fijian rights. That has created a situation causing, understandably, the utmost concern to the Indian ethnic composition of the population of that country, and this has caused utmost concern among Fiji's regional neighbours and, indeed, the reverberations have extended around the world. The Government's handling of this very difficult situation has been something that has been amply debated before in this place. All I will say is that Senator Hill's matter of public importance and his references to Fiji seem peculiarly ill-timed, coming as they do just a day or so after we have had the announcement by Brigadier-as he now is-Rabuka of the decision to stand down as interim head of the Government of Fiji, appointing by decree Ratu Sir Penaia Ganilau as President and, with Ratu Sir Penaia in his turn appointing Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara as Prime Minister, both of them pledging that a new constitution will project indigenous Fijian interests. Of course the proof of the pudding will be in the eating, and initial government responses to these events over the last couple of days have at best indicated cautious optimism about what we all hope will be the case. We certainly do hope that those developments will foreshadow the return of democratic parliamentary government under a constitution acceptable to all the peoples of Fiji. It remains to be seen whether that will happen, but to the extent that there is last some sign of the wheel turning again-there have been, of course, false alarms previously-that is an occasion for encouragement and not the kind of grudging churlishness that we have had from Senator Hill in his grudgingly churlish contribution to this particular debate today.

On the subject of New Caledonia, of course difficulties will continue to be thrown up so long as the French Government pursues its desire of recent times not to recognise fully the rights of the indigenous people, at the same time as safeguarding the rights of all the other long term residents and so long as the French Government goes on resisting the kind of peaceful orderly transition to self-determination on United Nations principles and multi-racial independence which we, along with so many countries of the region, have been anxious to see happen. The position that we have taken, which has been one entirely in sympathy with the position of the Forum countries and the regional countries throughout the Pacific, has not been a position which has been a comfortable one, so far as Australia's relationship with France is concerned. If Australia were as insensitive to the region as Senator Hill has suggested, if we had so little respect, so little affection and so little confidence flowing back towards us a result of this, that state of affairs would not, of course, have been pursued by us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance put forward by Senator Hill today is:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's record of neglect and its failure to pursue sound and consistent policies within the South Pacific region with a consequent loss to Australia of respect and influence.

The actual topic does not necessarily refer to any particular policies. Presumably the policies referred to, and which Senator Hill raised, are those of foreign affairs and possibly trade. Of course there are a range of other policies with which Australia is involved in the South Pacific. For example, it has a fairly extensive involvement in development projects and educational projects. Since Australia became a federation, over 80 years ago, it has certainly sought to develop and involve itself in the Pacific. I do not think anybody in this place would want us to do otherwise. Australia's interests are very much in the South Pacific and it is not at all difficult to identify them and to understand our role here. After all, our population of about 17 million is four times that of New Zealand or Papua New Guinea, 23 times that of Fiji and 115 times that of Vanuatu. Australia provides about twice as much aid to the region as New Zealand does, apart from what it provides to Papua New Guinea, and seven times as much aid to this region as the United States of America does. Australia also carries out more trade with the region that any other country, even though our trade in the region is only about 2 per cent of our global trade. Australia has very real interests in the area and has every right, therefore, to indicate its disapproval of developments which it sees as inimical to Australia's interests, to suggest alternatives and to demonstrate, where appropriate, its capacity and intention to pursue its interests if those suggestions are disregarded.

There are certainly many aspects of Australia's performance in the South Pacific which would support Senator Hill's assertion, although I am not sure whether I would embrace all the points he raised. Many of them could be seen as paternalistic. The Australian Government certainly botched the whole exercise with regard to aid to Papua New Guinea. Having had quite extensive discussions with the Government of that country, it then unilaterally pulled out of them, giving hardly any notice to the Papua New Guinea Government, and without even the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) explaining; it was left to Senator Gareth Evans, who has now left the chamber, to pick up the ball and run with it. What the countries of the South Pacific are looking for is not aid but trade. Aid will end up beggaring them. Trade will give them the ability to develop their economies and societies in the way that they see fit, not in the way that Australia or any of the other aid donors in the area see fit.

When one is talking about aid one cannot neglect the operation in the region of a number of countries which have no particular desire to support or help the region develop but which merely pursue their own defence interests. One such country that comes rapidly to mind is France, which sees the region as an area where it is able to conduct its nuclear tests, continuing its own particular form of colonialism. It currently wanders around the Pacific area handing out cheques to anybody who will stand still. That exercise has nothing to do with the development of the countries of the region and, fortunately, it is seen in that way by most countries of the region. They are happy to take the cheques and treat France in the way they have treated France in the past-with very little respect. France considers that this is not its region and that it does not have to develop a position here, whereas all the countries in the region do.

The politics of aid in the South Pacific are probably as controversial as the politics of aid in other parts of the world. With the instability in the region caused by the coup d'etat in Fiji, the politics of aid are likely to heat up considerably in the next few years. It is, therefore, in Australia's interests to maintain our aid at its previous level and increase, if possible, aid which is not handed out with strings attached but which is the type of aid sought by various countries in our region-not aid initiated by us. In addition, we should look more and more towards developing trade with Pacific island countries. I will give some examples which show that we have a long way to go. In 1986-87 we sold the South Pacific nations $1.092 billion worth of goods and bought in return $280m worth of goods. That is an extraordinary situation. The only way that those countries are able to make up that enormous deficit in their terms of trade with us is by relying on Australian aid. The two items are interlinked.

Another factor raised by Senator Hill and linked quite intimately to this issue is Australia's immigration policy with regard to the South Pacific countries. A major item in the Budgets of many South Pacific countries is the money which is repatriated by their nationals who live and work in Australia. The immigration question is linked to the economic question in this region probably more than anywhere else in the world. A consistent and developing immigration policy has to take into account those trade, aid and economic measures. There is a vacuum. There is a place for a coherent, rational and consistent policy, but it must include not simply Australia's foreign relations aspect but all policy aspects ranging as wide as education, immigration and trade.

The other problem-Senator Hill referred to it-is that much of the foreign policy debate with regard to the South Pacific is necessarily couched in terms of the East-West relationship. Oddly enough, what I have just been referring to are really the North-South problems, as they are called in economic terms. But almost every one of the development questions, the North-South questions, gets translated in the South Pacific context into an East-West exercise. Senator Hill, in his speech, paid a fair amount of attention to this aspect, that is, the intrusion of other powers into the South Pacific, the role of the Soviet Union and the United States in the South Pacific, not only now but in future, and the role of France in the South Pacific, which I have already referred to, with regard to its nuclear testing program. These issues have been heightened in recent times by the suggested exercises and the development of military relationships between the United States and Papua New Guinea, particularly with regard to the Papua New Guinea-West Irian border; the continuing unsettled situation in the Philippines, which might be seen to be somewhat outside the South Pacific region but which cannot be ignored; our role with regard to Indonesia; and Indonesia's role and position with regard to the South Pacific. Undoubtedly Indonesia will, in the very short term, be playing a much more expanded role in the South Pacific than it has played up to now.

If in a short debate such as this one were trying to draw the golden thread, as it were, which runs through Australia's relationships with such a diversity of countries, one would end up taking a very paternalistic role. In many ways our relationship with each of these countries is a bilateral, not a multilateral, relationship. Whilst we talk about the South Pacific as a blanket term, as though there is Australia and the South Pacific and Australia can have a one to one relationship with South Pacific countries, the fact is that in the text 10 years or so Australia will probably continue in much the same vein as it has continued in the past 10 years, that is, seeking to develop warm and friendly bilateral relations with each of the countries.

These bilateral relationships will involve different aspects with each of the countries. In the case of Nauru it may involve whether we will return to the devastation which Australia, along with Britain and New Zealand, managed to cause that tiny country, probably leaving it in the next year or two without any viable economic options. In the case of Papua New Guinea, Australia may have a role on the border with Indonesia. With regard to Vanuatu, we should have come into the airport construction exercise in a much more vigorous and upfront way. And so it goes on.

Hopefully with each of those countries we shall have some type of developing bilateral relationship, but it will depend on whether Australia can come to grips with some of its own problems. I refer to our own trade problems, the solving of which will mean that we shall be able to offer those countries more generous trade access to our markets. That is the foundation of any reasonable development, particularly with the smaller South Pacific countries, and determines whether our role in the South Pacific, and how we are currently linked with the United States, is beneficial to the South Pacific. New Zealand has made a stance in regard to nuclear powered or nuclear armed warships. That was going to make this part of the world fall in. It is interesting now, some time on, that that has been able to be accommodated in the international relations structures. I believe that a better situation in regard to New Zealand and the United States is very much in the offing now. These things finally have to be accepted and lived with.

One of the roles which Australia cannot play in the South Pacific, which too often in the past we have sought to play, is as surrogate to the United States. The interests of the South Pacific are Australia's interests because we live in the South Pacific. The United States interests in this region are to see this area in strategic terms, and in America's strategic terms overall. I believe that in the final analysis Australia's contribution to the development of friendly relations between the countries of the South Pacific will be seen in terms of what we are able to do in developing what one hopes will be a free trade zone in this part of the world. It will not be in terms of developing the South Pacific as an island of influence for United States military strategic planning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate this afternoon is debating as a matter of public importance the Government's record of neglect and its failure to pursue sound and consistent policies within the South Pacific region with a consequent loss to Australia of respect and influence. There is no doubt that as a consequence of the Government's neglect and incompetence in the field of foreign affairs, Australia has become not only this weak sister in the South Pacific region, but also a country of no relevance whatever in the affairs of the small island nation states in that region.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia, with its population size, its economic strength and its military capabilities, has been for a very long time the dominant power in the South Pacific region. I submit that it is a position that we have filled with distinction. The history of Australia in the South Pacific region has earned us in the past a position of trust, friendship and, above all, respect from the citizens who live in that region. That gave us a position of influence. We were in a sense a big frog in a little puddle, though one uses the little puddle analogy advisedly because there are some very large distances involved in the South Pacific region.

But all that has changed. Australia is dismissed as being of no consequence at all by the nations of South East Asia. I must say, having travelled around those countries now over a considerable time, I am dismayed as an Australian to find the contempt, almost, in which the nations of South East Asia hold Australia, particularly in a military sense. This is purely a consequence of the unco-ordinated policies of indifference followed by this Government. Just as we have suffered this fate in South East Asia, the same fate now has befallen us in the South Pacific region. This is a consequence of this Government having no overall policy. This Government has never taken the trouble to understand what is going on in the communities of the South Pacific nations, what their hopes and fears are, and what they need in the way of help from the nations around them. The Government has never considered what Australia's interests are in that region. There has never been a co-ordinated plan put together, despite the existence of some well-informed and capable people in our Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade who have intimate knowledge of the South Pacific region. There has never been a cohesive, long range plan put together by the Hawke Labor Government. That Government does not know what objectives it wants to attain for this country this year or in five or 10 years time. The consequence is that, at best, we muddle through and, at worst, we get overtaken by circumstances-circumstances which, with a little thought and planning, we could have gone some way towards influencing, if not diverting.

We enter into agreements with those countries to give them help on occasions and then, without warning, we break those agreements when we cut our aid program. But, above all, when the crises occur-such as the great crisis in Fiji where a democratically elected Government was overthrown in a coup-we fail to demonstrate any leadership at all. Like it or not, we are the dominant power in the South Pacific region-or we were-and the element of leadership in that role is inescapable. If we fail to demonstrate leadership, we surrender that status of having power and influence in the region.

After a long period of stability, the South Pacific has undergone a number of major changes-economically, politically, socially and psychologically. It is a region that is characterised by a large number of very small island states with vast distances between them. Therefore, there is a requirement for adequate communications and transport systems, which are expensive and often beyond the technology or the economic base of the countries requiring them. All these countries have increasing populations. Those populations are educated to some degree, and do know what is going on in the outside world. They have films and television and see the standard of living enjoyed in the rest of the world, and they want to share in that standard of living. But they have limited natural resources and do not have the capacity to earn, through trading with other countries, the means to support the lifestyle to which they aspire. There is a very great need for Australia, a need that we have recognised in the past, to help them to develop. As Senator Macklin said, there is a need to give them aid not for some self-defeating, short term purpose, but in an intelligently structured way to enable them to look after themselves, to grow and to better themselves.

Some of the changes in this region are reflected in both a military and a political sense. The most dramatic change has been the change in New Zealand under the Lange Government. This old ally of Australia changed its defence posture dramatically when it broke the ANZUS agreement. Australia, as a partner of New Zealand for many years, had a legitimate case to put to New Zealand, and on the platforms around the world, that New Zealand was doing the wrong thing in adopting its unilateralist pacifist path. This not only puts New Zealand's security at risk, but also puts Australia's security at risk and compromises to some degree the security not only of the South Pacific but of the South East Asian region. But again we had a leadership vacuum. There was not one word out of the Hawke Government about what New Zealand was doing. We had years and years of inactivity. Then last month we had the visit by the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, to New Zealand, where he committed an act of great dishonesty. He glossed over and failed to recognise the importance of the changed foreign relations policy of New Zealand. With great dishonesty he said that it was a sign of the maturity between our two countries that we could have these enormous differences which, really, at the end of the day, made no difference to the warmth of the relationship between us. That is absolute nonsense. Either we hold strongly that the security of Australia and the region is important and we do what we can to support it, or we do not. We cannot go on with a body such as the New Zealand Government which sets out on a premeditated path to break that down.

We have proceeded with a completely unco-ordinated plan with respect to Fiji. We are part of the Western democratic group of nations. We believe that the desirable way for countries to govern themselves is through a democratic parliamentary system. Fiji had one of the few such systems in the South Pacific. It is an important country-a country which is really a hub, a trading centre, in its part of the world. Its government was ejected as a consequence of a coup and Australia had no policy at all to cope with this. We had no intelligence that this would happen the first time, we had even less intelligence that it would happen a second time. No wonder the United States of America is upset about what is going on and is taking active steps to do its own intelligence collection in a region where formerly it was quite happy to rely on the quality of Australia's intelligence.

We are now in a position where we apparently have no influence at all in Fiji. While it is not one of the great trading powers of the world, it is a significant trading power in the Pacific. That trade was largely with Australia and was of benefit to our citizens. We had a favourable trade balance with Fiji. Recently we have seen the Indonesians move in and set up trade commissions there. We have seen Fiji shift away to other fields-particularly the military fields. Had Australia had a policy and a good intelligence service-which it should have had in a small open community such as Fiji-I would argue that we could well have intervened before the coup in Fiji. With the good relationships that we formerly enjoyed, particularly with the military who took over, we could well have persuaded them that there was a much better and more correct course to follow than the two coups that have taken place. But the only policy the Australian Government had was one of supine collusion with the trade union movement. It was the Keltys and the Creans of this world who decided what Australia would do when our interests were at stake in Fiji.

In Vanuatu, one of our close neighbours, we have again failed to have any influence on events. We have gone on almost in a comic opera way about perceived threats from the Libyans in that region. We have seen the Vanuatu Government attempt to get support from the Libyans for the extension of an airfield for which it has a legitimate need. This is something that we could have probably supplied through our aid program. Of course, this year we have seen the links between Vanuatu and the Soviets, with a $1.5m fishing agreement being set up. In New Caledonia we have followed a policy which is diametrically opposed to our policy in Fiji. In Fiji-insofar as we argued a case-we argued the case for the majority Indian community to be represented in the government of that country. In New Caledonia we are arguing that a minority indigenous community should somehow or other be granted control and that the country should have independence.

The relationship with Vanuatu, to some degree to New Caledonia and to the South Pacific region as a whole, is perverted by the problems that this Government has in developing a policy with France. I am on record-in speeches within this country and overseas and in writings in journals that have been published overseas-as condemning the French for nuclear testing. There is no doubt where I stand on that, but it happens to be a fact of life that I am not going to talk the French out of nuclear testing and neither is the Australian Government. At the end of the day we have far more in common with the French and we can do far more good for the nations of the South Pacific by working in concert with the French than by opposing them and thereby not being able to be consulted in the discussions on New Caledonia and other places where we could play a part in the development of political affairs in the region.

Time draws on and I do not have time to talk about the emergence of the Melanesian bloc, Papua New Guinea, the Solomons and Vanuatu. Senator Hill touched on that and again we do not seem to be able to build any bridges with this developing group in the Pacific. I think the announcement over the weekend that the Americans have been asked by the Papua New Guinea Government to act as military advisers sent a shiver down the spines of all Australians to whom I talked. The significance of that is not that the Americans are a threat to us but that they see Australia as an irrelevance. The Americans are looking ahead to a time when they may have difficulty in the Philippines, and they are developing an alliance in the South Pacific region which excludes Australia and puts us beyond it. We have done nothing to develop economic links with the Association of South East Asian Nations groups to which the South Pacific countries look beyond Australia. As I said, we are suffering from the lack of a sensitive, intelligent and well researched policy which looks at the long term needs of both Australia and the region.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that Australia's main fault in the South Pacific has been a persistent refusal to accept that the main tensions are within a North-South framework and not an East-West one. This, coupled with a lack of familiarity with the region, has led to a series of embarrassments in the last couple of years and is likely to lead to more if Australia persists in viewing the region through spectacles fashioned in Moscow and Washington instead of in Melanesia, Micronesia and Polynesia. Symptomatic of the disregard was the fact that not until last year did the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) embark on a tour of the region, with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) going even later. Compare this with David Lange's familiarity with the region and its leaders. Australia has always been more preoccupied with Asia than the Pacific, and even now persists in seeing the region as an area of potential super-power rivalry rather than addressing issues of economic security pertaining to the islands' real needs.

SPEECH.PARA: It was instructive to read on 14 November this year the comments of Mr Bill McKinnon, Australia's High Commissioner to New Zealand, after the two-day meeting in Canberra of the Heads of Missions in the Pacific. He commented that the worst fears of super-power rivalry in the Pacific had not been realised and that Soviet influence had not extended as far as had been feared following the Soviets' fishing agreement with Kiribati. A number of organisations who have worked in the Pacific pointed this out in 1985, but the Government preferred to listen to echoes of the Cold War. These ancient warriors, locked into bloc thinking, saw the Russians entering an area that until then, they thought, they had kept them out of. As a result, we were treated to scare headlines and articles about Soviet spying and Soviet efforts to secure port facilities that would be a foothold for the military, which said that if it was not the Soviets; it was their surrogates-Cuba, Libya and Vietnam. No one took any notice of the Prime Minister of Kiribati, who pointed out the hypocrisy of criticising his country's agreement with the Soviet Union-worth 15 per cent of his country's total income-when New Zealand had an agreement that even allowed shore access for the Soviets, and when Australian farmers would be in an even worse mess without wheat sales to the Soviet Union. Now that the Prime Minister is back from Moscow we read about more trade between Australia and the Soviet Union but, apparently, a desperately poor country with only 65,000 people was not to be allowed to make similar agreements and Vanuatu, with 145,000 people, got the same bullying treatment.

The great hysteria over Libya seems to have abated but there was never any recognition of the fact that an independent country such as Vanuatu was entitled to have diplomatic relations with any country it wished-just as Australia does. The Libyan People's Bureau in Australia was closed only when the Government's hypocrisy proved overwhelming, not for any security reasons. We could not tell other countries not to have a Libyan People's Bureau when we had one here in Canberra; so it had to go.

Again, taking our cue from Washington, the Government has constantly refused to acknowledge the violence and intimidation going on in the Republic of Belau, part of the United Nations trust territory of Micronesia, administered by the United States since 1947. The people of Belau suffered badly during the war between imperial Japan and the United States just over 40 years ago. They quite deliberately wrote into their constitution that they did not want any military bases in Belau after it became independent. The United States has simply refused to accept the result of nine referenda since 1979 because it wants to use Belau for military purposes. Belau's misfortune is that it lies in a vital geostrategic position for the United States. Although nuclear weapons are totally unnecessary for the defence of Belau and its 14,000 people, the United States views Belau as part of its global game plan. It is also viewed as a potential fall-back position if the United States ever has to withdraw from its bases in the Philippines. Not surprisingly, Henry Kissinger said of Micronesia in 1973:
There are only 90,000 people out there, who gives a damn.

That comment was echoed by Senator Evans here on 16 September in response to my question on Belau following the murder of Mr Bings Bedor. Perhaps Senator Evans does not realise that most of the countries of the Pacific have very few people. It is precisely because of attitudes like his that this motion is being discussed here today. The Government simply does not seem to care about a vast area with few people unless the Russians are coming. Fortunately, a number of key United States Congress people have realised that the vote in Belau in August was not an act of free choice and have sent letters to the relevant department in Washington, DC, saying that they cannot accept the results. It seems that US Congress people have more spirit than the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the people in the Department of Foreign Affairs who are writing letters about Belau to those Australian citizens concerned about the violence there.

As for the defence of freedom and democracy, which we hear so much about as a justification for keeping the Russians out of the Pacific, perhaps we should take note of what a Belauan senator said-that the United States had taught them democracy and then refused to let them practise it. There are those who have argued that a 73 per cent vote in favour of changing the constitution is enough. But the constitution states that it cannot be changed unless 75 per cent vote for it. That is the key issue which the United States continues to disregard. Again, this ignores the comment of Bernie Keldermans from Belau, who said that it was the Western democracies which had taught them that one does not change constitutions lightly. Considering the attempts to change our own Constitution during the Bicentennial, I think we should agree.

I remind the Senate that a mark of civilisation is the way in which we regard a small country and a small people, as the honourable member for Streeton, Tony Lamb, reminded some of us at the rally for East Timor held outside Parliament House at lunchtime today. The lack of consideration and the lack of interest in Belau and East Timor indicate just what the honourable member referred to-unless, of course, the country concerned is approached by the Soviet Union or Libya; then, suddenly, everybody gets very interested.

In Belau the Chief Justice had to resign because of intimidation, the Speaker was threatened, members of parliament were threatened, women plaintiffs in a legal case were threatened and houses were firebombed-in other words, incidents which, if they had happened here in Canberra, would have been considered intolerable. Yet such is this country's lack of concern about the South Pacific that all the representative of the Minister for Foreign Affairs in this chamber can do is make a joke about it. I find that quite deplorable. I commend the Government's stand on Kanaky and its support for the South Pacific Forum in getting New Caledonia inscribed on the decolonisation list at the United Nations, although I am concerned that any contact the FLNKS chooses to make to gain support is still judged through East-West eyes. If the people of Kanaky cannot get support from France and the United States, which are supposed to believe in freedom and self-determination, who are we to tell them whom they should seek help from? I am also concerned that the Government's support for the FLNKS may be weakening in the face of French intransigence and tacit US support for France, again because it views France as an ally in the East-West context somewhere on the other side of the world without taking into account the demands by the indigenous people for their own self-determination.

I must also comment on what Senator MacGibbon had to say a while ago about the hypocrisy of the Australian Government's stand when he compared the Australian Government's attitudes towards Fiji and New Caledonia. In New Caledonia the indigenous people are in the minority only because of an enforced and quite deliberate policy of emigration of French nationals to the region with the express purpose of making the local people, the indigenous people, a minority. It is a very different situation from that in Fiji.

I also commend the Government's repeated criticism of France for its nuclear test program at Mururoa Atoll since 1966, although I must point out that it was our neighbours in Melanesia who had to highlight the hypocrisy of condemning the tests while at the same time selling uranium to the country responsible for the tests, some of which uranium could quite easily end up at the test site because there is no real way of separating the yellowcake from different sellers once it gets into the nuclear fuel cycle. However, we should maintain our strong opposition to the French testing program in the South Pacific. As an immediate step, the Government should ban all sales of uranium to that country-reinstitute the ban that it was so proud of back in 1984.

Finally, we have to consider the situation in Fiji. It was quite lamentable that our Embassy in Suva took no notice of the Labour Party in Fiji between the time of its formation and the election which it won earlier this year. We chose instead to hobnob with the Alliance Party of Ratu Mara, who has now been nominated as Prime Minister by the military junta which overthrew the democratically elected government of Dr Bavadra. I hope that we will learn from this situation that our diplomats will need to keep in touch with opposition groups instead of disregarding them. It is obvious that our diplomats feel more comfortable with conservative parties which are totally loyal to the United States. As a consequence of that we did not know what was going on in Fiji. I think we should have known in advance what was brewing there. It was a coup 10 years in the making. There is plenty of evidence of outside interference which drummed up the racial argument as an excuse for getting rid of the new Labour Government in Fiji. I cannot understand why Australian diplomats were not aware of that.

The key to Australia's relationship in the South Pacific is to seek partnerships with the various countries based on understanding that the region's prime security needs are economic rather than military. I agree with the comments of Senator Macklin earlier that we should be increasing foreign aid to our neighbouring countries in the South Pacific based on self-help projects of their initiation, not aid with strings attached. Of course, we should be reducing the amount of military aid that we give to any country in the Asia-Pacific region. The issues are North-South rather than East-West. If Australia could see the Pacific through Pacific eyes, instead of taking an indirect view via Washington and Moscow, it might not be so subject to the kind of censure that it is undergoing here today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —A matter of urgency such as this appears to give the impression that the past National-Liberal Party Government had good policies and that they were better than the ones currently being pursued. I categorically state that my examination of politics over a long period has not shown that to be so. It is not so much that the previous Government's policies were atrocious; they did not exist. The previous Government showed no concern at all for the ordinary people living in South Pacific countries. Australia holds a place of pride in the South Pacific area. As a developed and democratic country, we have a responsibility to assist developing nations in several areas: financial, physical, defence, joint project development and leadership in seeking a peaceful, secure Pacific area, recognising the rights of and the independence of each nation, but mindful of the need to co-operate to assist each other for the common good. Australia has played a very constructive and co-operative role in convincing Japan, for instance, to stop dumping nuclear waste in the Pacific islands, which is very important in terms of the contamination of the fisheries which are very important to the life cycle of people in those nations.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Government has always strongly supported independence for the indigenous people in the area. One has only to look at history to see that the Whitlam Government from 1972 to 1975 played a tremendous role in accelerating the coming of the opportunity for Papua New Guinea to become an independent nation. Many years before becoming Prime Minister, Gough Whitlam, as Leader of the Opposition, was able to increase the recognition of Australia's importance in the world of nations. At that time the Liberal Prime Minister was not able to do that. In fact, he had no desire to do it. He had us living in isolation apart from some of the Anglo-Saxon countries and the United States of America. His desire to have a few powerful friends seemed to be all-consuming.

Senator Macklin suggested that there was a need to look at trade and not aid. I think both matters are very important indeed. When looking at the question of aid one must consider what can be offered and how that offering can be used in the best interests of the people in a particular country. Certainly these offerings should not be used in the interests of the government or of administering agencies; they should be used in the interests of the people in the particular country. Much aid money is wasted. Australia has given aid over many years. It has already been pointed out that Australia gives about twice as much aid as New Zealand gives in the area. I believe that our aid should not be given without strings. I see no problem with suggesting ways in which it should be spent and with offering not only financial aid but also physical involvement to see that that aid money is properly spent in the interests of the recipients. I suggest this not in terms of being paternalistic, but rather in terms of determining what their requirements are, what they need, and applying our particular expertise in order to achieve the ends which they seek.

Obviously we need to help to develop infrastructure. It is not a question of just food aid, although that is important when it is needed. We need to develop the infrastructure of these countries so that they can become truly independent and stand on their own two feet-at least to the extent that most trading nations can. In this respect, I accept, of course, what is well known to all of us: that no nation is an island unto itself and that trade-import and export-has to occur. I believe also that when we consider aid packages we need to have consideration for Australian industry. We need to provide people with manufactured goods that come from our own country. We should supply jobs for our country while providing value added goods to recipient countries. I see no gain and no purpose in providing millions of dollars for people to spend in, say, West Germany on machinery that could well be made in Australia.

I think it is fairly barren and narrow to talk about the relationship between one country and another only in terms of the government level. We could have two totally bureaucratic governments which do not concern themselves with what the people are able to achieve or their way of life and whether it is democratic and fulfilling. I believe it is important that contacts be made at all levels between countries. I point out that the trade unions in Australia, because they are in a fairly developed state-certainly not developed to the extent of having the types of powers that those opposite suggest at times- are in a position to assist trade unions in other countries. They are doing that. They are developing a policy of assistance which deals with education and helping people look at what is possible-but always on the basis of the principles of fairness and equity. Michael Kinnane, who is an educationalist in Queensland, has the responsibility of looking after a particular educational facility for the trade unions in the South Pacific. I think that is very important.

We in the Australian Labor Party believe that the democratic way in which the trade unions operate is admirable. I point also to the way that they have co-operated with this Government to produce, probably for the first time in history, a reduction in real wages. For the first time, with this Government, there was a collective approach to seeking to develop industry. For the first time that I can recall-and for the first time according to my reading of history-we have been able to have a true productivity bargaining situation, where people have given up certain things for a wage increase which involves no cost to the employers. The sorts of principles inherent in that enlightened view-the view of building and creating wealth to share in the community-are what we are seeking to share with the people in the South Pacific. It is not always possible for these countries to go along the road that we do, because of the fact that they are only at the stage of becoming developed. We also are seeking to develop their ideas on how the democratic forums can be utilised so that they can be drawn into the wider debate in the whole region of the South Pacific.

In respect of the Federal Government's involvement in Fiji, I certainly hope that the Opposition is not following the advice of Senator Puplick, who, I understand, said in an interview concerning the Gulf war:
if somebody shot Saddam Hussein the war could be over within a week.

I hope that is not the policy of the Opposition; it certainly is not the policy of the Labor Party. When looking at the position of Fiji one necessarily has to look at a little bit of history-and this does not take long. The situation in that country of the different races-the indigenous race, the Indian race and, to a lesser extent, others-was created because of the colonial situation overseen by the United Kingdom. I refer not only to the government to government situation but also to CSR Ltd, a capitalist giant, a company which created sugar plantations and sugar mills. CSR brought in indentured labour from India and created the problems we now see. It is not just something that happened yesterday. The development of differences of opinion has been going on over many years. For the first time a partly Labor government was elected in Fiji. It was quite determined to make the country more democratic and give people the opportunity to express views and have some power further down the line. It wanted to be totally and clearly honest in its approach. All of a sudden a number of hooded men appeared in the Parliament and, using the barrel of a gun, they removed the Government. The thing that astounded me is that a representative of this Opposition immediately came out and supported that action. That is the position: the Opposition favours the taking over of a democratic parliament at the barrel of a gun. Well, that was the position until he was, I understand, taken to task by Mr Howard, the Leader of the Opposition. What a daunting prospect.

What was Australia to do in this situation? Was it to send in several gunboats, drop in a few loads of parachutists and take over the country? We did not do that, but we certainly did whatever we could to indicate our attitude that Fiji should return to democracy and that the bringing about of that was a role for the people of Fiji. The trade union movement took the view, as a result of discussions with trade unionists from Fiji, that certain bans should be placed upon it. Great capital was made in the Parliament by suggesting that the trade union movement was taking over foreign policy from the Government. Nothing could be further from the truth. But a principle that we in Australia should all support and protect is that trade unions should have the right to withdraw their labour if they feel that something is going on in another country that is absolutely contrary to what they believe is right and correct.

The Government, in its wisdom or otherwise, decided that it would not adopt the approach of sanctions. But it still sought in every other way to bring about a proper conclusion to the dispute in Fiji. The suggestion that it does not have any status and standing in the South Pacific countries is so much rubbish. Mr Hawke was suggested as the leader of a group of people which it was hoped would be received by Rabuka to discuss the matter and reach some sort of conclusion. We are concerned about the situation and we will do everything within our ability.

Senator MacGibbon is quite remarkable in the way that he assesses things and responds. He suggested that Bob Hawke was dishonest and that he glossed over the difference between ourselves and New Zealand. There is no doubt that a large minority of people in this country holds that there should be no visits of nuclear armed or nuclear fuelled ships to these shores. There is no doubt about that. But this Government has a different view, and at least it recognises the sovereignty of New Zealand and its right to hold a different view. I think that it was totally honest and thorough of Bob Hawke to make the point that, although there can be differences in a particular area or areas, at least there are many other areas, on which Australia and New Zealand can agree and can go together hand in hand playing a constructive role in the South Pacific, not only for the benefit of their own people but also for the benefit of all nations in the South Pacific.

Senator MacGibbon also made a point about the lack of accurate intelligence regarding Fiji. I do not know that we have changed the team very much. I think that there are some people opposite who were there at the time when the Liberal and Country parties were in power. I have never been a great admirer of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and its people, either. Of course, Senator MacGibbon said that we had no further influence on France. I feel that we should be totally opposed, as the Opposition has already indicated, to nuclear testing in the Pacific, and we have stated that very clearly. If saying that we are being critical of France and if maintaining our position of encouraging and supporting the indigenous people in the community to have independence means that France will be placed in a position where it is not prepared to accept our influence, so be it. I would not want to see our Government suddenly say that it is all right to test nuclear weapons in the South Pacific and to use police and the military to suppress the Kanaks in New Caledonia, as long as Australia remains a friend of France. As far as I am concerned, we have taken a principled position in that regard and should continue to do so. We should support independence for that country. In doing that, I think we have the support and recognition of the governments and, more importantly, the people of those countries in the South Pacific, because we are being a positive force in the South Pacific for the future good of that area and for building a better and safer South Pacific where the opportunity for people to increase their standard of living and, more importantly, the opportunity for a nuclear-free South Pacific can be developed. In that situation, rich or poor, they will not die from the effects of radioactivity, or be blown up by atomic bombs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a matter of public importance proposed by Senator Robert Hill in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's record of neglect and its failure to pursue sound and consistent policies within the South Pacific region with a consequent loss to Australia of respect and influence.

I must say that everything I have heard in this debate would sustain the accuracy and fairness of that assessment of what this Government has done. In the South Pacific we are dealing with a very unusual and a very sensitive area and the Government's handling of it has been very inept. We must look at the nature of this region that we are talking about.

When the Second World War ended, five colonial powers-Australia, France, New Zealand, the United Kingdom and the United States of America-were administering the Pacific island dependencies. Today, all the islands are independent, with the exception of American Samoa, the French territories of French Polynesia, Wallis and Futuna, the Pitcairn dependency administered by Britain, Tokelau, which is a New Zealand territory, and Nieu and the Cook Island, which are self-governing but associated with New Zealand.

The independent South Pacific states range from Papua New Guinea, with 3.5 million people, and Fiji, with 700,000, to states like Nauru, with around 8,000 citizens and a land mass of 26 square kilometres. In total, the Pacific states, islands and atolls, including the American trust territories, cover roughly 22 million square kilometres, of which 97 per cent is ocean. Unemployment on the islands is high and subsistence agriculture is the norm. However, Nauru has grown rich on phosphates, while Papua New Guinea possesses high copper deposits. On the other hand, many of the islands possess nothing beyond meagre copra production to sustain them. With rapidly growing populations, many of the islands face problems of urban unemployment, particularly among youth, and of massive brain drains of newly qualified graduates to Australia, New Zealand and Fiji. The Cook Islands, Tonga, Tuvalu and the Samoas are ethnic Polynesian. In small, remote Nauru, the Micronesian, Melanesian and Polynesian strains are mixed, with Polynesian predominating. In Papua New Guinea, West New Guinea, New Caledonia, the Solomon Islands and Vanuatu, the people are Melanesian. Fiji lies in the Melanesian area, but indigenous Fijians are a mixture of Polynesian and Melanesian. Fiji's Indian population, which is the majority of the population, are former indentured cane labourers.

This is a very complex area and in such an area Australia is a major power but, because of its former colonial history, that power has to be used with great tact. President Theodore Roosevelt once said, `Talk softly, but carry a big stick'. We seem to talk loudly and carry a very feeble stick. We have to think about their interests and also our legitimate interests. With the possible exception of Nauru, they are all poor countries and they wish to live in peace. Of course, what they want is aid-but trade more than aid. In recent years our policies have not been very helpful in either of those areas.

What are our interests? We do not want to see super-power rivalry in the South Pacific. We do not want to see revolutions in countries that are underdeveloped, small in population and small in resources. We do not want to see this going on across our trade routes that link us with the American continent. What are the threats that might disturb what used to be described as the idyllic South Pacific? There can be internal threats-for instance, in Fiji and New Caledonia. In Fiji the ethnic population is outnumbered by the Indian population, and we all know what has been happening there. The same situation applies in New Caledonia, where the ethnic Kanaks are outnumbered by the immigrants, but the Labor Government's policy has been diametrically opposed in those two countries-typical of the confusion it has followed. In Fiji, insofar as one can make any sense of this Government's policy, it seems to be supporting majority democratic rule. In New Caledonia it is doing the opposite; it appears to be supporting minority indigenous rule. This is typical of the confusion as to what we stand for and what we are trying to achieve which is damaging our whole standing in the South Pacific. Those are the internal threats of racial intolerance and racial division in countries such as Fiji and New Caledonia.

There are also external threats. Of these, by far the most serious is the move into the South Pacific by the Soviet Union. That can be explained in many ways. The Soviets have developed fishing agreements. One would have thought that it was perfectly legitimate for them to develop fishing agreements with Kiribati and Vanuatu if that were their sole purpose but, on their past performance in other areas, one would have to be very naive to think that was their purpose. They are using such agreements as a means to project their power into an area to cause disruption to the Western powers and perhaps spinoff benefits for themselves. The interests of the local people are the last things that would cross their mind. Our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has said publicly, `We would welcome more political and economic involvement by the Soviet Union in the Asian-Pacific region'. That is what he said-he appeared to retract it a bit later-but I think we want to be very cautious as to the motives of the Soviet Union in the South Pacific. I do not think that they are designed in any way for the benefit of the people of the South Pacific or for the improvement of relations in the area between the Western powers and the inhabitants of the South Pacific, I think we ought to look at them with the deepest suspicion.

What is worrying is the enormous buildup of the power, particularly the naval power, of the Soviet Union in the Pacific. The Soviets are in no way militarily equipped to have a head-on confrontation with the United States Pacific fleet, but that is not necessary; that is the most unlikely thing that could happen. That would be part of a world conflict. Why, then, are they building up their power-which they are doing in a very impressive way? The Soviets' Pacific fleet is now the biggest of their four fleets, numbering 836 ships; 32 modern ballistic missile submarines; and 90 hunter-killer submarines. It includes the only two Soviet aircraft carriers and the latest missile frigates. Their amphibious assault capability is very great: half their entire naval inventory is in the Pacific. They are backed by a fully integrated Soviet merchant fleet capable of transporting seven divisions. They have moved, as we all know, although the Soviets keep on denying it in a rather feeble way, to bases in Vietnam, and since 1985 the base at Cam Ranh Bay has supported an average of 15 to 25 ships in the South China Sea and another 15 to 20 ships in the Indian Ocean. They also have modern bomber forces there and reconnaissance forces. This is a massive deployment of power and one cannot think that its purpose is beneficial to our interests or, for that matter, to the interests of the people of the South Pacific. We must look at the situation with very great concern.

The other external threat to the tranquillity of the South Pacific is, of course, the Libyans. I believe that they are a force for mischief. There is no great evidence yet that they have done any particular harm to any of the countries of the South Pacific, but again I do not think that the involvement of Libya in the South Pacific-an area one would have thought was of absolutely no interest to Libya-can be intended for the benefit and the tranquillity of the people of the South Pacific. Again, we must watch that with very great care and be prepared to counter it if the involvement of the Libyans appears to be disturbing our area of very great interest.

What has the Government been doing about this? Let us look at the political involvement of the Government. One of the early acts of the Prime Minister was to end Commonwealth Heads of Government Regional Meetings, very useful forums for discussing problems, for dealing with economic, political and defence issues. He was instrumental in ending them. Last year he did not bother to go to the South Pacific Forum; this year he attended it, but it was not really out of any great interest in the South Pacific as a whole. The Forum was used merely as a vehicle to project his attempt-a very ineffective and damaging attempt-to sort out Fiji's internal affairs. This caused adverse reaction from the Melanesian countries, which had the impression that we were trying to bully our way into the internal affairs of another country. That is the thing that we must avoid at all costs; we must not come over as the playground bully. Australia is much more powerful than those countries, yes, but we want to help them, not try to bully them. Of course, under certain circumstances military power may be significant, but certainly we should not initiate it or flaunt it. Talk softly and carry a big stick, not the other way around-which is the policy of this Government.

The second area of grave concern is the failure of our intelligence in the Pacific under this Government. The events in Fiji caught us by surprise not once, but twice. This was a very serious failure of out intelligence activity, which is directed by this Government-or rather, more accurately, misdirected by this Government. One of the Government speakers in this debate revealed an astonishing ignorance; he seemed to think that the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation was responsible for external intelligence. Admittedly he is a backbencher but nevertheless it is typical of the attitude of this Government and its members to the crucial importance of intelligence. We have very small defence forces in world terms. We rely very heavily on effective intelligence, to be deployed directly when necessary.

The third area of muddle by this Government is the whole question of sanctions regarding Fiji. The Government came to the conclusion, I believe accurately, that the imposition of sanctions on Fiji would not be helpful to a resolution of the problems there. The trade union movement, apparently conducting our foreign policy for us, imposed sanctions. This is typical of the muddle in our arrangements and the image we are projecting in the South Pacific. Then from the Government benches we had uproar over the American decision to send a very small training team to Papua New Guinea. It was represented by some members of the Government as being a secret agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was the Australian; it wasn't the Government.

—Senator Tate should listen to his backbenchers. The agreement was reached, and made public, at the request of the Papua New Guinea Government, and I believe it will be helpful to that country. It involves only a very small team of 15 people who will go there for two weeks. They will train at Wewak which, I point out to those who are becoming upset about the involvement of Indonesia, is 300 miles from the Indonesian border.

SPEECH.PARA: We must also be able, where necessary, to support the tiny island states of the Pacific-and they are tiny-against extremist external threats. If we do not deliver support, the first time we are called on will be the last time. This Government has run down our Defence Force. It has reduced our defence spending and very much reduced our ability to help people in the South Pacific. It has destroyed our amphibious capability, and it destroyed our Fleet Air arm. These things are the means by which we could have gone to help the tiny countries threatened by external extremists. These, of course, are very serious policy errors, which we will regret in the future. This Government has failed to comprehend the needs of the South Pacific, it has failed to handle them with sympathy and it has failed to provide us with the resources so that, if a crisis occurred, we could meet that crisis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wood Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened carefully to contributions from both sides of the chamber today and, in summary, they could all be fitted underneath Senator MacGibbon's definition of `leadership', which is `power and influence'. It seems that this Government and the potential government on the other side do not know the difference between leadership and power and influence. It seems that there is a preoccupation with control. There is a paternalistic preoccupation with control; control that is both economic and military.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Hamer has just finished telling us that we should support smaller nations against extremist external threats. The United States is capable of posing an extremist external threat to smaller nations in the South Pacific. Witness the bullying of Belau, to which other senators have referred in this debate. Belau has been bullied constantly since if formed its original constitution, and has voted time and time again to maintain its non-nuclear independent stance. The United States has used economic blackmail. It has exported violence and intimidation to Belau-a tiny Pacific nation, one that we should certainly support and defend against extremist external threats, even if the extremist external threat comes from a super-power that is supposed to be our closest ally. However, this Government and this Opposition have been silent on Belau, and the silence on Belau consents to the bullying. By ignoring the pleas of the Belauans, Australia has consented to extremist, external bullying by the United States.

Fiji is another country whose external threat came not from Libya. We keep hearing about Libya's intentions in the South Pacific and how we must guard against Libyan interference in the South Pacific. But where did the interference in Fiji come from? It was not from Libya. It was not Libya which supplied money to the Taukei movement in Fiji to inflame the racism in Fiji. No one denies that there were racial tensions in Fiji, but these racial tensions were deliberately inflamed to create a vehicle for the coup. As Senator Vallentine said, the coup was 10 years in the making.

We are being fed a lie. We are being told that the Government was caught with its pants down over Fiji, that Australian intelligence did not know what was happening in Fiji and that when the coup came the Government was surprised. I do not believe that for one moment because this Government knew all along what was happening in Fiji and it conspired, by its silence and inaction, in what happened there.

Today a demonstration in front of Parliament House reminded us about East Timor. What happened in East Timor and our attitude to it must be one of the most shameful episodes in Australia's history. We abandoned a country which was a loyal ally during the Second World War. The Timorese shed their blood and died to save Australia and we have abandoned them. Where is the support for our allies? Where is the support against extremist interference? This matter raises questions also about what is happening on the border between Indonesia and Papua New Guinea. Does our shameful desertion of the East Timorese prefigure our attitude to a similar incursion in Papua New Guinea? Why are United States military advisers in Papua New Guinea? The term `military advisers' sends shudders down my spine. It reminds me very much of the military advisers who went to Vietnam-and we know what happened there.

Every year Tahitians are going in their hundreds to hospitals in Paris and New Zealand to be treated for cancer, cancer which results from French testing in the Pacific. The French have bottled up the statistics and the research on cancer rates in the Pacific. If we were genuinely concerned about the people of the Pacific we would be genuinely concerned to make sure that the truth about the effects of French testing in the Pacific, in a medical sense, was put out to the world. But no; by our silence we conspire in that matter too. We bleat about French testing in the Pacific yet we sell the French our uranium for them to use in whatever way they wish. It may be our uranium being tested in the Pacific that is visiting cancers on the people of Tahiti.

Senator MacGibbon said that we have much in common with France. Arrogance is probably one of the things we have in common with the French. Senator MacGibbon also said that New Zealand was mistakenly unilateralist and pacifist and that it broke ANZUS. It was the New Zealand people who forced the New Zealand Government to stop the entry of nuclear warships into New Zealand harbours. The will of the people was so strong that all the major parties in New Zealand now have a ban on nuclear armed and powered ships entering New Zealand waters. That is what democracy is about-that the will of the people should be heard.

We hear about trade. I ask the question: trade with whom? We ought to look at the effects of our trade on the peoples in the South Pacific. When we trade with Fiji we tend to buy goods from Australian multinational corporations. In fact we are buying Australian products from Fiji the profits of which come back to this country. Very few of the profits are seen in Fiji or elsewhere.

I will close by saying that I have to agree with some of the sentiments expressed in the terms of Senator Hill's matter of public importance. I have to disagree with some others because I am afraid that this Government has pursued consistent policies in the South Pacific, policies which have enhanced Australia's military and economic dominance in the region, which have gained the approval of Washington and Paris but which have immeasurably lost any respect that Australia may have had among the indigenous peoples of the South Pacific.
