TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I welcome the opportunity to make a couple of comments about the 1986-87 annual report of the Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC), a formal report which sets out the membership, the objects and a summary of the work of the Council and the papers which the Council has either produced or will produce. In that sense it is of some value because it is a reminder of EPAC's presence which has, perhaps, become a little less noticeable of late. Of more importance are the actual papers which are produced and, of course, the papers which are to be produced. On 6 November a paper was published by EPAC headed Major Issues/Priorities for Council. On page one of that document it is stated:

Australia's economic performance over the next few years will be judged primarily on its ability to sustain employment growth, reduce inflation, and maintain or improve living standards, while at the same time continuing to correct the external trade imbalance.

Simultaneous achievement of these four goals will be possible only if domestic output grows much faster than domestic demand-ie growth is markedly `skewed' towards export and import competing industries.
I would not quarrel with that statement but I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that on page 12 of that report it is stated:
. . . import replacement and export diversification may continue for a time, but to sustain a major expansion in the trade-exposed sector, additional investment is required.
The report then notes:
. . . the latest ABS projections . . . suggest a fall in total manufacturing investment, of perhaps up to 5 or 6 per cent in real terms in 1987-88.

There could be no more damning a statement about this Government's management of the economy than that statement from the Economic Planning Advisory Council. The Government has suggested that the Australian economy is in some way in good shape, particularly when compared with other economies, and to blame other countries, and in particular the United States but more recently during the overseas trip of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Japanese, for Australia's misfortunes. The Opposition view is that a great deal of Australia's misfortune is to be laid squarely at the feet of the present Government. I do not believe that the fact that EPAC will now look to producing papers on key areas such as productivity, saving, investment, public infrastructures, labour market flexibility and general microeconomic constraints in 1988 is by any means good enough. Certainly, the Opposition welcomes contribution to public debate, but surely the time has come for some action. It is hard to believe that EPAC is only now getting around to addressing these vital issues. The fact is that Australia has been performing very poorly in relation to the rest of the world and in relation to its past record. The Hawke Government is continuing to pussyfoot around those issues which might upset its trade union support base. Labour market flexibility and the efficiency of the vital transport and communications sectors are prime examples, and only recently has the Government been able even to mention privatisation other than as a term of abuse.

The simple fact is that Australia's performance is woeful. When we look at the economic statistics which relate to Australia and to the United States, we find that on virtually very indicator Australia is way behind the United States. We have a much higher rate of unemployment; the growth in our gross domestic product is lower; the GDP per capita is, of course, far lower; our world ranking is far lower and our foreign debt is 40 per cent of our gross domestic product as against 13 per cent for the United States. The one area that the Government points to as being an area of superior economic management in Australia is our Budget deficit as a proportion of GDP, and there the figures are cooked because unless we look at the total public sector figures, that is for the States and the Commonwealth Government, we do not get a true comparison, and when we lump in the State deficits then we find that the United States is better off than Australia.

That is what actually happened under the Liberal Government when Mr Howard was the Treasurer. We found that to obtain a given level of inflation in the community more and more unemployment was required. That Government depressed the economy further and further in the vain hope of reducing the level of inflation and inflationary cost rises in the Australian community. Yet we saw at the bottom of the 1982-83 recession a position where the Liberal policies, with Mr Howard as Treasurer, after five Budgets, had resulted in not an 8 or 9 per cent rise in the cost of living in one year but in fact an 11.5 per cent rise. SPEECH.PARA: The Economic Planning Advisory Council was established following the National Economic Summit Conference in April 1983. That is the likely increase in the cost of living under this Government.

Yet just five minutes ago Senator Chaney claimed that on all the indicators the Australian economy was in woeful shape. He claimed that in the past the Australian economy had performed better, but of course the figures give the lie to that. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I present a report entitled The Management of Australia's Defence, together with the transcript of evidence and minutes of proceedings. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

This report is in response to a reference by the Committee to its Defence Sub-Committee, under Mr Manfred Cross, MP, which was originally issued in the previous Parliament and was subsequently renewed by the present Committee this year. It follows, and largely complements, the Committee's 1984 report entitled The Australian Defence Force: Its Structure and Capabilities. Like its predecessor, it will make a significant and constructive contribution to the defence debate in Australia. As its title implies, the report focuses on the higher defence organisation in Australia and examines whether the present organisational structure and policy processes are the most suitable for both peace and war.

It begins with a description of the existing arrangements and how they have evolved, and then examines the major criticisms that have been made in this and earlier inquiries. The report concludes that the existing arrangements continue to exhibit a number of problems and deficiencies which serve to undermine the overall efficiency and effectiveness of the defence establishment. These are documented throughout the report and include, first, continuing overlap in responsibilities and consequent potential conflict of interest between the Secretary to the Department of Defence and the Chief of the Defence Force, and between the Chief of the Defence Force and the individual Service chiefs of staff. A second difficulty is the isolation of the Minister from the defence policy making process, excessive areas of control for many senior managers and lack of sufficient means of reviewing or monitoring the defence establishment as a whole. Third, there is inadequate involvement of the Chief of the Defence Force and his joint staff in the development of defence guidance and the defence program. Fourth, there is also the continuing imbalance between single Service and joint Service interests and perspectives; and fifth, there is overstaffing and overranking in the Defence Department in Canberra. Here the Committee recommends an absolute reduction in the numbers of higher level personnel in the defence establishment. Sixth, there is an unduly complicated policy process; seventh, inadequate means of developing strategic and national security policies and continued absence of basic defence guidance; and, eighth, continuing tensions between civilians and military personnel at all levels within the defence establishment and a breakdown of the `joint process' involving the interrelationship of the Defence Department and the military.

Many of these problems and deficiencies were identified by earlier inquiries into the defence establishment. Some stem from the diarchic structure of the higher organisation which continues to separate the military and civilian staffs. It thereby ensures that much defence policy making proceeds by a process of confrontation and bargaining, rather than mutual co-operation and collaboration.

The report makes a series of recommendations to help overcome or eliminate these problems and deficiencies. It identifies a number of problem areas in which further study is required, either by the defence establishment itself or by an appropriate external review body. In making its recommendations, the Committee's primary objective has been to enhance the overall efficiency and effectiveness of the higher defence organisation and its policy processes, while still ensuring the primacy of control of the Executive Government and the Parliament. Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to have the remainder of my speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The issues examined in the report include:
(a) the division of powers and responsibilities between the secretary to the Department of Defence and the Chief of the Defence Force (CDF);
(b) political supervision and control of defence policy and activities;
(c) the overall integration of defence functions;
(d) the current staffing of the Defence Department and the Australian Defence Force (ADF); and
(e) problems associated with planning, programming and budgeting in defence, and with the equipment acquisition process.
Additionally, a major section of the report deals with the command and control of the Australian Defence Force, with particular reference to:
(a) The evolution of, and problems associated with, the existing operational command structure;
(b) the role and functions of Headquarters Australian Defence Force (HQADF);
(c) the role and functions of the joint force commanders and their commands;
(d) the single service command structure; and
(e) the provision of collective military advice to the Minister and the CDF.

The report ends with an overview of the implications for the defence establishment as a whole of the recommendations in the report, and a discussion of whether there are grounds for more substantive reforms later.
It concludes that there would be considerable advantages in establishing a fully unified higher defence organisation in Australia.

While understandably concentrating on perceived organisational and managerial deficiencies, the report acknowledges that in recent years there has been considerable progress in some areas of the defence establishment.

The 1987 defence White Paper, for example, represents a significant milestone in the formulation of a logical and coherent strategy for the defence of Australia, and an appropriate basis on which to develop our Defence Force structure.

Further, the adoption of a joint force operational command structure is both sensible and timely. Both the Department and the ADF have sought to rationalise and make more efficient many of their internal organisational and policy structures.
The report has sought first to clarify and redefine in a number of areas the basic roles and functions of the principal organisational interests within the defence establishment.
The suggested changes affect the relationship between the CDF and the Secretary to the Department, and the respective roles and functions of the joint staff and the Services.
In the first case, the report proposes that the CDF be given prime responsibility for developing and issuing detailed defence guidance and preparing the annual defence program.

In the Committee's view, the arrangements that have operated in the past have not worked satisfactorily and they have served to undermine the confidence of the military and others within defence in the force development process.

More importantly, we believe, as a matter of principle, that the person who is to be responsible to the Government for the defence of Australia in times of emergency or war should, within the overall policy and resource constraints set by the Minister, have the major say in how the Defence Force and its supporting framework is developed and managed.

The proposed realignment of responsibilities between the CDF and the Secretary is in line with changes that were recently made in the UK Ministry of Defence. It entails the transfer of the Force Development and Analysis Division and some other elements of the Defence Department's central organisation and the three armed service offices into HQADF.

A further important change in this area is the proposed establishment of a Defence Guidance and Capabilities Committee which would be chaired by the Vice-Chief of the Defence Force. It would take over the current functions of the Force Structure Committee and the Defence Operations Concepts and Capabilities Committee.
This would simplify and streamline the force development process and provide the potential for greater control of force development by the joint staff.

At the same time, proposals have been made which would strengthen the present process for preparing the broad strategic framework within which defence must work, namely, through expanding the functions and roles of the Defence Committee and the Strategic and International Policy (SIP) Division.

In the second case, the current roles and responsibilities of the individual armed services and their respective Chiefs of Staff would be further downgraded in favour of the CDF and the joint force commanders.
It is proposed that the ADF be divided, in conceptual terms at least, into two discrete elements: an employing or operational element and a maintaining or administrative element.

This would help emphasise the importance of joint service structures and capabilities, simplify the operational command structure, and remove the potential conflicts of loyalty and interest which characterise the present arrangements.
The operational element would be purely a joint service body and would be responsible for planning and conducting all Defence Force operations and operational training activities in peace and war.
The second element would be made up of the three services, which would play a purely enabling role with no operational responsibilities at all.

In keeping with that approach, the report recommends that rank parity be established between the joint force commanders and the service Chiefs of Staff. It suggests that there is scope to rationalise the maintaining element of the ADF either along functional or joint service lines. Within this revised framework, the report proposes a number of additional changes and measures which aim to:
(a) Increase the first-hand involvement of the Minister for Defence (and his Assistant Minister) in departmental and ADF matters;
(b) Ease the work load of top-level management and provide additional mechanisms for reviewing the structure and performance of the organisation as a whole;
(c) Provide for further rationalisation between and within existing functional areas within the establishment;
(d) Simplify the current policy process by eliminating some committees and decreasing the number of interests involved in decision-making, especially at the top; and
(e) Improve joint service structures, capabilities and career opportunities.

On the last measure, the report acknowledges that the ADF now recognises the value of adopting in peacetime the kind of operational command structure that will be required in times of defence emergency or war, and that it has begun to move in this direction.

It argues, however, that the present operational command structure is simply a single service command system by another name and that it will not provide sufficient opportunity to develop and practise joint service capabilities and doctrines or train military officers in joint staff appointments.
Accordingly, the report recommends that the CDF:
(a) Adjust the peacetime missions and tasks of the joint force commanders to ensure that they involve units and assets from two and preferably three services, and assigns these forces accordingly;
(b) Investigate the establishment of a permanent `theatre' joint force headquarters in the north or north-west of Australia;
(c) Review the existing joint force command structure in order to determine its suitability both now and in the future; and
(d) Implement a range of policies (described in the report) that would establish a strong, confident and motivated joint staff.
The problem areas in which further study or review is required include:
1. The utilisation and current relative distributions of the civilian and service work forces within the higher defence organisation;

2. officer and other rank separation from the ADF (here, I should mention that the matter of personnel wastage rates in the Australian Defence Force has been referred by the Senate to the joint committee for inquiry);
3. the means of formulating Australia's national security policies;
4. the defence planning, programming and budgeting system;
5. the role of the joint force commanders in the formulation and oversight of joint service and defence policy; and
6. the current means of providing collective military advice to the CDF and the Minister for Defence.
The Committee appreciates the ready assistance given to the Sub-Committee throughout the inquiry by the Minister for Defence and his officers from the Department and the ADF.

It also thanks those who made submissions to the inquiry and who took part in public hearings. I would like to thank the Deputy Chairman, Senator David MacGibbon, and the other members of the Defence Sub-Committee for their hard work.
I would also like to place on record the Sub-Committee's gratitude to the staff of its secretariat who assisted in the conduct of the inquiry and in the preparation of the report.

Particular mention should be made of the Committee's defence adviser, Dr Graeme Cheeseman, who is leaving the secretariat after four years to take up an appointment at the Australian National University.
The members of the Joint Committee believe this report represents a positive and timely contribution to the defence debate in Australia.
I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade entitled The Management of Australia's Defence which has been tabled this afternoon deals with the management of the Australian defence forces. This is a subject that is little understood in Australia, yet it is vitally important. At the risk of oversimplifying, I suggest that the relevance of this report might be explained by saying that at one level we have the `no threat doctrine' which implies that there will be sufficient time to prepare the Australian defence forces if we are faced with a defence emergency. But the implication of that doctrine, whether one accepts it or not, is that the system by which the mobilisation is going to take place, by which the defence forces are to be managed, is workable and adequate for the task. Regrettably, the truth is not so. The system that we have in place at present will not work.

SPEECH.PARA: Time after time over the years I have asked representatives of the Department of Defence, particularly the civilian secretaries, first assistant secretaries and other senior people, how good this system is. They have told me that it is excellent. I have then asked whether it would work in time of war, and they have replied, `No, we need another system'. That is really the proof of the pudding for a defence department. We must have a system that works when we need it and, furthermore, we must go as far as we can to work out the flaws in that system while we have the luxury of time to do so. I have a strong belief in the old adage that you train as you are going to fight. We must have a system in place that gives us a chance of being successful if we need to use it. We cannot start from scratch and learn during an emergency. If we do, we will probably lose; we will certainly lose a great number of lives. Even when looking at a management system in times of peace and devoting our best resources to it, we will still not see all the problems, but at least we can be sure that we will get rid of the obvious ones and we will go a long way towards developing an adequate system.

I believe that the report tabled this afternoon is one of the most fundamental and important reports tabled in this Parliament in my time here. It is a very large report of nearly 400 pages and a great deal of thought has been put into it. There are things in it that a lot of people will not agree with, but it is meant to make people think of alternative ways of doing the task better. This report reflects the constructive side of the Parliament. As parliamentarians we come in for a lot of criticism about doing nothing and wasting time and public funds. But this report gives the lie to that. It is a very constructive report of which the Parliament can be quite proud.

This report has no dissenters-it represents all groups and all political ideologies within this Parliament. It is a measure of the way in which the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade worked that even people such as Senator Vallentine could put their name to its report-although she was only associated with it in its closing stages. She did not dissent, though I do not doubt that there are detailed points that she wishes to make in her speech, just as there are detailed points on which I would differ with the report.

I very much regret that the scope of the inquiry was such that it was forced upon the Committee to abridge the terms of reference given to it by the Parliament. We dealt with two of the three referred points, namely:
(a) The determination, management and implementation of Defence policies, and
(b) the suitability of the existing defence organisation for peace and war.

We were not able to take the final brief of expanding on how national security policy was developed at the highest levels in the Parliament, in Cabinet and in the Ministry. I hope that the Committee moves to pick up that reference as its next task after we have completed our inquiry into resignation rates within the Australian defence forces. When we do the higher defence policy part of it, we will have completed a linear progression of inquiries by the Defence Sub-Committee which started with the report Australian Defence Force-Its structure and capabilities, of October 1984, and continued through to this report on the management of the Department of Defence. Finally, I hope we can deal with the formulation of higher defence policy.

I said at the outset that few people understand how the Australian defence forces are managed. The basic principle in Australia-in a democracy-is that there is always civilian control of the armed Services. That is proper and it is a position that is supported fully by every member of the Committee. A careful reading of the report finds that that belief is reinforced all the way through it. From a legal point of view, the administration of the Australian defence forces is covered by the Defence Act, which is updated from time to time. Under the Defence Act we have three Services-an army, a navy and an air force. Very few people know how those Services are managed-how the sizes of the Australian Army, the Royal Australian Navy and the Royal Australian Air Force are arrived at, what equipment they buy, what tasks are assigned to them and so on.

Up to the 1970s we had three different Services. Through the 1970s a dramatic change in management took place. It was really a logical outcome of a change that was taking place for historical reasons. In World War I, World War II, Korea, the Malayan campaign and Vietnam the Australian Services tended to operate as discrete arms-the Army, the Navy and the Air Force. They tended to be allied with the forces of other countries, principally the United States of America and, before that, Britain. That generated a certain structure within them which was appropriate at the time. Changing circumstances after the Second World War set in train a gradual shift in the way in which the Australian forces were structured. It became apparent that we had to move to a position of self-reliance from a defence point of view. That meant that the resources that we had-small though they were from our population base-had to be co-ordinated and brought together. So we have had a continuing program of consolidation of the Australian defence forces into a unified Australian Defence Force, without going down the path taken by the Canadians of wearing one uniform and having one common rank structure and all the rest of it. For a period of about 40 years we have worked to unify the three separate Services into one structure. That process is nowhere near complete, although we have gone a long way down that path.

In the 1970s the Whitlam Government decided to accelerate the program-it was quite correct in doing that-of bringing together the three forces by getting rid of the separate ministries. There was an Army Minister, a Navy Minister, a Minister for Air and three service boards-an Army board, a Navy board and an Air board-which controlled the Services. Over the top of all that, we had a Minister for Defence whose powers were not precisely defined, and we had a Minister for Defence Support who provided the equipment. So we had five ministries and three distinct Services. The reorganisation put in place by the Whitlam Labor Government resulted in our having one Minister for Defence, the abolition of the three service boards and the creation of a Department of Defence which administered the functions that were formerly the task of the three service boards. We had a civilian Secretary, allegedly in parity with the head of the defence forces, who was a creation of this reform-the Chief of Defence Force Staff as he was then, now the Chief of the Defence Force. Fundamentally, that was inevitable and it was a good move. There is no question that the consolidation was and is essential.

One can argue that the Department of Defence, as one of the largest departments of state, is far too large for any one Minister to manage. The moves after the last election, which resulted in the Minister for Defence being supported by a Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, is an indication of the recognition in the Ministry that the task is a huge load. It may well be that there is a need for one or two supporting Ministers for the Minister for Defence; but that is irrelevant to our discussion this afternoon.

However, where the Whitlam Government went wrong was in the selection of an officer from the Department of Foreign Affairs to draw up the blueprint for the amalgamation of the three separate services into the Department of Defence. It is no secret that Foreign Affairs tends to have an adversarial view towards the armed services. With the greatest of respect to Sir Arthur Tange, I do not think he had any real understanding or knowledge of how the three Services worked. He put in place a scheme which read very well to the untrained mind, but which in practice simply does not work. We have reached the stage now, 14 years after it was introduced, where we can no longer sweep the shortcomings of the Tange reform under the carpet and pretend they they are not a problem.

One of the great difficulties in this system, for those of us who have been involved in defence for many years, is that officers who come up through the three Services are highly critical of the operation of the Department of Defence until the point where they get to half-colonel or colonel level. Once they get beyond that level and their careers are directly governed by the system that is in place, they all refuse to say anything about the system. This Committee has undertaken three years of investigation of the Department of Defence and we unanimously believe that there has to be a fundamental change in the way that Department is operated.

While it is a big report and there are a lot of side issues involved, the fundamental point is that we believe that the situation where the Secretary has greater powers than the professional uniformed servicemen has to be changed. The Tange management system that we have in place in the Department of Defence commits the fundamental error of separating responsibility for a task from the control of the resources that are necessary to perform that task. To put it in simple words, what we do under the present system is say to the Chief of the Defence Force, `You are responsible for defending Australia'. But then we do not give him the control over the means to carry out that defence. We do not allow him to make his own assessment with his military analysts, of the strategic situation and of the needs that might arise for him to use his forces. We do not allow him control over how large those forces are. We do not allow him control over the selection of equipment he needs to do the task.

What we have done is separate the responsibility for carrying out this task from the essential resources which must be under the control of that commander if he is to carry out his task efficiently. In that way, we have gone back over 100 years to the situation that was in place when the British forces were committed in the Crimea where, again, there was a separation of responsibility for the operational side of it from the resources needed to carry it out. We would have precisely the same situation today as occurred in the Crimea if we had to commit the Australian defence forces seriously in such a defence emergency. That is really what this report is about.

The report makes it scrupulously clear that we support the principle of civilian control of the Department of Defence and of the armed forces in this country. What we do not support is the bureaucratisation of the Australian defence forces. We believe that civilian control is mediated through the Minister, who is answer- able to his Cabinet colleagues and to the Parliament and, through that, to the people of Australia. We believe that that is the correct interpretation of civilian control.

When the Tange recommendations were implemented by the Whitlam Government and carried on by the Fraser Government, the Defence Act was modified to provide for the changed circumstances. On the surface, there is very little difference between the powers ascribed to the civilian Secretary to the Department and to the Chief of the Defence Force. It is implied in the Act that there is a degree of parity between them on their powers but, in reality, it is quite different. The Secretary is the person who has control of all the key committees. Either the Secretary or his nominee-a first assistant secretary or one of the deputy secretaries-chairs all the key committees. I read from page 110 of the report on the relationship between the two powers, which states:
The CDF-
that is the Chief of the Defence Force-
is responsible to the Minister for the command of the ADF-
that is, the Australian Defence Force-

while the Secretary administers both the Department of Defence and the ADF (the latter jointly with the CDF). While these arrangements appear reasonably straightforward, a number of points are worth mentioning because of their implications for the way in which power is actually exercised within the defence establishment. The first point is that the Secretary alone is responsible for providing policy advice to the Minister. While the CDF is the principal military adviser, he must operate `within approved policy' and `subject to the resources allocated'. This predominant role is reflected in the membership of the key policy advisory committees-the Defence Committee, DFDC, FSC and the Consultative Group-which are all chaired either by the Secretary or his representative. Largely because of his policy-advisory role, the Secretary also has greater formal access to the Minister and could, if he chose, effectively control the agenda.

So there is no parity between the Chief of the Defence Force or the uniformed services and the civilian element in the Department of Defence. We have this great plethora of committees set up-around 90 in number-chaired mainly by civilians, which paralyse the decision-making process within the Department. We have a situation where the civilian element tends to have a degree of permanence to it. The service personnel are on rotational postings every two or three years and the Chief of Defence Force is only in that position for two or three years, while the Secretary tends to stay on. It is true that we have had four secretaries in the last 14 years but by and large the time that the civilian members of the Department of Defence are in significant posts is considerably longer. That, coupled with the structural arrangements which give them the right to chair significant committees, means that effectively the power rests in their hands.

This leads to a huge diversion of human resources into the headquarters at Russell here in Canberra. That, of course, is one of the reasons for the high resignation rate. Many people join the Services to take part in the activities that the Services undertake in times of need and to train for them. They do not join to sit in air-conditioned offices at Russell Hill. Furthermore, because they are at Russell Hill for so long, they became divorced from what the Services are about. Again, I think that is one of the contributing factors to the resignation rate; the senior officers in the Services now are not really familiar with a lot of the things going on in the three individual services. It also means a huge increase in the number of senior officers in administrative posts in the Department. There is an insidious element in this, because there is virtually de facto approval for the promotion of everyone from one star and above-the rank of brigadier, commodore and air-commodore-by the civilian component. People who have served in the Russell Hill offices are known to the civilian element, and people who have an independence of mind and a forthright expression of their views are viewed with disfavour by the civilian element. Promotions from two-star level and above are directly approved, as of law, by the civilian component. So we can be assured that the development of independent minds and of people who are prepared to be individualistic cannot take place under the system that we have in place.

Even though there is a great measure of control by the civilian element of the Department of Defence, peace and harmony do not reign within it. Indeed, one of the characteristics of the post-Tange era in the Department of Defence is the great degree of confrontation that takes place. I would like to quote from the report of the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities of 1986. In a relevant section Mr Dibb said:
Indeed, it was the inability of the ADF and the Department to agree even on basic force structure concepts that brought about this Review in the first place.
On the same page he said:

There are a number of issues that require attention. Some of these were identified by the Defence Review Committee into the Higher Defence Organisation in 1982 (the Utz committee). That Committee's report correctly stated that the scope for `improving working habits and relationships' was considerable, but it did not address the institutional flaws which arguably aggravate those relationships.
Later on at the end of the same chapter Mr Dibb said:

These planning difficulties are exacerbated by adversarial attitudes that exist in the Defence community. While differences of view are inevitable-and indeed healthy-in any large organisation, the levels of disagreement within the Defence organisation are excessive.

In other words, the civilians end up fighting with the professionals and the result is a marked diminution in the productivity and the output from the Department. Characteristically, Mr Dibb does not offer in his report any constructive solutions to redress these problems. When the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) talks about this matter he does so in a dissembling way by describing the situation as, I think, `constructive tension' or `creative tension'. He ought to try that concept on the Israelis when they are having differences with the Arabs. The fact is that we have here a fundamental problem of conflict which has to be resolved for the benefit of all Australians.

This report makes a large number of recommendations. The central part of the report relates to the proposition that we advance as members of the Committee that, if we have professionals, we should trust them and take their advice; that we should put the management of the Australian defence forces in the hands of the service professionals and that we put the civilian component of the Department of Defence in a supporting and enabling role-that is, we reverse the positions that exist at present. There are some secondary elements in the report. We call for an increased involvement of the Parliament in defence. Not only do we recommend that the Minister for Defence become involved in the details of how significant decisions are made and in understanding the processes involved, but we also recommend this for the members of committees and members of parliament generally. I have probably made more speeches on defence in this Parliament in 10 years than any other single person, including Ministers for Defence. I think that is wrong. Defence is one of the really great offices of state. Defence, Treasury, Attorney-General's and Foreign Affairs are the four principal tasks of a Federal government. Yet the time we spend on foreign affairs and on defence is minuscule. That is wrong. That is one of the reasons why we have such a high service resignation rate today. The service personnel feel that no one appreciates what they are doing.

To return to the report, we make considerable recommendations on the financial side as to how equipment should be managed and how materiel acquisitions should be carried out. We support the report of the Public Accounts Committee, which looked at this matter some while ago. We spend some time talking about joint commands. With the consolidation of the three Services into one Australian Defence Force, it is very important that we set up a workable command structure at the highest level so that in an emergency those forces can be used efficiently. Although Australia has a long and proud history in warfare, one of the consequences of our role as ally-first of all with Britain in the First World War and then with the United States of America in the Second World War-was that our forces were often attached as smaller units to the larger forces of another country. Because of that we lacked the command experience at a high level.

In the report that the Committee made in October 1984 on the Defence Force, its structure and capabilities we recommended that changes be made to develop experience in joint command headquarters. The response of the Services to that recommendation has been luke warm. What they have done is convert the three command structures that they had in place-operational command for the Air Force, fleet command for the Navy, and field force for the Army-into an air command, a maritime command and a land command respectively and claimed that they are joint force headquarters. These are not joint commands. It is just the old pals running the same old shop in the same old way as before. What we have called for in this report is the creation of a command which will give practical experience and the development of doctrine and the practice of staff in joint operations; in other words, of the three Services working together as and when they are needed. Importantly, the command structure has to be set up-unlike the present maritime command, land command and air command-so that suitably competent officers of all three Services can head it up as commander and get the requisite experience.

While this report deals at great length with the management of the Department of Defence its recommendations, if implemented by the Government, will not solve our defence problems. Good management is absolutely essential. As I have said before in this place, if we do not have a good management system the thing will not work. But a good management system by itself will not guarantee success. For Australia to have the Defence Force it needs we have to address three fields: the political field, the management field-which is addressed in this report-and the matter of the personnel in the Services. Dealing with the first of those fields, the political field, it is absolutely essential that there be an informed, educated Parliament. There must be debate and discussion within this chamber and in the other place about the needs of the Australian Defence Force and how it should be structured, used and operated. That does not occur at present and it must be developed. The second point is that there must be changes in the management system and this report makes some significant suggestions towards that end. The third point is that there must be a change in the senior officers in the Australian defence forces. Not all the problems that the Australian defence forces face at the present time are a consequence of the Department of Defence and it would be very wrong for anyone listening to me in this debate to believe that I am saying that all the problems stem from the way that the Department is structured at the present time.

The Services themselves have quite a deal to answer for. I believe that at the present time there is a shortage of capable men and women in the senior ranks of the Australian defence forces. That is not to say that we do not have intelligent, capable, competent and very dedicated people, because we do. What we do not have is enough of them. We need to redress the problems of the high resignation rates, as a result of which, through default people who would not otherwise have been promoted have gone up the ladder and now fill a number of the senior ranks. In the future we want those people displaced by more capable personnel.

The provision of defence forces for Australia is a great task which Parliament and the Senate have to face. We must combine the best human resources in both the civilian and the service fields for the benefit and security of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to join with Senator Maguire and Senator MacGibbon in particular in their remarks supporting this very important report which addresses the management of Australia's defence. Like Senator Vallentine, I joined the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade during the session of the Thirty-fifth Parliament. Of course, there were another 10 members of the various committees in both the Thirty-fourth and Thirty-fifth Parliaments. Nevertheless, the Committee does pick up and address many radical areas for change. It is acknowledged that the defence forces in Australia have evolved and, to a large extent, have become incestuous in many of the arrangements that have fallen into place at both the political and at the bureaucratic level. SPEECH.PARA: It is also opportune for me to comment on and to acknowledge the work of all members of those committees and, in particular, to the defence adviser to the Committee, Dr Cheeseman, and the role that he would have played in putting all that together. The report relates to change with the object of effectiveness and efficiency. I think that honourable senators need to recognise that that is probably the most important aspect of the whole report and how it should be adjudged. We need to look very carefully at that part of the functional role that is operational and ought to fall within the responsibility of the defence management area and that part of the role that is enabling and administrative and is most properly the functional role of the Secretary to the Department and the bureaucracy in those particular areas.

Senator MacGibbon alluded to the fact that many senior officers in the Defence Force were neither happy, content, nor felt that they had the challenge to participate in the future of the Defence Force. It will pursue very carefully the issue of separation rates within the Defence Force and it will analyse that. There are many areas in this report where the issues are already flagged and in particular I draw attention to the areas of staff development, the challenge of appropriate education processes to ensure that we end up with the calibre of management in the defence forces in the future and that we are able to hold, and to hold in, many expensively trained people who ought to fully participate in the future of the Defence Force. This is most important as we assess the whole range and future of the defence establishment. As Senator MacGibbon said, the defence sector of Australia's Public Service-and that is what it is-has a very significant, large and important functional role. We need to make sure that the men and women who choose to make their careers in defence are adequately accommodated, adequately trained and adequately rewarded both in the process of their involvement in their careers and their job situations and in knowing that there is a future for them in the management of the defence programs of the future.

I would also like to see a much closer addressing of the future training of the civilian members of the defence forces in the Public Service. I believe that we need to address very carefully the manner in which the civilians are trained-not just at Australian universities within particular disciplines. There needs to be a very careful integration of management training of people in both the military and the civilian bureaucracy to ensure that this is achieved. I am pleased to be associated with this report. I know that the debate will be wide-ranging and controversial, and over the next few months, as this report gathers a lot of attention, I hope that we will see the Government seriously address all the recommendations-and there are many of them-and that we can engage in a very positive series of changes that will stand for Australia's improvement and for the improvement of the defence forces.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak very briefly to this report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade about the management of Australia's defence. It is a very comprehensive and extensive report and requires close study. I strongly support the basic thrust of the report, which is that inside the Defence Department the balance of responsibility, the balance of power, between the professional and civilian elements has been distorted. I believe it was a result of the very proper establishment of a single Defence Force, but was distorted by the way in which action was taken under the Tange report.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two matters which a brief study of the Committee's report has led me to believe were neglected, and these two matters are the relationship in rank between public servants and service officers and the balance of service officer appointments to the senior ranks between operational and support appointments. One of the problems in the rank structure of the Services was the way in which the Tange report awarded quasi-military rank to public servants. It described assistant secretaries as one star officers, that is, brigadiers; first assistant secretaries as two star officers, that is, major-generals; and deputy secretaries as three star officers, or lieutenant-generals. I do not believe that there was a military rank equivalent to a secretary. The result was that on all the committees that proliferated under the old system, where there were delegates from each of the three services and the Public Service, if the Public Service appointed a first assistant secretary the three Services had to produce a major-general, a rear admiral and an air vice-marshal. They were grossly higher ranks than were needed. What was wrong was that the levels were set incorrectly-at least one, possibly two, ranks too high. The changes were made on the basis of equivalent pay. It was notorious and one of the causes of the very high attrition rate among senior officers is that the Services were underpaid. Giving them a relative rank structure based on pay alone caused an explosion in the senior ranks of the service.

I can cite figures relating to the number of officers of various ranks in the Services. For example, the Navy has one vice-admiral, 13 rear admirals and 27 commodores. I interpolate here that there are no sea jobs for commodores at all, yet there are 27 of them. The reason there are so many is that the tremendous number of committees set up under the old structure requires officers of those ranks to attend when officers of two or three ranks lower would have been appropriate if this absurd levelling structure between the Public Service and the professional armed services had not been set. The Army has one general, one lieutenant-general, 13 major-generals and 45 brigadiers. I interpolate again that there is an operational deployment force of two under-strength battalions. The Air Force has two air marshals, 10 air vice-marshals and 29 air commodores.

Those numbers are grossly out of balance in comparison to operational forces. We might not think that that matters much, but it does matter because if there were, say, 14 admirals and 27 commodores and one job for one admiral but no job for any commodores, we would have a senior officer structure without current operational experience. One of the arguments used by a former Minister for Defence was that that was good because we were keeping people ready in case of expansion. There are two things in that regard; first, our Defence Force necessarily is equipment-based and we cannot expand the Defence Force quickly-we could not get the ships, the aircraft or other weapons of war. Secondly, the last thing we want is large numbers of senior officers with no current operational experience. It is far better to keep them in lower ranks so that they can gain operational experience and promote them as they are needed, if an expansion occurs. What we desperately must do is get our operational-non-operational balance in the services corrected, and that requires a very sharp drop not only in the numbers of service personnel in shore appointments and defence headquarters but also in their rank structure. That, in turn, if the system is to work as a co-ordinated one between professional servicemen and civilians, requires a change in the relative rank structure of professional servicemen and the public servants. Without that, we will not solve this problem, which, I submit, is very serious. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I suggest that the Broadcasting (Ownership and Control) Bill (No. 2) 1987, the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1987, the Radio Licence Fees Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 and the Television Licence Fees Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987 be debated cognately with the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly I will make some remarks concerning the timing of the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987, the Broadcasting (Ownership and Control) Bill (No. 2) 1987, the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1987, the Radio Licence Fees Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 and the Television Licence Fees Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987 which have now been hanging about for some three weeks. The Government has not seen fit to bring them forward earlier. In the dying stages of the time allowed for debating these Bills the Government suddenly wants to debate all five broadcasting Bills cognately, thereby truncating enormously the time which would have been available to Opposition senators to discuss these very important matters. The Government has rolled together a number of Bills in a fashion which now forces us to consider them together and this will mean that debate will not take place in the way that we on the Opposition benches would like. Despite that, I hope that the Government will see fit, if need be, to give the Opposition and the Australian Democrats an extension of time to debate these Bills if we so seek at the end of our speeches. I doubt whether we will have the time to be able to discuss these Bills as fully as they demand.

SPEECH.PARA: Bearing that in mind, I turn to the Television Licence Fees Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987, which is a Budget Bill placing further charges on the operators of television stations in Australia. These fees will provide extra income of $5.7m in the next full year, and in 1989-90 they will raise $6.4m. I do not wish to spend a lot of time discussing this matter but I make the point that the Government must have regard to the fact that there is a certain limit to the capacity of the industry to continue to pay rising fees which are being increased every year. Obviously, in this financial year the Government had the imperative to increase television fees enormously in order to meet the Keating Budget target which we all know is on the verge of falling apart. As I will demonstrate later with some of the other legislation, the so-called Budget deficit-in balance, as Mr Keating called it-of some $27m will not be obtainable because the Government has already written off significant amounts of revenue as a result of the introduction of its new system of establishment fees for radio licences. Bearing in mind that this Bill is a Budget Bill, the Opposition will not oppose it.

The Broadcasting (Ownership and Control) Bill (No. 2) is somewhat technical in nature and relates to the legislation that was passed in the dying days of the pre-election Parliament in June this year. It concerns the new television ownership regulations which were introduced in that legislation. This Bill seeks to correct some technical problems. We are used to both the technical problems and the unintended consequences that often pop up in this Government's legislation because it has been ill-considered and rushed through its various processes in both the Cabinet and the Caucus. Consequently, this Bill will seek to correct some such provisions. The Opposition has no particular problems with this legislation. In the light of the fact that the Liberal and National parties will be looking further at the policy in relation to television ownership in the development of their policy on television, they will take into account the matters raised in this legislation.

The point that needs to be made is that this Bill just cleans up some of the errors in the previous legislation and, of course, it provides for the technical operation of the multi-channel service which was one of the alternatives for the operation of regional television stations in Australia suggested by the Government some time ago. This is mostly irrelevant now because the Government has also provided the alternative for regional television stations to be able to operate under the aggregation principle. The commercial processes have already been set to work through the legislation that was introduced last June. We have seen aggregation adopted by regional television operators in Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria. No doubt this will lead to a revolution in regional television in those areas and is a direct result of the Government's legislation of last June. I remind the Senate that the Liberal and National parties did not support the ownership limits that were introduced into the Parliament at that time by the Hawke Government, but the legislation was passed with the support of the National Party.

The Liberal and National parties are concerned about the effects on regional television of the development of either multi-channel servicing or the aggregation of areas throughout the three States concerned. The Government, notwithstanding an undertaking, as I understood it, not to proceed with aggregation in South Australia and Western Australia, in short order has now advised operators in those States that it intends to proceed very quickly with aggregation. That is causing a great deal of concern in South Australia, and no doubt in Western Australia as well, amongst television operators who are now being forced to make decisions which they did not expect to have to make for many years to come.

The point about regional television is simply this: the Liberal and National parties are determined that local ownership and programming of television will remain the prerogative of operators in regional areas. I believe it to be of fundamental importance that localism be preserved and, consequently, I foreshadow moving an amendment to this Bill which indicates our concern at the possible loss of localism in both programming and the ownership of television stations.

The Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987 is a grab-bag Bill made up of several different matters. One of particular importance in the electoral sense will be addressed by my colleague Senator Short at a later stage in this debate. In view of the shortness of time, I will not, therefore, dwell on that matter except briefly to say that the Government has introduced amendments to the electoral law which will control the degree of electoral advertising that can be undertaken by broadcasters in the pre-electionperiod.

The other parts of this Bill concern a large number of matters, but perhaps the most important is the section relating to the public broadcasting sector. As we all know, this sector is developing, and has developed since the early 1970s, as a vital and creative sector of broadcasting. It is alive and well and developing very strongly right across the Australian community. The Liberal and National parties are committed to the ongoing development of this sector of the broadcasting industry, as we believe that the community has a perfect right to involve itself in local broadcasting of all kinds to provide specialist services to those who demand them.

This Bill seeks, after some 10 or 15 years of actual operation of public broadcasting, by a series of legal manoeuvres to set up a proper medium within the control of the Government and subject to broadcasting legislation in the way that it should be regulated in the normal course. I point out that under the legislation which, as I understand it, has applied to public broadcasters-that is, public broadcasting stations which are not owned by any particular person or any particular company but by community organisations-those stations have been subject to special licensing arrangements and, in some cases, have been granted commercial broadcasting licences in radio, whether by virtue of special governing restrictions on those licences or or by other regulation. The whole thing, of course, has been very unsatisfactory.

We have to remind ourselves that the Government has been very slow to set up a new legislative framework for public radio broadcasting in this country. It was back in 1985 that Mr Duffy, the then Minister for Communications, advised the Parliament that he intended to introduce new laws in respect of public broadcasting. But it is only now, in 1987, that we see those stations being established with a proper legal framework. The Government at the same time introduced planning guidelines for the development and regulation of radio but, as I say, the industry has been floundering for some two years, waiting to hear the Government's intentions in this area.

One other element of this legislation which is of importance is the definition of advertisements for the purposes of the Broadcasting Act. This has a great deal to do with, and reflects concern about, the practical operation of public broadcasters, as there has always been some grey area of doubt as to whether or not broadcasting stations in this area treated themselves as being sponsored for particular announcements, or whether they breached those very severe and tight arrangements and in fact were conducting advertisements on behalf of community organisations and bodies. This matter has been dealt with in this legislation, and we hope that it will be clarified for all time. There is included in the legislation some streamlining of Australian Broadcasting Tribunal procedures, which we in the Opposition support and would like to see taken further as time goes by.

I now turn to the Bill which I regard as the central piece of this package, the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1987. This Bill has a rather chequered history, and I think it is wise to run over the milestones along the way to its introduction. Honourable senators will remember that Mr Keating announced in the Budget that we were about to enter an era of licensing of radio and television stations by virtue of an auction system, or a tendering system, as he preferred to call it. Apparently that was a proposal brought to the Expenditure Review Committee by the Department of Finance and the Department of the Treasury in both 1985 and 1986. It is interesting to note that at that time Mr Duffy, the responsible Minister, actually cast out those suggestions and would not adopt them. In came Senator Evans, the present Minister for Transport and Communications, who thought, `This is a bright idea' and adopted them apparently with the coercion of the Treasurer, Mr Keating. It was not long after Senator Evans announced these new proposals that we found that he was in all kinds of trouble with those stations whose licence applications were already part heard. The Department had nominated four areas in particular for new licences in FM radio. They were Gosford, the Gold Coast, Shepparton and Geelong. The Government was seeking to change horses in midstream with these licences. Applications had been called and the people in those areas who were interested in making submissions for licences found that they were acting under a certain set of rules. Then along came the Budget and suddenly all those rules were changed. Many of those organisations-and there were something like 100 right across those four areas-had spent many thousands of dollars, and in some cases many hundreds of thousands of dollars, preparing their submissions and their cases for the Broadcasting Tribunal in seeking the licence. Then they found that, under the new proposals announced in the Budget, they had to turn around and redo their proposals and consequently were being judged on new criteria that were not outlined at the time the original call for applications was made. As you would expect, Mr Deputy President, there was an enormous outcry and before long the Minister, Senator Evans, realised his mistake and was faced with the option of going on in the face of such enormous public outcry or changing his view. Of course, he folded.

The problem with the tendering proposal is simply that it runs against all the principles of broadcasting. It does not allow everybody an equal chance to obtain a broadcasting licence; rather, it allows those who can bid the highest amount of money for a licence to get the benefit. That means that those who are the more powerful financially in the community are perhaps able to do deals and make arrangements which smaller groups are not able to do. We in the Liberal and National parties believe that that kind of approach is wrong, because we should be encouraging, not discouraging, more and more localism in broadcasting and in particular in the area of radio, which we see as a very important medium for local participation, for local reporting and for providing local programming. We believe that those radio areas for which licences had been called and for which the rules have been changed were very badly treated by the Government in this proposal.

We believe that the Government's alternative, which is suggested by this legislation and which provides for an establishment fee system, is just as bad in that it will require very large sums of money to be provided by licence applicants to the Government, not for the purchase of equipment, but merely for the purchase of the licence itself. Consequently, it will restrict the capacity of the organisation taking over the licence to develop programming and to become more effective in the local community. We will be moving amendments during the committee stage of this debate to affect changes to the legislation to exempt the four areas for which licence applications were called at the time the Budget was announced.

We believe that the establishment fee system has all the defects of the auction-tendering system which the Government announced earlier and which will still put those four areas to very significant disadvantage compared with future applicants in other areas. We will also move an amendment to strike out the reference in the provision relating to the calculation of the establishment fee to an amount to be fixed by regulation. We notice that this has been drawn to the attention of the Government by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, which we agree with. The legislation seeks to set a fee paying mechanism which can be determined by a regulation of the Government rather than by an Act of parliament. We believe that it should be controlled by an Act of parliament, that the Government should seek to pass a Bill through this place and the House of Representatives to achieve that purpose on an annual basis, thereby rendering itself capable of scrutiny at any particular time.

The Government has chopped and changed its approach to radio station licence fees and the way in which applications are called. It has made an absolute mockery of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, whose job it is to approve applications for licences, because it has virtually taken out of the ABT's hands any decision-making power. The Government has done this-this has been well documented by complaint by the Chairman of the Broadcasting Tribunal, on the public record-by requiring a certain fee to be paid, however high it might be. That is something which Senator Evans obviously did not think through at the beginning of his exercise and trek down this road. He has become totally confused and mixed up. No doubt all Cabinet Ministers have been confused by his actions in this matter. In view of this confusion, and the great concern in the community about this change and the lack of a proper review of applicants by the Broadcasting Tribunal, the only proper thing to do is for the Government to stop and to refer the whole licensing fee proposition to the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, which will then be able to come down with some suggestions as to what policy might be adopted in this area in the future. Therefore, at a later stage I will move for a reference of this legislation to the Senate Committee for such an examination.

This brings me to a very interesting point. The Government originally claimed in the Budget that it would be getting some $22m revenue as a result of the sale of licences in the four areas I mentioned earlier. As a result of the changes which Senator Evans announced about a month ago when he introduced the establishment fee system he cut that amount of money back to about $11m, when one takes account of the fact that he also changed the amount that he expected to get from the conversion of AM to FM radio licences. The point about this is that Senator Evans, at one stroke, has given up $11m worth of revenue, which will reduce significantly the `balance' which Mr Keating claimed he was going to have in his Budget this year. That is a very significant change.

I would now like to demonstrate that this year the Government will get absolutely no money from the sale of those four radio licences. The truth is that the four areas-Gosford, the Gold Coast, Geelong and Shepparton-are areas where the licence applications have yet to be heard by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. I am advised that the earliest the Tribunal will be able to hear the first of those applications, let alone approve the successful applicant and receive money from the applicant, is about May or June. That means that, given the time for payment of some 60 days after the date on which the issue is determined by the Tribunal, the Government has absolutely no chance of getting any revenue, even from the first applicant that is approved by the ABT, before June 1988. Consequently, the Government will not have any revenue this year and the whole amount of $22m will not be received. The whole exercise, therefore, has been futile.

That makes it even more important for the Government to stop and to take account of our motion to have this Bill referred to the Senate Transport, Communications and Infrastructure Committee to investigate this whole matter. Quite clearly, the Government has plenty of time to give this matter consideration. It does not need this legislation today because it is not going to get money under the legislation by June anyway. What is needed now is a careful appraisal of the legislation. It should be considered by the Senate Committee and, accordingly, recommendations brought down when all factors have been taken into account. Senator Evans, no doubt, must be concerned about this development but he has nothing to lose. He is not going to get any money anyway.

I read today in a Press release emanating from Senator Powell that some sort of a deal has been done between the Australian Democrats and the Government to introduce a system which the Democrats thought up out of the blue in conjunction with the Government which again will reduce the suggested amount of revenue that might be received. As I have said, no revenue will be received anyway. The Democrats have gone to the extent of calculating a new establishment fee system for the licence application areas I have just been talking about. Apparently, the new fees they have suggested have been agreed to by the Government. It would seem, therefore, that we will not be successful in having a proper, detailed examination of this question.

I implore the Democrats, and Senator Powell in particular, to reconsider their position, to come to the support of the Liberal and National parties, guaranteeing the passage of our motion referring the question of the establishment fee system to the Senate Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. We believe that that is what is required. As I have said, there is no possibility of the Government getting the revenue it expected this financial year anyway. There is plenty of time for the Government to set this matter aside and refer it to the appropriate committee, get a report on it and have a broader community debate on the matter.

I mention that in the context of the fact that at this stage there has not been any proper consultation with the industry or with the community generally on the question of the various changes that we have just been tracking through in our discussion tonight. I also foreshadow that in respect of this Bill I shall be moving at a later stage an amendment to the second reading motion to note the Opposition's concern at the Government's ad hoc approach in respect of these changes to broadcasting policy and setting down the reasons for our approach. (Extension of time granted) I thank the Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson) and the Senate. I mentioned earlier the suggested amendments that we will put forward at the committee stage in respect of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee report.

If I may summarise on this Bill, the Government has made an unholy mess of its policy in radio broadcasting. This Bill represents the central piece in that confusion. Secondly, there has been a total lack of proper consultation with the four areas I have mentioned in which the applications had been called at an earlier time and only part heard, and the consultation did not extend to other operators and organisations in the community. Thirdly, having discarded the policy of tendering and auction fees which the Government had announced in the Budget, the establishment fee system was introduced out of the blue, again without any consultation or thought as to how that might have been established. I acknowledge, however, that the Federation for Applicants for Independent Radio-the FAIR organisation-which is interested in FM radio broadcasting came up with a proposal and suggested it to the Government at an earlier stage. I believe, though, that that was the only organisation that supported such an approach by the Government.

The fourth point is that there is a definite need for a review of this legislation and of the whole licensing system by a Senate committee, and for that purpose we shall be moving the appropriate amendment. Fifthly, I ask the Senate particularly to note the rather retrospective effect of the change of rules that has now occurred twice both with the Budget and the new establishment fee system that has applied to those four areas for which licence applications had been called earlier. That is a sound justification for the opposition of the Liberal and National parties to that legislation.

The final Bill in the package is the Radio Licence Fees Amendment Bill (No. 2) of 1987. This Bill contains two major parts. The first is the Bill providing for the payment of a fee by commercial radio licensees for a conversion of broadcasting on the AM frequency to broadcasting on a higher quality FM frequency. Secondly, the Bill also proposes to increase the licence fees payable by some commercial radio stations. The other amendment is the implementation of the establishment fee which we have just been discussing and on which I have already indicated the position of the Liberal and National parties.

Again, on the AM-FM conversion the decision to allow this and to raise revenue from this source was made and announced in the 1987-88 Budget. In general terms we support that idea. We see that the proposals are to apply to regional FM station applications only, and we would like to see an accelerated program for the development of FM radio broadcasting in regional areas. The first point that needs to be noted is another point of major confusion insofar as the Government announced in its Budget that this fee would be calculated on the basis of 30 per cent of the incumbent licensee's annual gross earnings. Suddenly at this later stage in the legislation we find that that has been raised to 50 per cent of annual gross earnings. There has been no explanation, but it is suddenly a factor that is dreamt up out of the blue, obviously showing a lack of appreciation of the issues in the first place.

The other point, as I mentioned earlier, is that the total amount of revenue to come from the sale of licences was to be $22m. There was no mention in the Budget of the amount of money to be received from the conversion from AM to FM radio licences. That suddenly has changed again, because we see that $5m is now expected to be received from this source in this current financial year. This is just a subterfuge to cover up the fact that the Government has dropped off $11m from its original estimate of how much it was to receive, in some way trying to patch up Senator Evans's reputation with the Department of Finance. This is a nonsense and is playing around with the issues. We are very disturbed at the way in which Senator Evans has handled this matter. It shows quite clearly his inability to grasp the realities of the whole broadcasting system.

I have mentioned that we support the principle of converting AM stations to FM in regional areas and consequently will not be opposing that part of the Bill. However, we will be moving an amendment to refer that part of the Bill which speaks of the change in the establishment fee system to the Senate Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. That will be a matter for debate during the committee stage of the Bill and is a matter that we will come to at a later stage. However, at this stage I also foreshadow an amendment which the Opposition will move to the motion for the second reading. Although the Opposition will give the Bill a second reading, our amendment asks the Senate to condemn the Government:

for its decision to increase the fee for the conversion of AM to FM broadcasting from the level announced in the 1987-88 Budget, that is 30 per cent of the converting Station's annual gross earnings, to 50 per cent of annual gross earnings, which will impose an additional cost burden on licensees in regional areas wishing to convert to the FM frequency.
That sums up our major objections and is consonant with our position in regard to the Government's approach to broadcasting as it has been handled by the present Minister.

We find it incongruous that people who are operating AM stations at present who may be able to seek supplementary FM licences can obtain those licences in regional areas without payment of any fee, and yet those converting from AM to FM will have to incur the 50 per cent fee which we have just been discussing. The Government has given no explanation for this approach, but clearly it puts supplementary operators in a position of some advantage in terms of capital outlay if the Government is so inclined. We have already seen some attempt by supplementary licence operators to obtain licences in that situation. We believe that the Government is rapidly getting itself into a frightful mess in this whole area.

Subject to the amendments which we have outlined, we believe that the Government is not covering itself in glory in the area of broadcasting policy. Senator Evans in particular is blundering through this petunia patch of broadcasting without having proper regard to the local circumstances of individual operators or to the future of the industry and its well-being. We believe that the amendments we will move are of substance and certainly demand support. Consequently, we call upon the Australian Democrats to give us their support in the reference-particularly of the establishment fee system-to the Senate Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this cognate debate I wish to address my first remarks to the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1987, the Radio Licence Fees Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 and the Television Licence Fees Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987. The purpose of the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 4) is to introduce an establishment fee for new commercial licences. The obligation to pay the fee comes under the accompanying Radio Licence Fees Amendment Bill (No. 2). The other purpose of the first Bill is to prohibit the sale of new commercial television and radio licences within the first two years of their being granted. This, of course, is to avoid the repetition of what happened in Perth where the new television licence was sold before the station even went to air.

SPEECH.PARA: On Tuesday, 15 September, when the 1987-88 Budget was brought down, the proposal for auctioning of new FM radio licences was announced.
