The Australian Democrats immediately expressed their strong concerns about that proposal. There followed a very strong campaign to draw the Government's attention to the impact of that auction plan on locally based applicant groups who, in many cases over a long period, had got together a number of local shareholders and who were now faced with being swamped by the media empires which would be able-because they have deeper pockets-to outbid local groups for the many licences which were coming up. The Australian Democrats found this abhorrent because we believe that the final decision on the most suitable applicant in these circumstances should continue to be in the hands of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) to ensure that the best and most appropriate local service was not decided by a resort to the higher bidder, which we believe quite strongly would necessarily come from amongst those who are currently dominating the media interests of this nation.

Because of the work done by the Australian Democrats, groups of licence applicants and groups fighting to retain independent radio media-and, I add, the Australian Labor Party Caucus committee-at the same time as the stock market crash, the auction proposal was dropped by the Government. At this point I commend the Government for making that change and for seeing the light. Such a change of direction-acknowledging that a proposed system is less than perfect-is normally followed by a fair amount of criticism by other parties in the interests of point scoring. I note that the National Party's spokesperson in the House of Representatives today could not resist such an indulgence. I think that is one of the most regrettable aspects of Australian politics at the moment. When a government makes a decision which can be applauded, it should indeed be applauded.

I was always somewhat surprised to find the Liberal Party of Australia claiming that that change was a stunning victory for it. In fact, the Liberals were near to useless during that critical period because they were unable to decide what they would do and were constraining themselves with their ridiculous habit of supporting all legislation announced in a Budget or a mini-Budget. I suspect that Senator Messner may also have been frustrated by that particular stance. I do not really know, but if the Liberals are to be at all relevant in this place they need to rethink that silly policy, particularly when the Government has woken up to them and is having two Budgets a year and therefore rendering the Opposition impotent for most of the sessions of this Parliament.

All along, the Democrats have acknowledged the need for a fee to be paid by successful applicants for new FM licences. We believe that there should be due recompense for the allocation of what is, after all, a public resource which is being allocated for the purposes of private profit. It was the Democrats who proposed the payment of an establishment fee and we continue to support that view. We agree with the Government that the grant of a radio licence should bring with it some payment to the public purse. We believe that is fair, but we believe that such a fee has to be reasonable. The establishment fee, which was proposed by the Government and which was in the legislation passed in the House of Representatives, is too flexible and unable to fully take account of the whole range of factors which affect different markets-all markets having their particular characteristics. Certainly, the metropolitan FM stations have been enormously profitable, but it would be unrealistic to assume that therefore all regional FM stations would be also and would be, to use a phrase which upsets many, `a licence to print money'.

The basing of the fee, as the Government did, on the revenue of the existing AM stations directly does not take into account the fact that some AM stations have higher revenue figures because of ownership of perhaps another local media outlet and the ability to maximise advertising rates as a result. Nor can such a formula take account of markets where an efficient AM operator has maximised the potential of that market. It has become increasingly obvious that many of the markets were likely to be declared not viable for independent licence under the system which the Government set in place in its legislation. Of course, this would mean a loss of government revenue because in these markets no establishment fee would be paid. Far more importantly, it would entrench the concentration of media ownership in radio, which is surely the last thing that we need or want in Australia because that is what has already happened with regard to the ownership and, of course, television and the print media.

We recognise that some of the concerns expressed to us by aspirants for new radio licences were more genuine than others. It is obvious that some applicants would not be satisfied with any fee and that some want a licence without charge. I repeat our view, which mirrors the Government's view, that that should not be the case-that a public resource is being allocated for private profit and therefore some reasonable recompense is required. Our judgment is that, to ensure the future of regional radio with a fair degree of local programming and ownership, an establishment fee must impact less on the smaller markets. To that end we are proposing our amendments to the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 4).

In essence, those amendments establish an establishment fee which is based on a graduated scale by virtue, in the first instance, of being linked to the formula upon which the annual licence fee is calculated and, in the second instance, within itself a graduated multiplier to take account of those larger and more lucrative markets graduating down the scale to ensure that as far as possible smaller and less profitable markets can sustain a viable independent station. This will have two results-broadening the ownership of radio and, as we pointed out to the Government quite forcefully and successfully, netting some revenue to Government which would not be available if such markets were to supplementary licences. We realise that in this whole process the Government has halved the $22m Budget figure, under the auction proposal, with its existing proposal for an establishment fee-the proposal which was passed through the House of Representatives. By accepting our amendments, which we confidently expect that the Government will, and by the Minister understanding the arguments and the long term implications which have been put to him, the Government will be accepting a further reduction of almost $2m from the radio industry in this round of licences.

TALK.START.PARA: —What will that bring it down to, Senator?

—On our calculations, the approximate figure will be somewhat over $9m. I agree with Senator Messner that it is arguable whether all of the figure will be available to the government in this financial year. That is a matter for the processes as they are followed through. In this context we note that revenue from both television and radio licence fees is rising, but we also note that most of that increase reflects assumed increases in the earnings of stations. Television licences in particular escaped a significant increase in the Budget because of last minute work by the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, when he hastily reconvened the Expenditure Review Committee. Its deliberations resulted in a lower figure. I suppose we should be pleased about the close interest that the Prime Minister obviously takes in broadcasting matters, particularly those affecting television and newspaper proprietors, but this did cause a loss of revenue-at the hands of the Prime Minister at that stage-from the most lucrative sector of the media industry. If the Government is faced with a shortfall of revenue in the broadcasting area, that should be remembered. We certainly remember it and we certainly remind the Government of that, as we have reminded the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: We also hope that the Government will look at the licence fee area in general and give consideration to some alteration of the criteria upon which it is based. The recent statements at the end of last year by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), who has confidently predicted a surplus Budget next year, lead me to say that a possible $2m shortfall this financial year in this area should be readily catered for.

I underline again the fact that in this whole exercise the Australian Democrats have been looking at the long term implications. As we pointed out to the Government, if markets beneath the Shepparton level were forced to go to supplementaries-even the AM licensee in the Shepparton market, one of the plum markets for which applications had already been called, went through the process of appealing and claiming that that market would have to go to supplementaries under the Government's formula-that would mean, not even in the long term but come next year, no additional revenue from establishment fees for the Government. I believe the Government has accepted that argument.

Most significantly, and to reiterate our major concern, we need to have diversity of ownership and control in at least one section of Australia's media, the television sector having been turned over to media domination by a few significant figures and to networking. Those basic reasons underlying also the need for strong local programming were at the base of our concerns. That is why we listened to people in the industry, looked at the implications and have come up with the amendments that we will be proposing. We were also concerned that applicants who are successful should be given time to pay the establishment fee. We were concerned that any legal challenge should not see the Government left for long periods holding the applicants' money pending the outcome of any legal challenge. We were pleased when the Government put forward an amendment in the House of Representatives which addresses this problem and which now gives a period of 60 days for payment, though we believe it would be fairer for the fee to be paid prior to the issue of licence, that is, at a time much closer to the time when the new radio station would be broadcasting and bringing in revenue.

Another measure which the Democrats urged the Government to look at was the introduction of a licence transfer tax. In the United States of America where, incidentally, the regulatory body has prior approval power, unlike our Australian Broadcasting Tribunal these days, such a fee is being considered. Its introduction here could have helped to address the problem of licences being sold and resold many times over. I believe the Government should look at this again in the near future.

We strongly support the two-year moratorium on the sale of new licences, which is introduced in this legislation. Indeed, we believe that the moratorium could be over a longer period. One of the most important results of the auction proposal being dropped is that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal will now choose the most suitable applicant. We believe that the value of this should not be underestimated. We note the Minister's commitment to look at the regulatory powers of the ABT. We hope that the House of Representatives committee review of the ABT will prove a worthwhile exercise and that at the very least we will return to a situation in which the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal will have prior approval in the case of licence changes, and that such a change will be forthcoming. Nothing could be more important than the task which is entrusted to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal of ensuring the public interest, particularly at this time when Australia's media is in danger of being held in a total stranglehold by a very few major financial interests.

The Minister has also announced new ownership limits for radio which are not yet embodied in legislation but which have been announced and I understand will be introduced in the next session. We certainly made it clear that our support of the present legislation is dependent upon a Government commitment to reasonable ownership rules. I believe the Australian democrats can take some credit for what has been announced. The national limit of 16 stations is more than we wanted, but it is an improvement on the 20 recommended in a departmental discussion paper.

We also pushed for a national audience reach limit which would have prevented a large radio network from buying up 16 stations in the biggest markets and therefore ending up with an audience reach of more than 80 per cent of the Australian population. Unfortunately, the Government has not adopted that proposal. However, there is to be a State limit restricting ownership to 50 per cent of markets per State. I believe that restriction would not be in place but for the pressure which the Democrats have exerted in this whole range of radio policy issues. We would have preferred a 33 per cent limit, but at least there is now a limit which will prevent the domination of a State by one radio group. Cross-media ownership laws will be extended to include radio in any market. People such as me who have lived in regional Australia know that this has been needed for many years.

When the whole package is complete-I stress that in this exercise the Australian Democrats have had in mind the long term and how the whole package will affect the nature of the radio in Australia-there will be stronger ownership limits on radio than those that apply to television or the print media. The Australian Democrats are very happy about that and can take some credit for it. It will go some way to alleviating the damage which has been done by way of legislation in other media areas in recent times. All through this process we have sought to ensure the best media for regional Australians and the restoration of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's power to assess the most suitable applicant. The level of the establishment fee which we are proposing by way of our amendments, and the foreshadowed ownership limits, will together go a long way to achieving our aims for a substantially local and independent radio media.

I turn now to the Broadcasting (Ownership and Control) Bill (No. 2). The major purpose of this Bill is to introduce grandfathering provisions because of the effect of aggregation. As television interests move into extended service areas they should not be in contravention of current cross-media ownership rules. This Bill also addresses the issue of the necessary changes to company structures-particularly those relating to company directors-so that they will not be in contravention of cross-media rules. Some other drafting improvements are also embodied in the legislation. There will also be some Governments amendments to this legislation. All I can say in this regard is that it is a pity that it could not get it right the first time. However, we do not have fundamental objections to those amendments and we accept this Bill.

However, I wish to make some comments on the aggregation issue. I point out that aggregation is now becoming a reality and I stress that this is occurring against the opposition of the Australian Democrats. Here I pick up the pleas of Senator Messner for support for the Opposition's proposal to send the establishment fee issue to a committee and all his protestations about what we are or are not doing in the area of broadcasting legislation. I remind Senator Messner that in February of this year the Australian Democrats attempted to send the whole broad issue of media ownership and control to a committee so that there could be full public scrutiny of the full range of broadcasting legislation. At that time, of course, the Opposition was having its problems. It could not get its act together as far as media policy in general was concerned. As we saw, in the final analysis, particularly on the issue of aggregation, it all came apart and, because of inability of the coalition to stay together, the National Party renegades, quite surprisingly, crossed the floor and voted with the socialist Labor Government. We now have networking embodied in our regional television, perhaps for all time, with the excuse that this would bring in diversity. So now people in the country will be exposed, in the same way as people in the city are exposed, to second rate programs through networking and the stranglehold by the media mates who shore up this Government and who, the Opposition hopes, will shore it up when its turn comes or, at the very least, in the run-up to the next election.

On the subject of ownership and so on in the area of television, we have recently heard rumours that either the Liberals or the Government-it really does not make much difference which; they are rushing and tripping over each other to please their mates as much as they can-will want to increase the ownership limit from 60 per cent to 75 per cent. There are some compelling reasons for that, since a couple of the owners are already over the limit. As I said, the Liberals and the Government are tripping over each other to impress these large television owners. While the Democrats acknowledge that there may have to be some adjustment for aggregation of the kind that we see in this legislation, it certainly need not be a rise in the audience reach to 75 per cent. Any attempt to use aggregation as an excuse to raise that limit will not wash. Similar rumours have been around that the prescribed limit for television ownership should be raised from 5 per cent to 15 per cent. This is an even more blatant attempt to please the Murdoch and Fairfax groups. Fortunately, it seems that the Labor Caucus is not so keen to proceed with that change, for good reasons, and it seems a little less likely now. We will remain vigilant on that question.

I move to the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 3). The main focus of this Bill is to clarify the use of sponsorship on public radio and the use of promotional advertisements, including community service announcements. The Bill also deals with ownership and control regulations of public licences to be controlled by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. Public radio is an exciting area of broadcasting and a relatively new one. Over the past 13 years it has grown rapidly around Australia. A recent survey showed that the public radio sector is attracting a larger audience than many realise. Fifty-eight per cent of Australians are aware of public, community or volunteer radio. Fifteen per cent listened to public radio in the week in which the survey was undertaken. This includes 21 per cent of the people who were surveyed in Melbourne, 28 per cent of the people surveyed in Perth and 53 per cent of the people surveyed in Darwin. The most widely listened to station, Melbourne's 3RRR, has an estimated 323,000 listeners.

Public radio stations or community radio stations, as they are perhaps more appropriately known, take many forms. They range from rural community stations-one station in Harcourt is housed in a disused railway station and is quite fun to visit-to ethnic stations, campus based stations with high music content, Aboriginal stations and others. There are many innovative and worthwhile programs on all stations. One which I think is particularly worth mentioning is the Watching Brief program, which is syndicated all around Australia and which deals with environmental issues and other issues of global concern.

My State of Victoria has a number of stations, including community stations in Portland, Ballarat, the Latrobe Valley and central Victoria, where, as I said, 3CCC operates from the old Harcourt railway station. Radio Port Phillip serves the Mornington Peninsula on Melbourne's outskirts. In Melbourne the two stations with the highest listening audience are 3RRR, which was originally a campus based station and which very successfully combines education and music formats, and 3CR, the very first public radio station in Australia, which provides access to a wide range of community groups. The birth of 3CR in 1976 actually preceded the issuing of public licences. Since then it has grown to the point where it now has over 170 programs each week, including 30 ethnic programs in 13 languages, with three new language groups waiting in a queue to join. The station has a broadcasting code which specifically excludes:

Threatening, abusive or insulting and promoting hatred against or hostility towards groups of persons distinguished by their sex, sexual preference, race, religion, colour or ethnic or national origins, bringing into contempt or ridicule groups of persons distinguished by their sex, sexual preference, race, religion, colour or ethnic or national origins.

The range of programs which are broadcast on that station at least include gardening shows, brass band shows, a local suburban football program, music programs, youth programs, women's programs, Aboriginal programs, programs for all sorts of ethnic groups, a whole range of environmental and anti-nuclear group programs and so on down the list. Approximately $1.5m was given in grants to public radio in 1986-87. This went to 110 different stations which themselves raised over $7m from their listeners. The funds from government are disbursed through the Public Broadcasting Foundation, an organisation with an excellent administrative reputation. It is disappointing to me that the Minister could not find room in his restructuring of the radio industry, at least thus far, to provide further funds for the development of the public radio sector. Such funds could have come from an increase in licence fees or by setting aside a small proportion of the revenue raised from the establishment or the AM-FM conversion fees.

The Democrats believe that such a fund would be well justified in terms of both the benefit to the many listeners and an acknowledgment of the role that public radio plays in training. A recent survey showed that a large number of those working in the commercial media had in fact previously worked in the public radio area either as volunteers or as paid staff. A report from the public broadcasting sector includes a survey of the 14 larger and more established community radio stations showing that in the period 1982 to 1986 Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio employed 114 people from the public radio sector; ABC television, 26 people; Special Broadcasting Service radio, 14 people; and SBS television, two people. In the print media, 53 people moved from the public radio sector; in commercial radio, 95 people; and in commercial television, 39 people.

It appears that time may overtake me and I would seek the indulgence of the Minister for an extension of no more than four or five minutes so that I may conclude my remarks in this cognate debate. (Extension of time granted) I thank the Minister for his indulgence. I think that that is quite an impressive list of the number of people who have moved from the voluntary sector into professional work, that is, training that is not paid for in any way. I believe it is a good argument for at least some increased funding in the public radio sector.

This Bill will bring some welcome changes to the regulations covering the public radio sector. Amongst other things, it will clarify the area of promotion and sponsorship, including community announcements and program promotions. The public radio sector has been calling for a review of this area and we are pleased that this need finally is to be met. The Australian Democrats are pleased that we now seem to have a Minister who has quite a strong commitment to the public broadcasting sector. In the past, strong support has not always been there and it is a credit to the determination of individuals and community groups who have developed public radio that it is now so strong and so widespread. As I said, it has shown phenomenal growth since the beginning in 1974 to the present, when 70 stations are operating around this nation.

The lack of a timetable for future public stations has been of concern to the Public Broadcasting Foundation and the announcement earlier this year of a timetable was welcomed. However, we point out to the Minister that there are some problems with individual applications and the long delay before they all begin to operate. It is a very difficult business for some applicants. For example, a group in Warrnambool in Victoria is shown on the timetable as due to be granted a licence in 1992. This group has been setting itself up for several years and it is now ready to begin operating. It would be unrealistic to expect it to wait until 1992. I hope, and the Democrats ask, that the Minister will do whatever he can to introduce some flexibility into the timetable to cover situations like this which I know are reflected in other areas around Australia.

In general terms, in relation to the issues of broadcasting policy, and in particular to radio policy which is addressed in a number of ways through this package of Bills which we are debating cognately, the Australian Democrats welcome the pattern which is being set. As I have said in the course of my remarks, it is a pattern which demonstrates that at least one section of the media in Australia stands a chance-and a much better chance, given that the Government is expected to support our amendments on the issue of the establishment fee-of remaining diverse in ownership, with strong local content surviving, and that is the radio medium. The Australian Democrats deeply regret what has happened and is continuing to happen in the other areas of the media. We will continue to exhort the Government to move to increase diversity of ownership and to improve the ability of local content to survive. In the context of the radio legislation, we will be delighted with Government acceptance of our amendments. In large measure, we commend this legislation to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a series of broadcasting Bills. I do not intend to speak for long but, as I remain concerned about the media restructuring occurring as a result of Government's legislative direction in this area, I intend to take this opportunity to voice my concerns again. The Bills before us are mixed in their effects. The Television Licence Fees Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987 increases the rate of fees payable by television licensees. It is a tax increase by another means and, as was mentioned by a colleague in a previous speech tonight, there must be a limit on this. The Radio Licence Fees Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 is another revenue raiser which imposes increased fees payable by radio licensees. With this legislation the Government has increased the conversion fee since its announcement in the Budget and changed the originally announced auction system, which has already been dealt with at length in this debate. The combined effect of AM to FM conversions and the higher fees is expected to raise an extra 31 per cent in collections.

SPEECH.PARA: The three broadcasting Bills are much more wide ranging. They deal with, among other matters, cross-media ownership, Aussat, electrical blackouts, the Special Broadcasting Service, associated members for the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) and establishment fees for FM radio licences. Generally, they reflect the continuing direction of the Government's broadcasting package. The major issues which I wish to touch upon tonight revolve around the question of the concentration of ownership which is occurring as a result of the Government's package and the deficiencies at the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, two issues which so far the Government is not satisfactorily addressing.

My concerns arise from the unique nature of information and the unique function in our society of the media. I remind the Senate that the media is unlike any other market. In the 1960s, the British royal commission referred to the paramount public interest, and placed it apart from other competitive industries. I commend that sentiment to the Senate. The role of the media and its importance in a democracy prompted Ralph Nader to describe information as `the currency of democracy'. As I said, the media is not like any goods market; it deals with information, opinion and opinion formation. For that reason, it is important that there not be an undue concentration of ownership, whether it be in public or private hands.

In its grand scheme of changes the Government claims a freer operation of market forces, but it fails to properly take into account, on the one hand, that the number of electronic licences is limited and, on the other hand, that the barriers to entry in the newspaper arena, particularly within metropolitan cities, are enormous. The Government claims that, by a combination of its cross-media ownership and audience reach provisions, a more diversified media ownership will be produced, but the facts suggest otherwise. Until recently, among metropolitan daily newspapers, representing 85 per cent of newspaper circulation, the four-firm concentration of the market was 99.2 per cent. It is now marginally less, but still involves four firms: principally, News Corporation Ltd and John Fairfax and Sons Ltd, with the comparative small fry, Northern Star Holdings Ltd and the Bell Group Ltd. These firms control our print media.

If the Government had its way with the television audience reach of 75 per cent which it sought, the so-called `queens of the screen' as Senator Gareth Evans described them, could legally have had stations in every capital city, Darwin, Launceston, Wollongong and Newcastle and still not exceeded that limit. This is important because of the restricted number of licences available. Public debate still continues as to whether it is possible to have a fourth station, and no doubt that debate will continue further. The corresponding four-firm concentration of the market in television is better, but not by much-a mere 98.5 per cent. Ownership of media is important and prompted a comment which has been quoted in the Senate previously but which I believe is worth repeating. This statement was made by a person who has great knowledge in this area, Rupert Murdoch, who in 1977 said:

I think it would be a pity if I grew any bigger in Australia. there are now basically three newspaper groups in Australia, and that's too few already. If I were to grow bigger and take over one of the other groups-or be taken over-that would be against the public interest. I'd like there to be six groups. The fewer there are, the worse it is.

What has happened, in fact, is that there are now fewer groups. Mr Murdoch's position is significantly strengthened. Presumably, he is still saying, `The fewer there are, the worse it is'. That statement no doubt conflicts with his financial well-being. Many other people have commented about this concern regarding the concentration of media ownership, one of the most prominent being Sir John Norris in an inquiry in Victoria-and this quote is worth repeating-who said:

The amount of news which pours in upon the media is so great that it is impossible to publish everything. Accordingly, the media must select the items for publication, and they must decide the manner in which they will present them. Little reflection is needed to realise that the power to select the facts that are to be published, and to decide the light in which facts are presented to the media's audience, is a major factor in determining public opinion. the real danger may not lie in the act of propagation of one-sided views, but in the conscious or unconscious suppression of shades of opinion which ought to have a voice.

I commend those comments to the consideration of the Senate. Under a system of concentrated media ownership, there is every likelihood that that concentration will, in fact, grow further. As I indicated, the barriers to entry are becoming higher and higher and, while there may be competitors, their market share and influence will be marginal. One need only reflect for a moment on just how difficult it would be to set up a metropolitan newspaper in any major Australian city to compete with the established newspapers. We can recall the recent unsuccessful attempt, involving only a short period of time, to set up a daily financial newspaper in competition with the Australian Financial Review. In our market it is becoming practically impossible to set up a competitor, and those who draw to our attention the example of the independent newspaper in the United Kingdom, of course, fail to realise that they are talking about an entirely different market.

We must bear in mind also that, when we talk about the power of influence through economies of scale, increasingly national boundaries are becoming unimportant as we look to more and more large international media organisations, such as Mr Murdoch's organisation, which simply have Australian connections. Our Australian based media operations, in some cases, have overseas media and other connections. It is these international connections and technologies that can profoundly influence what we see, read and hear. New technologies, the ability to syndicate across a large network, can give a big operator overwhelming economies of scale. Quite apart from the unequal competitive balance, we may see, I suggest, an unhealthy uniformity of programming.

To achieve a competitive and quality media Australia needs a number of economically sound media chains and fewer players. It does not need a few very dominant corporations; it does not need token competition from operators who are involved mainly to diversify their investment portfolios. Because of the unique nature of information, this Government should ensure that this is the case. But it has failed to do that. Of course, we really need to recognise that the media, a big business, involves not only newspapers, television and the like-and I suppose that this has been brought to our attention particularly in the past few days-but also the supply of newsprint, reliable newsagency reports, magazines and methods of distribution. I raise this matter because in the past few days we have seen the potential for one chain, in effect, to take control of the whole vertical integration of these various parts of the industry. Of course, I refer to the possibility of News Corporation Ltd, subject to a Trade Practices Commission inquiry, taking control of the Australian Newsprint Mills-which, I think, produces about 90 per cent or more of Australian newsprint-and taking control of Australian Associated Press which is the major gatherer of news information in this country. Those groups will be added to News Corporation's enormously powerful newspaper outlet structure in this country.

I think that even the most determined free marketeer must be concerned at the development of this type of vertical monopoly that covers every facet of the industry and how in the future it could not only dominate but also restrict the supply of information to the community at large. An example of the deficient, negligent approach to the media by this Government is demonstrated by its willingness to happily ignore the public statements of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal over the past two years. The Government's answer is really a rather pathetic avoidance of responsibility; it has simply passed the task to a new parliamentary committee, its first assignment being to examine the powers of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. I will return to that point later.

Another example of the deficiencies I suggest, in the approach to the media is the farcical award of the sale of the third Perth television station. The Government will come back immediately and say that, in some ways, it has provided an answer to that debacle, but I remind honourable senators briefly of some of the aspects of that farcical situation. In 1986, honourable senators will recall, Kerry Stokes was awarded the licence for the new station which was to be known as NEW-10. That occurred after 117 days of Tribunal sittings and the attendant expense of $6m.

There were two significant changes in shareholdings in the course of that inquiry, both of which were quite legal, and the second being the most significant, because Mr Stokes disposed of his interests at a massive profit to Northern Star Holdings. The second change was significant because the station had not made a single telecast. Here is an example of a station that is simply a public resource being granted a licence by the public in terms of a particular owner but being transferred at a massive profit before it had operated. What does that mean in relation to the various undertakings that had been given and the representations that had occurred during the 117 days of the inquiry? Honourable senators may recall that Kerry Stokes said that up to 60 per cent of his West Coast Telecasters would be available to the public, but that did not occur. I am not suggesting that that was not the intention when the comment was made, but it did not happen and the station was nevertheless sold.

A strong point in Mr Stokes's bid for the licence was a commitment to a resurgence in local production. No doubt that was of great appeal in Western Australia. He promised local documentaries, quiz and variety shows, community affairs programs, locally written drama and Western Australian ballet specials. There were plans to telecast 5 1/2 hours of local sport on Saturdays with an emphasis on low profile sports such as netball. Such sports are very appealing and should be covered, but they have not been adequately covered in the past. West Coast said that it would employ some 150 people with apprentices and younger employees being drawn from local technical institutions. Presumably, all these commitments no longer bind the new licence owners. Whether the remedy being imposed by this Government-that is, a two-year restraint with a power to avoid that-will be adequate to avoid a repetition of such a situation is still very much in question.

The first matter I mentioned was that it was remiss of this Government not to address the continuing and constant complaints being made publicly and being brought to the attention of the Government by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. Before I sit down, I will briefly remind the Senate of these matters because they have not, as yet, been answered. The Chairman of the ABT, Deidre O'Connor, criticised deficiencies of the Broadcasting Act-criticisms which have not yet been met by legislation-and referred to it as a toothless tiger. Senator Gareth Evans conceded that the Tribunal faced an impossible task on its present legislation, and it still does. That has not been corrected by the Government, although the concession has been made. In an editorial on 10 November 1987 in the Australian Financial Review the Tribunal was referred to as a tremendously expensive and wasteful exercise in tokenism, exactly what the Tribunal should not be. I will not go through its early history but will refer to just two annual reports which specifically brought the challenge home to the Government, a challenge which has not been met. The first public expression of frustration was in the ABT's 1984-85 annual report, which stated:

The Broadcasting Act-Unfortunately, the legislation has prevented the expectations of improved broadcasting administration from being fully realised. Although there was a radical change in the policy of broadcasting regulation and administration there was not a comparable change to the legislation. Rather, the new policy was implemented by welding the concept of a public inquiry on to the existing provisions. Not surprisingly, this has created difficulties and frustrations for the Tribunal, the industry and the public.

Of course the Government did not listen. The Tribunal, in its 1985-86 annual report, was more direct. It detailed no fewer than 10 proposals for immediate consideration by the Minister and then detailed a further 12 proposals for attention. Progress on some of these proposals has been painfully slow. The Tribunal-and I must give it credit for its persistence-went on to state:

In the long term, the Broadcasting Act needs radical revision. In many respects, the Act drains Tribunal resources for doubtful public benefit, and places unnecessary burdens on the business sector and the public. It does not deal properly with converging technology, at a time when the distinction between `broadcasting', `radio-communications' and `telecommunications' as a whole is becoming increasingly irrelevant. In the Tribunal's opinion, any revision of the Broadcasting Act should aim for the following:
coverage of all telecommunications services with point to multi-point potential;
a clear statement of overall regulatory objectives;
a realistic framework that will be supported by the resources and government commitment to ensure that it is administered efficiently and is respected by the industry and public;

the minimum degree of mandatory regulations necessary to protect the public interest in a particular service, coupled with a range of additional discretionary powers exercisable within the bounds of clear policy objectives and constitutional power.

In the last year or two under this Government we have had a mass of broadcasting legislation, but it has not properly addressed the criticisms that have been brought to its attention by the Tribunal. I respectfully suggest that it is about time that it did.

Those are basically the matters I wish to bring briefly to the attention of the Senate tonight. Despite the mass of legislation, many Bills have yet to come before the Senate and no doubt the arrival of a satisfactory media control within this regime will take considerably more time. It will be next year before the Senate debates the recently announced radio licence changes. Obviously it will be a long time before the House of Representatives committee recommendations on the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal are brought before the Parliament. As an individual I must say that it is a pity that there will not be an inquiry and that we will not receive recommendations about the community cost of the concentration of ownership within the media that we are experiencing in this country. Hopefully, greater application by this Government in meeting the very reasonable criticisms of the ABT in relation to reforming the Broadcasting Act will in due course give the ABT more teeth and ensure quality media for Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this cognate debate to address my remarks specifically to that part of the legislation dealing with the establishment fee for FM radio licences. I trust that my remarks will be succinct and that I will not take too much time of the Senate. However, I would like to make half a dozen points which I think are important. Speakers in the debate have already pointed out that the history of this legislation, to put it mildly, has been ad hockery at its worst. Initially, four new licences were to be granted in the Gold Coast, Gosford, Ballarat and Shepparton and the closing date for those applications was 14 September. On 15 September, when the Budget was brought down, the Government had changed its mind and wished to proceed to a tender system which was, quite clearly, only a revenue raising device and which had no concern with the quality of additional radio licences.

SPEECH.PARA: Then we saw a subsequent move from a tender system to the so-called establishment fee, which is now being varied yet again and which, in the words of Senator Powell at a Press conference which I understand she gave today, would ensure that the radio industry was not dominated by a small number of big networks. I find her remarks in no way convincing because the ramifications of the establishment fee remain the same. Essentially, new commercial FM stations in a regional market are small businesses which quite simply cannot carry the extra burden of the establishment fee. For instance, in 1985-86 the radio industry returned only 8.5 per cent operating profit on gross revenue-the latest figures available. Furthermore, it was originally envisaged, when radio licences were to be given on their merits as distinct from who was able to pay for them, that more people would have access to participation in the business of public broadcasting.

The idea of the fee being in any way equitable has serious problems as well. For instance, in any of the given markets AM commercial licences are already in existence, exploiting those markets and having an established revenue base. The difficulty confronting people who have applied for these licences is one which ought to be acknowledged. Our move to have the matter referred to a committee deserves the support of the Australian Democrats, and indeed Senator Messner earlier today implored them to reconsider their position. The criterion for the new fee being imposed in Geelong, Shepparton, Gosford and the Gold Coast had been established, and there has now been a change in that criterion. I hesitate in this context to use the word `retrospective', but it is undeniable that the conditions that existed when people put together their applications no longer exist and indeed they have been penalised in that endeavour.

Another point of concern is that the establishment fee for new commercial licences is to be twice that charged for conversion from AM to FM, and I see nothing from the new negotiations that the Democrats have had with the Government which is in any way going to change that. Then we come to the question of the 30-days period versus the 60-days period for the payment of an up-front fee. The fact that it is to be changed from 30 to 60 days really does not overcome two intrinsic problems. The mechanism for the granting of the licence is that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal will decide on merit who is to be the successful applicant. That applicant will then be advised of that success and told that if he makes the required payment in the required time, the licence will be granted. What, then, is the position if there is to be an appeal? What, then, is the position if the establishment fee has had to be borrowed and interest is being paid on it? Should an appeal be upheld? Does that mean that the Government would return not only the paid establishment fee but also the interest that it has attracted? Indeed, if in that 60 days an appeal is launched, and the initial successful applicant does not make the prescribed payment within the 60 days, does he lose the right to that award, irrespective of what happens on appeal?

There is a further question of some considerable debate. What is the nature of that establishment fee for taxation purposes? It is a considerable amount of money; it is not inconsequential. Is it a once-off capital payment or is it an expense? How is it to be treated by those people who are investing in that application for a licence? One of the more reasonable requests made by people who have been affected by the new legislation, and which I think is worthy of consideration by the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, is this: Would it not be more equitable and fair that if an establishment fee were to be paid, that fee should be paid on an annual basis over the period of the granting of the licence, which is normally five years? Why is it required that the fee be an up-front payment? Is it only to be a revenue raising device? If so, as has been pointed out by speakers earlier in the debate, the benefit of the Government receiving the revenue in a short timeframe has now been negated because of all the changes that have occurred.

It seems to me that there are many issues which remain unresolved, and this will always be the case when legislation is put up in a hasty manner and then chopped and changed on more than one occasion. I would like to recap those problems which I think are important and need to be redressed. Is it fair that a new licensee has to pay twice the amount of money of someone who is converting an AM licence to an FM licence and has already had the advantage of exploiting a market where such a fee was not payable? Is the new and more complicated formula to establish the amount of that establishment fee, following negotiation between the Democrats and the Government, a fair and equitable one? Is it fair and reasonable that people who have prepared their applications-that is, the four I mentioned earlier-on one basis that was prescribed by the Government, should find that the conditions have changed subsequent to the closing date, or should these licence applications be exempt from any future legislation? Is it fair and reasonable that in the 60-day period provided for the payment of the fee, that fee could possibly be at risk, and indeed, that interest which may accrue to someone who has paid it could be simply an additional cost which is borne? Is it fair and in the public interest that a system such as that proposed be introduced which will squeeze out the small businessmen in the radio industry simply because they cannot bear the additional burden of this establishment fee?

I think those points that I have raised, together with the one that if the Government persists with the establishment fee, as it seems determined to do, it should be able to be paid in instalments, are all fair and reasonable. If we in this chamber are interested in seeing fairness and equity and in seeing the public good served, I suggest that the Democrats should answer Senator Messner's plea and support the actions of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The package of broadcasting Bills that the Senate is debating tonight are all very important. Senator Messner, on behalf of the Opposition, has covered in his remarks in the second reading debate, the main points that the Opposition wishes to raise in relation to the package of Bills as a whole. I will restrict my remarks tonight-and I would like to continue them in the committee stage of the debate-principally to the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 3), although I recognise that, as Senator Messner has pointed out, the key Bill is probably the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 4). In that context, and before getting on to the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 3)-which I wish to concentrate my remarks on-there are some issues about those other Bills, particularly the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 4), that I would like to make.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has foreshadowed, through Senator Messner, an amendment in relation to the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 4) to add the following words to the motion for the second reading:
``, but the Senate notes with concern the ad hoc approach that the Government has adopted concerning recent changes to broadcasting policy which is exemplified by:
(a) the decision to abandon the proposal to auction new broadcasting licences only six weeks after the proposal was announced;
(b) the decision to implement an establishment fee system for new FM radio licences, which will:
(i) seriously disadvantage local or community groups from obtaining the new radio licences in regional markets.
(ii) result in a reduction in the competitiveness and diversity of radio services to listeners in regional markets.

(iii) have a particularly deleterious effect on those applicants currently being assessed by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal for the radio licences in Geelong, Gosford, the Gold Coast and Shepparton, and
(iv) lead to widespread uncertainty in the broadcasting industry about possible future changes to broadcasting policy; and
(c) the Government's failure to fully consider possible alternatives to the establishment fee system and to consult with the radio broadcasting industry''.

The Opposition is expressing serious concerns about the Government's approach to these Bills. Each of the Bills is flawed in various ways. All of them are flawed with a common trait, that is, the basic uncertainty which has prevailed for months in the Government's attitude towards this legislation. I do not know when the Government is going to get into its head the fact that, if we are going to conduct business in this country on a commercial and proper basis, the industries concerned must be able to operate within a sphere of certainty. With chops and changes in Government policy, of which this legislation is but one example, from day to day and week to week, it is no wonder that there is a great deal of uncertainty and concern throughout industry. But uncertainty and concern are not confined just to industry but extend through the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and other non-commercial bodies. There is a great deal of concern as to just where this Government is going. It is about time the Government got its act in order. I urge the Government to take note of the concern being expressed by the Opposition on behalf of a very wide range of the community about the ad hoc approach it is adopting towards government in this country.

The Democrats' statement, which I understand was in the form of a Press release today and to which Senator Messner referred, on the establishment fee system is a matter of staggering propensity. Earlier this year the Government proposed, in the Budget, I believe, the auction system in relation to licence fees which was going to bring in $22m. I remind the Senate that the Government was estimating a Budget deficit this year of a whole $27m-about $3 billion not enough. The $22m we are talking about is almost equal to that amount. Within about six weeks after the Budget was introduced the Government thought that that was not quite the way to go so it came up with another scheme which, as I understand it, is incorporated in the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 4) and which was going to bring in $11m.

Today we hear that the Government has done a deal with the Democrats to have another system of graduated fee scales which is going to bring in $9m-a fall of another $2m. Perhaps one can ask: What is $2m out of a total Government Budget of about $80 billion? One can say two things. Firstly, the degree of uncertainty and confusion that all this has caused is monumental and is costing industry a great deal. Because it is costing the industry a great deal, it is costing the community a great deal. If industry cannot operate effectively in an environment of government stability and certainty, the community-the user-is going to suffer.

Secondly, we have had examples of this which are legion. The $2m here and the $10m there add up to a very large amount of money. If the Government is really serious in saying to the Australian people that it is a competent economic manager, that it knows where it is going in terms of government financing and that it expects the community and the private sector to pick up the ball and run effectively, I do not understand how the Government can really believe that that can happen with the degree of uncertainty it is generating. It is not just a matter of this legislation. It is a matter which pervades the whole area of Government management at the moment and is but one, although a significant, example of just how incompetent the Government is increasingly becoming at managing its own affairs and, therefore, the affairs of the community as a whole.

Senator Powell said earlier that, I think in February this year, the Opposition refused reference to a Senate committee of a range of media ownership matters. I think I quote her roughly accurately. She implied that, by doing that, we had refused to have considered by a Senate Estimates committee the establishment fee issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—That was the implication of what Senator Powell said. If she was not saying that I hope that she will take the opportunity in subsequent remarks afforded in the committee stage of this debate to refute the quite wrong implication she made in her remarks tonight. The subject that we were talking about earlier in the year had nothing at all to do with this subject. Indeed, what we are talking about now is yet another shabby deal that the Democrats have stitched up with this Government. If that is not what she was saying, let her have the courtesy and the honesty to get up and say so.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill on which I wish to concentrate most of my remarks is the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 3). There are several important parts to the Bill. As the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) said in his second reading speech, it covers a wide range of matters affecting public broadcasting and the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's administrative procedures. Two significant aspects of the Bill-although there are many aspects of significance-to which I wish to draw particular attention are the provisions in relation to radio station 3CR in Melbourne, which is subject to one of the amendments relating to the public broadcasting provisions. The amendment in the Bill provides for the conversion of radio station 3CR to a public licence. As Senator Evans said in his second reading speech:

The station was granted a limited commercial licence in 1976 before public licences were introduced. The conditions which were applied to the licence to establish its `limited' character related to restrictions on advertising. These conditions were reflected in the scheme of public broadcasting which was introduced subsequently. Since 3CR has always been conducted as a public licence, it is appropriate for it to be formally converted to that form of licence. The current situation is an anomaly which needs to be corrected to ensure that the other amendments made by this Act apply to 3CR in the same way as to other public stations. The conversion is a purely administrative process which will not affect the operation of the station.

There are certain matters I would like to remind the Senate of. Station 3CR, since its establishment in 1976, has certainly been Melbourne's most controversial and, quite unequivocally, Melbourne's most offensive radio station.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only a few programs.

—Those programs are very important. They are the programs against which 3CR is measured and certainly ought to be measured. If there are offensive or highly offensive programs on any radio station, they are the programs by which that station rightly would expect to be judged. The pro-terrorist line that 3CR has followed since its establishment in 1976 is a line that we as members of the national Parliament not only should be aware of but should condemn. It has run, in particular through Bill Hartley's program Par Avion but in other programs as well, a pro-terrorist line. I think Senator Ray would not deny that point.
—Even worse, it runs an anti-Ray line every week. It never attacks you.

—I extend my sympathies through the Chair to the Minister, and I feel that is a matter of concern. I am glad to see him looking fairly relaxed about it. The fact remains that it is offensive, it is pro-terrorist, it is a racist station and it smacks in everything it says of bigoted, racist and terrorist statements. Statements early in its career prompted a bitter and well fought attack from Australia's Jewish community, which did not culminate in an inquiry because a deal was struck between the two parties, but I am told that it is honoured more in the breach. This matter and similar matters were brought to Parliament's attention in several adjournment speeches, particularly in the other House. If one looks at some of the interjections that took place in those adjournment speeches in the other House, one may not be surprised at, but one should be aware of, the interjections, particularly by the honourable member by La Trobe (Mr Milton). The honourable member for La Trobe has a considerable interest in that station. He holds trust shares or units in it. It is no secret. It is contained in the disclosure of members' interests in the other place and is something we should be aware of.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not only the Jewish community which has been insulted by the poisonous venom that has emanated from 3CR. It has made continuous and extraordinary anti-American statements. After the shooting of the President of the US in 1981, a 3CR broadcaster said:
I see they didn't get him anyway. It was a nice try though. Perhaps the guy who plugged John Lennon should have tried for the big R. Better luck next time.

Greek and Italian organisations have joined in the chorus of protest against 3CR. Even the Cain State Labor Government in Victoria is complaining. Indeed, I support Cain Government Minister Crabb in the case that he has taken against 3CR. I understand that he is opposing 3CR's present licence renewal application. The Minister has initiated legal proceedings against the station alleging contempt of the conciliation and arbitration hearings.

The conclusion reached by many in the late 1970s and early 1980s that 3CR was dominated by the ultra left to the exclusion of opposing views is just as valid today as it was then. A look at the list of its affiliated organisations is but one indication of that. In September this year in the report of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal into 3CR`s licence renewal application, the Tribunal expressed concern:

. . . the tribunal is concerned at Mr Hartley's lack of reponsibility when filling out a program questionnaire, especially considering that he is a director at the station. This lack of responsibility reflects adversely on him personally, and puts a particular onus on the station's management to deal with any outcome of the court proceedings which would affect the services provided to the public.
As a consequence the Tribunal expects the licensee to keep it informed of the outcome of the contempt proceedings, and how this is dealt with through its internal management process, if necessary.

One could go on further about 3CR, but I shall not do so at this time. I feel that the Senate needs to be aware of this point, given that one of the important provisions of this Bill is to change the station licence of 3CR. Although the Minister says that it will have no practical effect, my understanding is that it will give it some greater reach. I would be interested to hear the Minister's comments.

The other point I wish to make on the Bill is listed in the Minister's second reading speech under the heading `Other Matters'. I refer to the deletion of the political identification requirements currently set out in section 333 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act and the consolidation of these requirements in the Broadcasting and Television Act. The Minister said:

These provisions set out the requirement for identification of speakers in electoral broadcasters and records of electoral broadcasts to be kept by broadcasters. The amendment will overcome the confusion caused by the similar obligations which are currently imposed by these different Commonwealth Acts, thus implementing a recommendation in the 1984 report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform.

The Opposition agrees that that was a recommendation of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform in its 1984 report. We do not have any great difficulty with that proposition. The Electoral Reform Committee included some notable members of this place, in particular from our side of the House the Hon. Sir John Carrick, who took a great, abiding and expert interest in these matters. He was a signatory to that report and that in itself gives the Opposition confidence in the matter. We have examined the matter closely and would support the general thrust of the Committee's report, which by and large has been taken up at this stage in the amendment proposed to this Bill.

The 1984 report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, identified three areas of concern in relation to the broadcasting of election matter. Of those the first and perhaps the most important was:

. . . inconsistencies between the provisions governing broadcasting of political matter in the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942 and the provisions governing the broadcasting of election matter in the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918, and the need for consolidation of these provisions.

What is being done in the present Bill is in essence to remove from the Commonwealth Electoral Act the relevant provisions in relation to the broadcasting of election matter, and to incorporate those in the Broadcasting and Television Act. We agree with that. We think that it is being done broadly in the correct manner. There are other aspects of a technical nature concerning this action which I will reserve for comment during the committee stage of the Bill. There are some matters that we need to look at, and I hope that the Minister will offer some comment on these. For example, the Committee on Electoral Reform recommended that the Australian Electoral Commission publish a manual of Australian electoral law and practice, including relevant obligations not contained in the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918. Now that section 33 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act is being abolished and the general gist of it is being incorporated in the Broadcasting and Television Act, that adds additional weight to the Select Committee's recommendation along those lines.

That Select Committee made more than 100 recommendations of which only about a quarter have been taken into account to date. I understand from the Minister for Home Affairs, Senator Robert Ray, who is the responsible Minister, that further amendments will be made to pick up the recommendations of the Select Committee, perhaps in the autumn session next year. As Senator Messner will presumably find out-one of these days, but not for some considerable time yet-if he is ever involved in putting together Budgets, there are sensitive matters about which it is very difficult to consult in detail in the run up to the budgetary announcements. Certainly, while there was only a general discussion about the primary budgetary measures now before us, since the Budget announcements there have been very extensive talks with all interested parties and developing details of the legislation.

In moving an amendment in the House and in agreeing to support amendments that have been foreshadowed by the Australian Democrats today, the Government has shown its willingness to take the views of the industry very much into account. By contrast, the Opposition's only policy has essentially been to refer the whole difficult matter-it is acknowledged on all sides to be difficult-to a committee. The difficulty about referring this to a committee is that, quite apart from anything else, it would delay measures unconscionably. The revenue cost of the original Bill would be $16.5m this financial year. That reduces to just under $14m on the assumption of the passage of the amendment that has been foreshadowed by Senator Powell. It is a very large sum of money whichever way one looks at it. That would be very much at risk since the delays would obviously make quite impossible the passage of the legislation until after the decisions of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) were, for all practical purposes, already taken on the licences that had already been called. Accordingly it would represent a back door method of exempting those first four markets which would, I think, on any view of the equity and justice of this situation give them an inequitable advantage over the licences that have yet to be called. Senator Messner argues that because he claims revenue will not be received at all in 1987-88 there is time for committee consideration. However, he also claims that fees cannot be charged for licences already called. He was a little unclear at the end of the day on which horn of that dilemma he wants to finally perch his posterior. Further delays will certainly, I suppose, lead to further calls for exemptions from Senator Messner. I suggest that we are caught in a no win situation by the rather negative attitude-to put it most politely-that he has adopted.

As to the claim that no revenue will be received this financial year because of the inevitable delay in final decisions forthcoming from the Tribunal associated with the payment periods and so on after that, the Government has always recognised the tightness of the timing, bearing in mind the need for the Tribunal scrutiny of the application in question. Estimates of timing have to take account of a range of uncertain factors. All I can say is that we looked at it very carefully. While I certainly acknowledge the tightness of the timing, particularly as it will impact on the conversion fees side of it, on balance we think that the estimates are a reasonable ballpark figure. Accordingly, we are very keen to press on with the exercise.

As to some of the issues that were raised, a lot of them, I suppose, will be the subject of further debate in the hopefully not too extended committee proceedings. Let me say a word or two about some of the other matters. The AM-FM conversion fees issue has led to criticism from the Opposition, both of the change from 30 per cent to 50 per cent of current revenue in the period from the intitial Budget announcement to the introduction of legislation and on the basis of alleged inequity with the fee payable by the new licensee. The scheme in the Bills represents a different package to that announced in the Budget. In devising an alternative to the tendering scheme, the Government needed to reconsider all aspects of the new financial arrangements. The figure of 50 per cent of the establishment fee, which will be charged to the new licensee, reflects the fact that the new licensee is acquiring a new right to broadcast in addition to whatever financial advantage he derives from having it on an FM frequency. By contrast, the incumbent is only supplementing an existing right to broadcast with a new FM frequency and, as such, it is obviously the case that he should pay substantially less than the new licensee. If one looks at a claim of inequity in that comparison, the reference by Senator Messner to there being no conversion fee estimate or reference in the Budget is simply false. I draw his attention to page 309 of Budget Paper No. 1 where there is a specific reference to the conversion fee proposal. It was always intended to be subsumed in the Budget. Although it is not quantified--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is my point.
—There is certainly a reference to it and I am told that--
—Yes, I know that.

—Okay, we have each scored an equally trivial debating point and I hope that honours are now even as I move on to the next issue which relates to ABT processes. Several speakers commented on the current complexity of broadcasting legislation. I fully acknowledge the complexity. It is a jungle; it is a minefield. It justifies every description that anyone has ever offered of it. I do not blame the draftsmen for that. I suppose I do blame the sheer difficulty of coping with a fast moving, technologically very sophisticated environment.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is addressing these difficulties in three ways. First, some of the provisions of the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 3) pick up ABT suggestions for amendments of the Broadcasting Act. So here and now we are trying to streamline-admittedly in a fairly marginal way-some of the matters in issue. Secondly, we are supporting the work of the House of Representatives Committee which will be looking at the role of the ABT. Thirdly, an internal departmental review will have a wide ranging look at the scheme of the current Act, including those provisions setting out the functions and powers of the ABT. I should also mention that I hope to introduce a further piece of broadcasting legislation in a matter of days before we get up-not for debate this session, but for scrutiny over the break-which will deal with the radio ownership and cross-media issues that I foreshadowed earlier. That legislation will, as part of it, involve quite a substantial rewriting and restructuring of the broadcasting legislation, hopefully in order to make it more accessible.

On the difficult and sensitive question of the public radio planning timetable, might I just say that, although I have put down a timetable in recent months as a planning aid, that should be regarded as indicative only. I hope that it will be possible to resolve over the next few months some of the outstanding areas of concern with that timetable. Certainly, I am conscious of the problem and will endeavour to do something about it. With those remarks I commend the Bills to the House and wish them a speedy passage.
