TALK.START.PARA: -I refer to the Government's decision-or lack of decision-with regard to a matter concerning transport. I am glad that the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans, is in the chamber. I wish to draw the Senate's attention tonight to a prime example of the way Labor governments are more concerned with taxing small businesses than helping them. The situation I shall describe is also an example of intergovernmental buck-passing and bureaucratic lethargy. It is a long running problem which neither the Federal nor the South Australian government has shown the will to resolve. It relates to licence fees imposed on a small business, a bottle shop, at Adelaide Airport. This shop is run by Peter and Heather Britton and it trades as the Happy Landing Bottle Shop. The Brittons have been running this business since November 1982. As their business is located on Commonwealth property, the State Government has not imposed the usual State licence fee on the Brittons' business.

SPEECH.PARA: However, it has been a long-standing policy of the Commonwealth to impose its own comparable charge on such enterprises to ensure that they do not gain a commercial advantage over other businesses which are subject to State charges and fees. But in 1985 the South Australian Government found a way of levying its own fee on the Happy Landing Bottle Shop. The fee was imposed on the shop's wholesaler. This fee was, of course, passed on by the wholesaler to the bottle shop owners so that the Happy Landing Bottle Shop was, in effect, required to pay the State licensing fee. However, the Commonwealth's charge has not been withdrawn. Thus Mr and Mrs Britton have to pay the licence fee twice, to both State and Federal governments-a deplorable example of double taxation. In fact, this situation flies in the face of the principle behind the Commonwealth's assertion that it charges this fee only in lieu of State taxation in order not to give a commercial advantage to a small business on Commonwealth premises.

The Brittons raised this problem with Mr Heini Becker, their State member of parliament, who has been pursuing this issue for a considerable time. In turn, Mr Becker has raised this matter with me. Accordingly, I wrote to the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Peter Duncan), the junior Minister at the Department of Transport and Communications. Mr Duncan's short ministerial career at Federal level has been rather undistinguished thus far, and he does nothing to enhance his reputation in his reply to my letter on this matter, when it eventually came. The Senate will remember, of course, that Mr Duncan, when he was in the South Australian Parliament, clashed vigorously with his leader, John Bannon, now the State Premier and Treasurer, even to the point of resigning from the front bench in a great cloud of angry rhetoric. Perhaps that has flavoured his attitude to doing anything co-operatively with the South Australian Government. I suggest that this is yet another matter where Senator Evans, as the Minister for Transport and Communications, needs to take a closer look at what his junior is doing.

I wrote on 28 September this year to Mr Duncan and received his reply dated 1 December. I do not know whether Mr Duncan actually read the letter before putting his signature to it. It is a reply that Sir Humphrey Appleby himself could have produced. It makes it clear that the Commonwealth will not compromise at all in this matter. The Federal revenue grab will continue no matter what. I quote from the Minister's letter:

It is the Department of Transport and Communications' policy to charge all concessionaires who sell liquor at Adelaide airport a consideration fee at least equal to the licence fee that would be payable if they held a relevant State liquor licence. These fees are an important contribution to the Department's airport revenues which are aimed at ensuring Australian Government airports are operated in a manner which minimises their burden on the taxpayer.

In other words, the Minister's highest priority is to maintain the Commonwealth's tax grab. I note that Senator Reynolds is now in the chamber, Senator Evans having left. I must add that requiring payment in lieu of the otherwise applying State tax was a fair principle up until 1985. But the double taxation has persisted for 2 1/2 years. Despite this having been clearly pointed out to the Minister, he gives this form of words which is circuitous and contains no kind of substantial response to the problem involved. It is for that reason that I say that the Minister's highest priority is to maintain the Commonwealth tax grab. By the end of the letter the Minister is trying to slide out of the matter by saying that the Commonwealth fee should not be seen as being in lieu of the State fee. That is directly contrary to the principle that was put forward some years ago. Mr Duncan concludes:
. . . the Department could not consider the waiving of its consideration fee, which was originally levied at a rate comparable to, but not in lieu of-
so he now claims-
State licensing fees.

This playing with words reflects no credit on the Department or its Ministers. The Minister's, or should I say, the Department's, letter to me describes an attempt to get some sort of response from the South Australian Government on the issue. To someone's credit, at least an attempt was made to get the State Government to back off from its 1985 stratagem to raise some revenue. Mr Duncan's letter admits:

I can appreciate that the provisions of the (South Australia) Liquor Licensing Act 1985 and the imposition of the Department's consideration fee results in concessionaires at Adelaide Airport effectively paying twice for the right to sell liquor. In that regard the Department approached the South Australian Liquor Licensing Commissioner on July 3, 1986 with a view to obtaining an exemption from the application of the Liquor Licensing Act 1985 to any holders of an Authority issued pursuant to the Airports (Business Concessions) Act 1959. The Commissioner advised on July 8, 1986 that a report on the matter was being prepared for the South Australian Minister of Consumer Affairs, the Honourable C. J. Sumner. Subsequent inquiries indicated that the report was duly presented to Mr Sumner for his consideration. On December 8, 1986 the then Minister for Aviation, the Honourable Peter Morris, MP, wrote to Mr Sumner requesting his assistance in progressing the Department's exemption request. Since then, the Department has followed this matter up several times with the State Government Liquor Licensing Commissioner, but has not yet received a final reply. However, I am aware that the Liquor Licensing Commissioner is actively reviewing the situation and the impact of the State legislation on Airport business activities.

What a lovely phrase-`actively reviewing'. If I were more cynical, I would suggest that that is bureaucratic language for `The file is lost, but we are looking for it'. In any case, what an inglorious saga this is. Clearly the State Labor Government has no more serious interest in resolving the stalemate than the Commonwealth Labor Government. There is no sign that the State Minister communicated with the Federal Minister before the State charge was imposed in 1985. There is no sign that the State Government is willing to yield any ground. So much for co-operation between two Labor governments.

In bringing the matter before the Senate in this way, I urge Senator Evans to come to grips with this deplorable situation in which his junior has apparently been quite unable to achieve any progress. It is high time that the Commonwealth and the South Australian governments got together and sorted this matter out so that small business people like Mr and Mrs Britton can be relieved of this absurd burden of double taxation.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 October 1987 (Hansard, page 1038), Senator Childs asked Senator Walsh, as Acting Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the Acting Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce seen an article in the International Herald Tribune reporting that `odd pockets of contamination' in food keep showing up 18 months after the Chernobyl incident? As the foods range from French mushrooms, English mutton and Turkish hazelnuts to fish from Finland, are steps being taken to protect Australian consumers from imported contaminated products?
The Acting Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce undertook to refer the question to the Minister for Community Services and Health, who has provided the following additional information:

Foodstuffs imported into Australia from countries affected by the accident at the Chernobyl nuclear power station have been under surveillance since mid-1986. France, the United Kingdom, Turkey and Finland were included in the thirty-one designated countries.

Any radioactivity levels in imported foodstuffs have been such that the risk to health from consumption is negligible. It is expected that these levels will become steadily smaller in the next twelve months.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 November 1987 (Hansard, page 1528), Senator Coulter asked me, as Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister aware that the 2, 4, 5-T used in Vietnam contained on average approximately 20 times the level of 2, 3, 7, 8 tetracholo dibenzo dioxane (TCDD), with some samples of 2, 4, 5-T containing up to several hundred times the levels of TCDD now permitted in Australia? Does the Minister recognise that TCDD is a known mutagen and carcinogen? Does the Minister also accept that all recognised world authorities, such as the International Agency for Research on Cancer, believe that a linear/no threshold relationship exists between the level of exposure to a mutagen and the risk of effects arising, such as abortion and birth defects? Does it not therefore follow that the conclusion of the Evatt Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam that none of these health effects-abortions, birth defects and cancers-arose as a consequence of exposure to Agent Orange in Vietnam, is patently not supported by the evidence or by accepted scientific theory? Finally, will the Minister therefore advise her colleague, the Minister for Defence, that the Hogg inquiry must find that one of the principal conclusions of the Evatt inquiry was wrong?
The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following information:

No. However, I am advised that certain 2, 4, 5-T formulations used in Vietnam contained relatively high concentrations of 2, 3, 7, 8-tetrachlorodibenzodioxin (TCDD) as described in the `Report of the Royal Commission on Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam.' I am also advised that the published views of the International Agency for Research on Cancer are that there is sufficient evidence for the carcinogenicity of TCDD in animals but that the evidence for its carcinogenicity in humans is inadequate. That Agency also considers that the evidence for genetic activity of TCDD in short-term tests is inadequate.

As far as my Department is aware, neither the International Agency for Research on Cancer nor any recognised world authority has proposed any particular relationship between the level of exposure to a mutagen and the risk of adverse effects of the type proposed.
Mr Hogg's report is now finalised and will be considered by the Government in the near future.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 November 1987 (Hansard, page 1529), Senator Lewis asked the Acting Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Walsh, the following questions without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Question 1
Did Austrade advise the Australian companies of the opportunities to tender less than 14 days before tenders closed when Austrade had known of the opportunities for 4 months?
Question 2
Why were the documents sent with summary translations only direct to companies?
Question 3

Will the Government enquire into the manner in which this project was conducted in order to ensure timely advice and effective assistance will be given to Australian companies exporting to non English speaking countries?
The answers to the honourable senator's questions are as follows:
Answer 1

The 307 items selected from the 1500 items scrutinized by Austrade's Tokyo office were progressively released over the four month period in the daily Japanese Government Gazette. Except for three cases at the very outset of the exercise, when the timing of advice to Australian companies was dictated by the volume of tender invitations available, Austrade's Tokyo office advised companies of the opportunities within 4 days of publication of the item. In general, Australian companies had a period of between 4 and 6 weeks in which to reply.
Answer 2
Austrade's Tokyo Office has to make decisions about priorities and how best to use the resources available to it.

To avoid wasting resources on making full translations of lengthy technical documents, not all of which would be of commercial relevance to Australian firms, Austrade's Tokyo Office decided to send English language summaries. The firms themselves could then decide if a good technical and commercial match was indicated and obtain fuller translations if the prospects appeared to warrant the expense.
Firms were contacted directly because in Austrade's experience that is the most cost effective and expeditious means of conveying market intelligence to potential exporters.
Answer 3

I am satisfied that Austrade's Tokyo Office provided a prompt response, appropriate to the opportunities it perceived, to the resources available to it and to the other demands on its time and resources.

As Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce I am interested in why Australian firms did not respond more positively. Some would have made sound commercial or technical decisions not to participate. But the lack of interest on the part of some firms might be indicative of a low export orientation or a lack of experience in overseas markets.
An enquiry would not help in tackling problems of this nature.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 November 1987 (Hansard, page 2196), Senator Chaney asked Senator Gareth Evans the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: In light of the seriousness with which he regards the risks to the health of people in aeroplanes, why has he continued to expose service personnel who man the VIP flights to those health hazards, given he is not prepared to see the rest of Australia subjected to that indignity?
The Prime Minister has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The ban to be imposed by the Government applies to Regular Public Transport (RPT) flights only; in effect, airline and supplementary airline flights. As such, defence force flights of any description are not covered; neither are flights by private aircraft nor corporate jets.
